content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even though it's not finished I believe this game blows Game Dev Tycoon out of the water. The only thing GDT has on MGT is being able to build and distribute consoles, which could possibly be added in the future. (I'm not going to compare this game to Software Inc, because it's more about software in general and doesn't go into too much depth(yet) with game development like this and others in the genre).Features-Build each room within your building, giving you more control over your company (you can have 100's of employees if you want, it gets a little hard to manage in it's current state, but hopefully that will be fleshed out more)-Employees skills raise by developing/working (Game Dev has this as a mod, but I feel it works better in this game) also the skills make more sense (GameDesign, Programming, Graphics, Music & Sound, Office Work, Speed, Work Will).-Employee needs (Bathroom, heating/cooling, and furnishings)-Research new genres, topics, engine features, game sizes (B - AAA), and game improvements.-Has WAY more Genre and game topics than GDT, and there is no game genre/topic matching (which never made sense to me, there's no such thing as a bad genre/topic match in the real world, only bad games).-Release updates/patches for your games after release. (In the beginning you won't be able to fix bugs during development, but you can after release by either patching the game, which will remove a lot of bugs. You can update the game and choose to remove some bugs while also improving the game, which will improve sales as well).-Eventually you can have seperate rooms to improve your game:              ~Game Design (Remove bugs during development and improve gameplay, also where you make game reports)             ~Music Studio (obviously improves music/sound)             ~Graphic Studio (dem textures)             ~Motion Capturing (recently added, I'm not to sure on the specifics, but I believe it improves graphics/gameplay) -Sell developed game engines and make money off games made with them (you can select the initial price of the engine and the % you receive from sales)-Customer support room to keep your fans happy once you reach a certain amount. Can also run campaigns to increase fan base-Publish your game through other companies (they will produce and distribute your game, and occasionally market it).-Publish your own games! (To do this you need a production room and a storeroom. You can actually choose how many copies of a game you want to make, including the price and things like a t-shirt, game manual etc. You can also re-release older games and eventually release game packages)-Marketing!-Build a Server room and release your own MMOs! (Yes Game Dev Tycoon has MMOs too, but it works so much better in this game) You actually choose the Subscription price of your game and have to have enough servers to support your subscribers. Unlike other games, once your MMO stops selling copies it stays on the market, and you can release expansion packs. Expansion packs will act as seperate games (in terms of sales and marketing), but it will also make your base MMO start selling again. There is also a F2P option that is not usable at the moment, so hopefully the way MMO's work in general will be improved.-Licenses for movies, books, or other games that you can buy. I honestly don't even use this feature as it's not necessary and there's always another game already released under every license anyway so I don't really see the point.Possible negatives-(This one really isn't a big deal, but it annoys me). I'm not sure if the Dev is foreign, but the FPS genre is called Ego-Shooter. Never heard this term before and I don't like it at all, I could see "Ego-shooter" being used for more arcadey style games like Doom, Serious Sam, and maybe even COD to an extent, but it's not a term used in the U.S.-Managing huge teams can be annoying if you want to make sure you have the best people for each room. There is an auto-assign feature, but I'm not sure how it decides to assign employees.-As I stated before, you can't create consoles like in GDT, but hopefully it will be added.-The aspects of controling the way your game turns out (other than the skills of your employees) have specific settings for each genre that are considered "correct", but in my opinion GDT's sliders don't work much better.-No real End game as of yet, and no New game+ like GDT has.-Each genre has pictures for your game that depend on the level of technology applied used, but don't differ between topics. Ex. if you make a Fantasy Rpg and a Knight Rpg on the same engine, the pictures will be the exact same. Granted no other game in this genre has this from what I've seen.If you enjoyed GDT then buy this game, it's way better IMO. I believe this game is worth the price even if it's not finished.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												Now that the game has been released, I guess it's time to give it some attention. According to Steam Spy, this game has sold ~50,000 copies while Game Dev Tycoon (GDT) has over 1mio owners here on Steam alone. In my opinion, this doesn't reflect the games' general quality at all. It's not a perfect game, but a good tycoon sim and a lot better than its direct competitor GDT. I will try to argue what makes this game good on its own, but I guess some comparisons to GDT have to be brought up. But first, for the lazy ones:TL;DR: It's a good game. Do you like games like Game Dev Tycoon or older tycoon games like Theme Hospital? Buy it. It puts together the room and staff managment from Theme Hospital with the game dev elements from GDT. Is it perfect? No, it has some problems that might annoy you.After choosing some attributes of your company founder, in which country your studio is located in (which will have impact on your sales) and the game's difficulty, you'll start as a small dev in the early 80's. In the beginning, you'll try to survive by making small (and probably mediocre) games and doing minor additional missions to earn some money. As the time passes your possibilities and obligations grow. You have to research new technologies, build different facilities to ensure the quality of said technolgies in your games, hire staff specialised on those techs (or hire uneducated ones and put them into your training facilities), fix bugs, release updates to keep the game interesting, create marketing campaigns, analyze your games etc. You'll also have to switch your studio's location: In the beginning you develop your games in a garage. But you want to end up being a big publisher with over a hundred staffmembers working for him. So the garage might not be the perfect place for long.This game offers you a lot of different means to make some money. Besides the obious "develop a game and give it to some publisher to release it" these are some of your options: you can start developing a console, you can become a publisher yourself that releases not only his own games but also other studios' games. If you do so you have to manage the content of your boxed games (will it come with a coloured manual and a free T-Shirt or will it be a bland box with nothing but the game's CD in it?). You even can become the next Electronic Arts and buy other developers, harvest their success and after you have ran down the company sell it again.This is what sets the game apart from GDT, imo: the possibilities. You can focus on becoming one thing or do a lot of stuff at once. This raises the replayability of the game greatly. Another difference is the game's size: in GDT your highest amount of developers is around 6 or 7 guys. Well, in Mad Games Tycoon you might end up with over 100 people. You can have one team that does nothing but developing updates and expansions for your latest World of Warcraft clone. A different team does nothing but market your games and consoles. Working at multiple games at once? Not a problem at all. Fire all your dudes and do nothing but earn money with the games coming from other developers? Sure.But the game has some problems. When you play it for the first time you can't know what it takes to develop a good game. Sliders decide, how much focus your developers lay upon a certain aspect of the game. How do you find out the perfect placement of a slider? Trial and error. You can analyze your games later to check if your slider placement was correct, but it will take a while. As soon as you know the perfect 'slider position' you'll produce one great game after another. This also was a big problem of GDT and while the devs in this game made it a tad more elegant, the same problem remains. A different problem of the game is its way of building: Sure you can design a nice office that looks nice. But it will be more efficient to put as many desk as possible into small rooms. Your staff won't mind as long as you give them what they want as soon as they complain. I also have some problems with the game's visuals. It looks like a tycoon game from the 90's (while obviously having nicer textures etc.). You might find that charming or disturbing - that depends on your taste.But in the end, this is a game worth its 15 bucks (or your regional equivalent). It's a great and fun indie tycoon game and worth a shot. Like in so many tycoon games you'll get your money's worth, if you like this genre.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								A game in the vein of Game Dev Tycoon that aims to add some more depth with features like building & outfitting rooms.While the added complexity is fun at first, the underlying mechanics don't work well. The success of games seems to depend entirely on the amount of "points" invested into them. That is, if you have a good and/or large enough Staff, producing a lot of graphics/sound/tech/gameplay points, EVERYTHING will get great reviews.I just got a "Music FPS/Sports"-Game without graphics to get the Game of the Year award...I prefer the Game Dev Tycoon model, where even if you sink extreme amounts of time and money into something, it might still flop because the initial concept just doesn't work. Just like in real life.Another aspect is the economy. Income & Development costs do not scale well. Now this might be due to the fact that due to the abovementioned problem, ALL my games were getting 90%+ reviews no matter what I did, but essentially I ended up with unlimited money at some point. There is also not a really good progression system. Basically my first smash hit allowed me to go straight from a small studio to a huge office building, hire 40+ people and spam games with multiple production rooms/studios. Simultaneously, I could train a dozen code-monkeys in the training room which are now maxed out in most stats and producing the aforementioned >90% games en masse.Now of course a lot of this might still be due to alpha status and might get finetuned down the road, but at its current state I would not recommend the game.Overall, it does not handle its own complexity well and is fairly easy to exploit. A lot of refining in regards to the ingame economy is needed in order to make it more challenging & fun, so buying it now is really kind of a gamble.

Posted: April 15, 2015
Early Access Review
  Introduction            	Mad Games Tycoon is a really cool simulator that allows you to form your own game studio and rise through the ranks, from your garage to huge mega million dollar company. You can’t deny that Mad Games Tycoon does not seem a bit similar to Game Dev Tycoon (I guess a lot), but this is not a bad thing. I personally loved Game Dev Tycoon and Mad Games Tycoon deserves love in its own light. The one thing that really sets Mad Games Tycoon apart from Game Dev Tycoon is the fact that it allows so much more customization.(Office Upgrades, Storefronts, Paintings, Plants, different desks, and bookshelves One of the huge draws that Game Dev Tycoon had for me was all of the references to real life game companies and devices; Mad Games Tycoon only expands on this and creates even more amazing references and jokes. (Cupcom, EA, Pony, L ★, and tons more)  Pros                Tons of real life references Typical/Amazing gameplay Ton of customization  Great amount of graphic options Plenty of upgrades and gameplay elements     Cons               Slow paced Music gets a bit annoying (This may just be me) Not as simplistic as Game Dev Tycoon     Conclusion                 	Mad Games Tycoon is tons of fun and just builds of the Game Dev Tycoon formula. If you had fun or are looking for something more complicated game dev sim, Mad Games Tycoon is exactly what you should look at.  It add tons of customization and more in depth game elements. Mad Games Tycoon is a must have for anyone who enjoyed Game Dev Tycoon. -HiPFiRED   If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator GroupCheck out the Original Network Groups. content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mad Games Tycoon is a game with an identity crisis. It's not sure whether it wants to be an economic simulator for the games market, or a game studio micro-management simulator, and because of that it fails pretty poorly at both. A lot of the reviews laud the game for doing more than Game Dev Tycoon, but Game Dev Tycoon's simplicity is part of why the game is attractive.The micro-management in MGT is quite tedious at times. When you create a game, you have to select all the priorities, focuses etc. This part is fine. You then have to click on your graphics department and improve the graphics, then click on the audio department and improve the audio, then click on the QA department and improve the gameplay, then click on the motion capture studio and improve the filming & animation. Six times for each of these departments. Similarly, you'll need to micro-manage your production department.The marketing department can auto-repeat its campaigns, but I'd like to see this expanded into a queue system, where you can give a department jobs and have each job executed when the last finishes. I'd also like to see the ability to link up the QA, graphics & audio departments with a specific development department, so that when I start making a game, those departments automatically queue the improvements I've researched (or at least, so that when I add things to my queue, they're automatically done on the right game).The development cycle is also very inaccurate. My team of 16 developers (plus 4 QAs, 4 graphics, 4 audio, 4 motion capture) could barely put out an MMO *expansion* every 3 years. Treyarch is a similar-sized studio, and they can put out a full AAA title every 2 years. Game Dev Tycoon has a 'hype' system which allows me to predict my game's sales. In MGT, I can run a media campaign but I can't have any idea how much it's influenced sales, how many people it's reached etc. It would be great to see more media interactions like interviews, followup articles when my games reach landmark sales or news about my competitors' games.This brings me onto the other side of the coin, the market simulation. It feels like MGT is trying to simulate a market, this is something I really wanted in Game Dev Tycoon, but it's a very poor simulation.The competition never seem to decline. They grow until they are valued at $200 million, and then grow no more. A market simulation should correctly simulate their studios in the same way it simulates mine, with the games produced, their scores and their marketing determining which companies thrive and which die and/or are bought. Similarly, I've not seen any of the console manufacturers die. Atari, Sega, Microsoft, Nintendo and Sony are all active in 2050 in my game, all sitting between 8 and 20% market share.If you're going to simulate this, you'd also need a better media engine to display the information to the player. My competition are buying each other? The RPG market is saturated right now because 5 AAA RPGs were announced at E3 this year? Right now it feels like the competition only exist to be bought and to offer me terrible games to publish. Similarly, the studios I buy, even after being upgraded to 5 stars, rarely give me a game with higher than a 70% score. These studios were winning Game of the Year before I bought them.Companies should be created (it wouldn't be hard to create random company names) on a regular basis, most would go out of business after one game, but some would go on to be a success. Companies should buy each other. Publishers should buy developers. 'Franchises' should exist, which have fans (separate from company fans) and are transferred when you buy their owners.Minor bones to pick:- Random game titles destroy immersion, 'Rabbit Quest' the sports simulation and 'Ice Hockey Manager' the ego shooter? Please create lists of topic/genre specific terms and a better algorithm to create the names.- Engines are ridiculous. I managed to get from 1980 to 1995 without releasing a game. I just researched, created engines and sold them for $0 + 40% of profit. I made an absolute killing and got to my 3rd office this way.- The game is too easy. By the end I could buy all the devs for pocket change, and none of them grew to my size/scale.- No Linux/Mac support in 2015.- Performance was poor even on modern (i7, 8GB RAM, Intel HD4000) hardware.- The Marketing menu doesn't have a confirm button. ALL of the other menus do. This has caused me to waste $ on the wrong campaigns multiple times.- Staff item requirements are ridiculous. I had to buy a cheap refridgerator for my staff room even though I already had the expensive one, had to buy an orange chair in an office where everything was blue, etc.The game is not without its positives, you really do get a lot of choice, and a lot of control over the focus and design of your studio. You get to know your staff, you can train your teams; you can find a publisher, self-publish or even publish other studios' games. The game has charm and can be enjoyable at times. It's just that the lack of difficulty and a deeper market simulation overshadows the positives.MGT has a lot of ambition, but really isn't well-tuned in any of it. It is in early access, and if the developers can tighten the scope a little and fix the balance issues, it shows promise to become the forerunner in this emerging niche. Until the developers make the changes I've mentioned, though, I wouldn't recommend anyone spend their money on this title.

Posted: September 15, 2016
												I'm a huge fan of tycoon games and this one is probably one of the best I've played, BUT:Most of the positive reviews were in regards to EA development and developer's response to players feedback, not that much on gameplay itself which certainly has some flaws. After 24hrs of playing this game, I feel a bit dissapointed, and I will try to explain in as much detail as I can.Some of the biggest flaws for me at least are replayability, game depth and difficulty and some minor flaws are lack of polish in certain areas.-ReplayabilityI had only 2 restarts before I made it to the endgame, from the earliest start (1980), slowest game setting and highest difficulty, where I managed to get to a pretty big profit and it all started to become pretty much repetitive. I don't feel that there is much to be done differently in a new restart, so I really see no point in doing that.-Game DepthAlthough there are quite a lot features you can add to your games, the closer you get to an endgame, the more you feel like there is not much more tweaking to do. I pretty much soon found myself cranking the game speed to max, selecting everything there is for my new games or my updates and started looking for something new I could do to amuse myself, but sadly there really wasn't much more to do, and it was only year 2014. Sure there were some new technologies comming up, but I really didn't care much about them, as they wouldn't make much difference because you could repeat your last succesful recipe and make the best game over the competitors.-DifficultyI really don't find myself as a harcore player that plays games on legendary setting, and I've played only few games on highest difficulty, but in this game I decided to start immediately after I figured the basics in the tutorial, and succesfuly made it to the endgame, continuously being on the top over my competitors, and even producing 100% game in the early endgame.-Minor flawsI personally feel there should be some automated procesess like managing an auto-update of your game for your developers over a certain period of time. Also there should be some kind of an option to save room layout because every time I moved my company to bigger offices, I felt pain of creating rooms that were working for me in the previous office, and not to mention selecting my workers one by one and assigning them to appropriate rooms all over again. Overall, I feel the game was fun for about 20hrs, but if I knew that it would be only one playthrough for me, I definitely wouldn't pay more than 10$ for it, because I like my tycoon and management games to be much more replayable than this one.Still Recommended - 8/10

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mad Games Tycoon is a pretty awesome game developer management sim. It's one of the few early access games I've bought, but I'm irrationally obsessed with Game Dev sims like Game Dev Tycoon and Game Dev Story. Eggcode's take on game dev management adds much needed customization options and depth to the experience by allowing you to build rooms and assign employees to specific rooms to perform specific tasks.Before I get to the bad, I would like to say up front that I freaking love this game. I've had tons of fun and I think it's absolutely worth the purchase if you enjoy tycoon games or want another take on the Game Dev Tycoon style of management sims. The team at Eggcode is a standout example of how to do early access right and deserves recognition for their constant bug fixes and content patches that range from adding new rooms and employees to improving the UI. That's also part of the frustration of this game. I'm sure that this was a gameplay choice, but having to build special rooms for certain tasks gets annoying. For example, the games core development all happens in one room. Bug fixes have to take place in a seperate room for QA. If it takes the QA team longer to squash the bugs than it takes for the core team to finish development on the game, the development room is rendered useless until you choose to launch the game. Not to mention, the development team can't help fix bugs unless they're dragged away from development and pushed into the QA room. I get that the music studio, art offices and motion capture rooms should be standalone, but why can't the core staff improve level design?That is my biggest issue. Everything else is a minor problem. I don't like how many clicks it takes to assign tasks to almost every room except for the development rooms. The UI isn't that great. The art isn't terribly nice to look at and I wish there were more (or custom) logos to choose from. But the art didn't effect my enjoyment.Like I mentioned above, I love this game. It's fun and I've lost afternoons to this game. I can't wait to see how Eggcode continues to improve this already enjoyable game.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've put 20 hours into this game and I'll probably put many more. I've played several Game Dev sims and this is the only one besides Game Dev Tycoon that I have thought was worth the money. I loved Game Dev Tycoon and have spent quite a bit of time on it, I was even part of the group that bought it back before it was on steam and was still in development. I have crafted numerous companies in that game but was always at the end left wanting a little more. Mad Games Tycoon gave me that. There is a lot more to being successful in this game and once I got the point my company was making real money and was in a medium sized building I found myself constantly engaged. Between marketing, development, research, employee training, meeting employee desires, hitting trends, contract work, rearranging, etc I stayed on the move constantly. The career felt so much longer than GDT's (which if you can't tell is the standard for me) and I even wanted to keep playing after the consoles stopped rolling in from other companies, which is usually when I would restart in GDT. It took quite a few hours to get to that point too because you can choose several options when choosing difficulty regarding how quickly time passes. Of course in game there are the standard Sims style speed buttons but you can choose how quickly beyond that days pass. After 20 hours I have a company worth 16 billion dollars with several successful consoles, MMO's and AAA titles to my name as well as a 97% positive reputation in the industry. Even after all that I still want to keep playing, maybe even restart now that I know what I am doing and see how fast I can get back to that point. I loved this game so much I actually took the time to write this, my first written steam review. That should say something.Gameplay: 10/10Replayability: 8/10Fun Factor: 10/10

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
Early Access Review
***Disclaimer: This is a long review! Sorry.***Allow me to preface by saying that I own both the Kairosoft original 'Game Dev Story' on my phone as well as the similar release Game Dev Tycoon here on steam. Huge fan of both, but there was always something missing in a way. I feel like this game takes the things that I liked about both of those games(time/micro management), removes the things that I didn't like(RNG), and adds a few new things to keep me engaged(building)! I spent all day playing this yesterday without even realizing it. How do they compare? Here is my breakdown so far: Game Dev Story/Tycoon- You reasearch technology and genres while doing contracts in between for extra cash so that you can eventually release big titles, gain fans, and maybe even take over the world? The not so fun thing about these games was that if you got lucky and managed an amazing score on a certain game, future releases would be forever held to that standard which in turn made it very tedious to try and stay afloat while releasing a quality product that your fans would like. Half of the time the score would seem a bit random even if you did all the right things like combining the right genres and putting your strongest team to work on the more dificult parts. It would get frustrating when you would lose power or your machines would break down, ruining all progress on any of the titles you work on. This isn't so bad at first, but it happens more as the game goes on which effectively makes the time and care you put into making a good game title pointless. You also had to grind out 'Research Points' to be able to learn about anything which took valuable time away from making money among other things. In short, while fun at first, but was hurt by seemingly RNG mechanics and too much micro management which I never thought possible. Mad Games Tycoon- Still research everything from technology to genres but it only requires money. You can actually design your game company with special rooms just for your developers, researchers, marketers, customer service reps, etc. You can even build a warehouse/production area so you can publish all your games in house and watch them fill the shelves! It made it really easy for me to keep track of who does what and making sure they were on task. You don't have to worry about a previous game's high score effecting future releases with unrealistically imposed standards. You don't lose power or progress and your employee stats are much clearer and easier to gain. You don't have to grind research or any other kind of currency besides just money which allows me to spend my time doing other things to help my company thrive. Training your employees is much less costly and everything from their stats to the game creation seems to be a lot more streamlined. I also love that you can change where any of your employees are working with a simple click and drag.As far as early access titles go, this product is pretty polished! My only gripes are that once your company starts to get REALLY big the game starts to struggle with the load. I had the big 2 room office which is the largest one you can get and while most things were still running smoothly, the hiring window was really laggy. I also wish there was a way to hit pause on the game time while a dialog box is open notifying me of something so I don't lose time in between tasks. Things to keep in mind:This game, like its predecessors, can be very unforgiving at first til you learn how everything works. Expect to restart your game a few times within the first hour of playing as you get the hang of it. Don't be afraid to exlpore and make mistakes. Try new things! When in doubt, save first! You can reload if things go badly.You have toggles on the bottom of your screen in case you keep accidentally picking up furniture when trying to click an employee.Keep an eye out for a sad face icon on the lower left hand side of your screen. That is your employees trying to tell you they need something to thrive. It's usually shelves or fire extinguishers so fix it. Otherwise they work at half their normal speed.

Posted: February 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Since many of you will probably compare this to Game Dev Tycoon, I suppose it would be a good idea to base this review off of that.For starters, Mad Games has much deeper strategy that what is in Game Dev Tycoon. You also have competing game companies that you have to deal with if you want the sacred GOTY Award. Or if you'd prefer to be aggressive, you can just buy out all your competition.As far as comparisons go, they both focus around creating vidya games as well as the gaming empire that surrounds them. Your lil people level up the more they do things, and bankruptcy is a huge threat.Or to put it simply, Mad Games Tycoon is an excellent compliment to Game Dev Tycoon, and they're both good on their own.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								To sum up this game as simple as possible, take Game Dev "Tycoon" and then add in standard Tycoon space/room management, and you end up with this. It has a lot more things to do game play wise then GDT and feels more enjoyable even in early access but definitly does feel like it suffers from the same issue of GDT of each genre having a perfect slot for the sliders  to get the best sales, so doesn't really let you make silly things unless its in the tending right now things.With that said, if you hated GDT then this probably isn't for you, if you thought GDT was meh but like tycoon games like Theme Hospital, Rollercoster tycoon, et then you may find this game enjoyable even though it has some of the same issues as GDT. And if you enjoyed GDT and hate normal Tycoon games then you may not like it, and if you liked GDT and love other tycoon games then you will probably love it.All in all it's definitly not a must buy, but this is definitly much more of a tycoon game then GDT was and has more things to do.  I personally liked this game a lot more but I also grew up on games like Airport Tycoon, Rollercoaster Tycoon, Railroad Tycoon, etc so I probably like tycoon games more then I would if I didn't grow up on them.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								I don't often review Early Access titles, but I also don't tend to buy them either.  This is a very worthy exception.  As a game dev myself, I've definitely played Game Dev Tycoon and had my fun with it but found the lack of depth quite lacking.  I wanted more control over my environment even if it might not resemble a real game studio.  Mad Games Tycoon brings that to the table - this is the first one I've played that felt more like I was crafting an actual studio and reacting to the market place with all its ups and downs.For an Early Access release at this price point, I'm surprised at how much is already in the game.  At this point you have a functioning sandbox with a compelling upgrade tree and system to work out for progressing your company.  Customizing the office to do what I want is already there, letting me prioritize how I want - including making multiple projects happen at once as my studio expands.  You can decide pretty early on how you want your studio to function, as a studio that primarily specializes in its own projects and later on you can even build your own production warehouse and start printing and publishing for others.  You can be a handheld developer or a AAA MMO powerhouse.  The sheer amount of options you can build up to as the projects grow in complexity is mind-boggling even at this early stage.Right now the biggest con is that you hit a point where about late game you start to run out of research options.  There's no campaign or score, its just the sandbox, so you will hit a point where all you can do is just make millions.  It takes quite a while to hit that part, and the office space upgrades in particular are expensive enough to give you goals to work towards, but there isn't as much competition as I'd like.The other big con is that the tutorial is VERY short and a lot of features are not well explained when they come into play, leaving you guessing how they work.  For example, random events don't provide a lot of data on such things as how long they last - a big deal when you're camping on a game to release it to market AFTER a market crash!  A lot of the data the game tracks isn't useful either, or broken up over several screens when it should be in just one.  I was particularly annoyed that I couldn't just pull up an easy stat screen on a finished project that included release date, sales, financial data, and scores.  The guesswork in the development process could also use some fine tuning - right now, after you ship one game in a genre, the next one you ship in that genre will display arrows providing hints as to which direction you need to devote resources... but nothing more concrete.  It would be better if after shipping a LOT of games in a genre, the UI became more precise to let you know exactly what the sweet spot for resource distribution is.  Right now there's also no data given when you assign priorities to development, leaving you guessing even when you've succeeded as to why you did well.I bring these issues up because updates are rather frequent at the time, and address things like this.  I'll be keeping an eye on this game to see how it keeps shaping up.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												Mad Games Tycoon is like the Name already says a Tycoon Game. Your task is to build a Game Studio from scratch.  I am a huge fan of “Game Dev Tycoon” so I wanted to play this one for quite a while, and I’m glad that I finally found the time to do so. It all starts small…in a garage...Gameplay Mad Games Tycoon plays like a typical Tycoon game. You start off with some Employees and a few basic skills. As the game progresses you can hire new Employees and build different rooms for the different aspects of Game Design.For Examples: Development/Research/Marketing and many more!When you earned enough Money you can buy a new Building for your Studio. What I really like is that you have to build the Studio by yourself, there are no set rooms. It is all in your hands, and you have to decide how much, of the limited, space each Department gets. Also it is to you furnish every room and check if your Employers like to work for you. Each NPC has their own set of skills in different categories like Game Design, Programming and Sound etc.    Besides that, the game offers you a huge variety of different genres and topics for your games to experiment with.The Game mechanics are working well together and supplement each other.Also Mad Games Tycoon never gives you the feeling to be lost. Beside the good tutorial, the new Gameplay features are added with good time intervals in-between them so you will never feel overwhelmed. I was always exited for what comes next. The game has 4 different difficulties from Easy to Legendary and different “speeds” so it offers a challenge for casuals as well as for pros.  Technic Nothing I can complain here. The graphic is good and helps to keep an overview, which gets important later when you are moving into the bigger Buildings. I never had a single stutter or anything else in my whole playtime. Only the music got annoying for me after some time. Story If you want a Story this game is not for you. Conclusion If you are a fan of games like Game Dev Tycoon or other tycoon games I can definitely recommend the game to you. You will get a great and fun Tycoon Game which offers you many hours of Gameplay. If you’re new to such games but interested in the topic I would say “go for it” The game has a good tutorial that will help you to get into it and it never overruns you with its features.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												TL;DR: At it's core, this is a more fleshed out Game Dev Tycoon.  Unfortunately, there are a lot of small annoyances born from sloppy design that before long start to add up.  Unless you have a lot of patience, it isn't worthwhile in its present state.  Only recommended if it's on sale, or if a patch cleans things up.I'm writing this review because, honestly, I like this game.  At the same time, though, I can't really recommend it, because of a lot of small issues that add up to a few big ones.This game is, at its heart, a combination of Game Dev Tycoon and Theme Hospital.  It's different enough from the former that things will go very badly for you if you try to use any prior experience.  The latter was what initially drew me to the game, but unfortunately the implimentation leaves a lot to be desired.  In fact, that's where the first big problems start to show up.Much like in Theme Hospital, the player has to create several specific rooms, each with their own unique function.  These must be furnished with a number of items, including generic work stations, cabinets, trash cans, and so on and so forth.  Rooms can only be rectangular, and must have a non-blocked door, but not next to a corner.  This seems like a really, really minor thing, except that it inevitably leads to having to Tetris rooms, sliding them around with the 'move' function until you finally manage to squeeze everything together.The second nuisance is the variety of things rooms require for furnishing.  Having a lot of things you can add based on your tastes is a good thing.  Having a lot of things you HAVE to add, lest you incur a penalty until you find a way to squeeze them into the already-cramped space, is just annoying.The biggest offender is the First Aid stations: you need one of these in every room people are going to frequent, lest they randomly become 'injured' and unable to work for an obnoxiously long span of time.  And even if you've added them to every room, sometimes they just don't work; having to delay a release for a month while you wait for the one specialist you need to recover from a random injury gets old quickly.But the thing that REALLY bugs me is that, if characters don't have a clear path from place to place, they'll just teleport there.  This isn't a bug, there's an animation for it.  This severely undercuts the need to try to be ergonomic, and considering the ratio of space to crap is already a problem, it quickly becomes easier to just stop caring.  At which point a good chunk of the game becomes a tedious distraction, rather than something fun and interesting.The 'Game Dev Tycoon' half of the game fares better, but still has its share of annoying issues.  The biggest of these is that the game is somewhat player-hostile.  The tutorial doesn't explain the stats, failing to intuit what the sliders have to be set to will result in games that fail to make back their development cost, and relevant information is frequently stuck in sub-menus far away from where it might be relevant.Game Reports are an excellent example of this: for starters, you're unlikely to even be able to get them before Year 3, at which point you'd have to already know a good chunk of what they tell you.  Before that, all you'll get is cryptic reviews and the rare email from fans telling you that one of the sliders was too far in one direction or another.Once you've managed to unlock the QA room - WHY they're tied to the QA room instead of the Reaserch Room I cannot begin to fathom - you have to have one or more developers tie themselves up with writing them.  The menu for selecting which games to get reports from is buggy; there is no button to start the queue, the only way I could get it to start required checking off reports until the menu closed itself and the devs started writing them.  While Game Reports are being written, you can't look at existing Game Reports unless you build a second office, or start development on a new game.The entire interface feels kludgy: the Bank icon appears in SOME menus when making selections that have an associated cost, but not others; the escape key does different things depending on where in the menu system you happen to be; information alternates between being readily available and hidden behind several layers of menus; the stats don't have tool-tips, but the engine add-ons do; you get a little picture of your in-game avatar at the start of a new game, but you have no means of customizing it at all, not even the option of picking from among the various pre-fabs that will make up your employees; vital explanations for what things actually MEAN are nowhere to be found; the game remembers slider positions from the last game you made of ANY genre, so you have to either write down their previous positions or avoid making more than one type of game; and so on, and so on.  This feels like an Early Access title that got released six months too early.And the most frustrating thing of all is that past all of the irritation and clutter, a solid game is THIS close to happening.  There is a much greater importance on employee management, and it's a ton of fun to create developer teams for several genres.  But more often than not a parade of things will get in the way, and before long the slog through the sloppy interface and the constant micromanagement of trashcan-radiator-shelf-desk-photocopier arrangments drag the experience down, until it isn't worth it anymore.

Early Access Review
								To be honest: Mad Games Tycoon was more fun then i expected. In my opinion it delivers enough to be worth buying at this stage of development. Be aware though, it's much different from Game Dev Tycoon. Thats either a pro or a con, depending on the way you look at it. I think its a pro and both games are fun in their own way. One isn't better then the other, they're different and can both be lots of fun.If i would compare Game Dev Tycoon with Mad Games Tycoon i would say GDT has more focus on the game development and less on business simulation, where as MGT is much more of business simulation tycoon. For example: in MGT you spend relativly more time on upgrading your building, producing games in your factory and managing your staff. And creating a good game itself isn't much of a challange in MGT, compared to GDT.Pro's:- enough content to meet the expectations at this stage of development- lots of charts and stats to play with- gameplay looks promising, with the more content and challanges it can be a pretty nice game- actual business simulation elements in it, havn't seen that for a while in a game!- lots of fun possibilities, like your own game factoryNeutral:- okay graphics and sound, nothing special- could use some customization options for the chartsCon's:- controls are a bit sloppy, but can be changed pretty easy i assume- creating games isn't much of a challange, it does'nt have to copy GDT but it could be made a bit more challanging- at the point where you run a big business, it gets a bit hard to keep oversight... this could use some work

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								Since my previous review was from February last year, I thought that it was time I updated my review.Mad Games Tycoon (MGT for short) has seen a lot of progress in the last year. This early access titlle is one of those pears that will continue to see updates until it is finished. The developer continues to improve the game and has on ocasion fixed reported bugs within twenty four hours.Admittedly, that doesn't happen often, since it's better to do a lot of bug fixes in one then dozens of patches to fix single bugs, but it HAS happened. The game supports many languages which is mostly done by other people. That being said, Stefan (that's the dev's name. I think.) could definetely  improve his English. It's a world language and if you release a game on Steam then it's first language should always be English. Well, in my humble opinion at least.My opinion of the game hasn't changed. It is definetly worth purchashing and if you have doubts... Watch a let's play. That should at least show you what the game is like.Now, there are a lot of people who compare MGT to other titles. I'm not going to name those titles here, I don't want to start yet another bash fest, but keep in mind folks, there are only 'so many' ways you can do a game like this.While the art is simiilar to some titles, that could be because of how the game is made.As always, this title is in early access, so some features are still missing, incomplete and there may or may not be imbalances. Always keep early access in mind, because it is ALWAYS a risk and the game can ALWAYS be abandoned mid development for various reasons.Trust me, I know. If and when you buy any early access title, and it goes sour, then you don't have basis to complain. You knew what you were getting into, and the risks you were and are taking. Anyway, buy or not buy?Definetly. BUY.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Despite the title, Mad Games Tycoon has no correlation to the other Mad game, Tv Tycoon, despite both games sharing a very eerily similar title. The devs deny it but can't help question the likeness. Regardless, Mad Games Tycoon has more in common with Game Dev Tycoon, except that MGT is more indepth and has a lot more too it.Already as an early access title, its got enough features to keep you entertained. Where as Game Dev Tycoon is more of a mobile type of game, and rather simple in design, Mad is designed to be more PC worthy in that it has a lot more features such as running your own production machines, storage and servers for online games that you have to setup. You also have to setup a support team for technical support, and keep your dev team happy and productive with amenities dotted abuot the office. Although I've yet to see any direct consequences of NOT having stuff around to keep your employee morale up, it may become more prominent later on.There's also the fact that you can essentially build your own office and place things where you need them. Mad Games Tycoon definitely reminds me of an old PC game called 'Startup' that had a lot of these features, but in the end was a very poor implementation. MGT seems to have gotten it right, so far at least. Their are a few shortfalls however that the game lacks that I hope the devs work on in the future, this including staff categories and perhaps a more immersive background experience, perhaps a road and some animated cars/people walking by including all the noise that comes with that?I'm also not sure if modding features are ever going to be supported, but hopefully they will.Regardless, if you liked Game Dev Tycoon, or even, if you didn't like it and thought it was too simple, then I can recommend this as so far its a great title, and it looks to improve even more in the near future.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ever since I completed Game Dev Tycoon in a few entertaining evenings I have longed for something more.  I waited with much eagerness for some kind of update or sequel but sadly none was forthcoming.  Well thankfully this game came along and I really couldn't be happier.  My review will compare it to Game Dev Tycoon.PROS:Game is slower - it really allows for you to get stuck in and enjoy all the little components that involve running your company.  Also allows for you to keep up with the market instead of being one step behind all the time.More to develop - Not only can you develop games but you can also develop game engines (which is a great way to make some money) this is a lovely touch.  There is also more to develop in terms of what you want in your game.  Plus when you come to produce your own game you have some freedom to decide what to include in the box and how much you want to sell it for.  There are also many more genre's and topics Buildings - it's refreshing to be able to build and equip your own offices.  Much more freedom to decide how much you want to spend/how many people you want working on something.Staff Training - much easier, much quicker and much more effectiveCONS:Can get annoying when people won't work for you because you don't have a certain fridge or seat.  In some cases I have had the luxury version but people won't work for me because I didn't have the cheaper version.UI can get a little annoying.  I can't think of how to describe it but the expanding boxes type of thing becomes monotonous and you have to go through a few boxes sometimes to get what you want.  Be good to be able to pick multiple things too, especially when selecting platforms.  The screen can become a little cluttered also.  Be nice if the full screen would work but I can't seem to get it to do so.No ability to develop your own console (at least not that I have found).No tutorial although it is easy enough to figure out.OVERALL:This is a really good game and I'm sure it will continue to improve.  It is far better than Game Dev Tycoon and provides an enjoyable gaming experience.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love Game Dev sims. Game Dev Story was one of those games that managed to burn away many hours of my life. It still is one of my favourite games on my iPhone. And for a long time, it was also pretty much the only game of its kind. Thankfully, Game Dev Tycoon came out in 2012. While it managed to be similar to the aforementioned game, it was also a bit more complex and supported mods. I played it a lot back in the day, but it never became an evergreen for me. Thankfully, Mad Games Tycoon has been in Early Access for some time now and I think it's the right moment to write this little review of it.Mad Games Tycoon takes a similar, but more complex approach to the topic at hand: You start off in a garage, alone, with your new company and you immediately get to build rooms, Theme Hospital-style. You even get to buy furniture, which has some impact on hiring new employees for your young studio. More talented people only pop up, if your company has enough stars, which in turn are determined by the quality of furniture you have in your office. At the beginning, you won't have a lot of stars, since you need most of your money in order to finance your first games. While they are cheap to produce at the beginning, you have running costs, like the salaries of your employees and of course the upkeep of your studio.Producing games is relatively simple at first. You define the name, genre and focus of your game. Each genre has a different focus, so you'll have to experiment and invest in a quality assurance department in order to find out what's the perfect mix. The closer you get, the higher the critics score your game and the better your game will sell. Later on, you can even combine some genres, but some combinations work better than others. You also take care of updating your games, which can have a positive impact on sales.While this certainly sounds easy enough, there are additional things you can take care of. You can decide to develop your engines yourself, which has the added benefit that you can sell said engine to other game producers and get a fraction of the money they make with games that use your engine. This means you'll also have to invest time and money into research. Buying a licence for a third party engine is an option too, of course, but you'll be loosing a portion of your profits.When your games start getting bigger, you'll need to invest in a quality assurance department and dedicated graphics, music and motion capture studios, in order to improve those areas of your games. This also means you'll need bigger offices quick and this is where one of my biggest problems with this game can be found: When you get a new office, you'll need to build all your departments from scratch and reassign your entire workforce. Now, this is manageable the first time around, but it gets tough quickly. In one of my games, I had a workforce of over 100 people and it was impossible to assign them properly in a timely manner. Sure, you have the possibility to arrange them by five different attributes, but that is not enough. The game lacks a filter for unassigned workforce, which makes life harder than it needs to be. Maybe this will be added at some point later in the development.The latest addition to the game is console development. While it doesn't look like it's completely integrated yet, it is pretty awesome to research and develop your own console and push it on the market to let it go up against the NES. You can set the price for your console and developing for it is pretty cheap. Unfortunately, right now I haven't managed to develop an exclusive title that turned a profit...While the gameplay is fun and the systems are comprehensive, the presentation still leaves a bit to be desired. Graphics are simple, yet functional and the music is ok for the first couple of hours but soon starts to get on your nerves. Some soundeffects are overused, especially the telephone, which thankfully can be switched off separately. Performance takes a notable hit too when there are more than 100 people working in your studio.While these are some important complaints I have about the game, I'm also certain that at least some of those things will improve over time. But right now, Mad Games Tycoon is the Game Dev-Sim to go! It's more complex and more satisfying in almost every way compared to similar games.

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 14, 2016
												---- Preface    This game is pretty darn good and it's FINALLY out of Early Access! I bought this game a while back in late 2015 right after looking over the shoulder of my brother who was watching a lets player playing it. I just had to have it because it looked so darn good... and it WAS.    So why is this game so good? Months before this I had bought Game Dev Tycoon and thought it was the most addictive game to ever be released on steam. I played that game for long hours and long nights and would be quite fulfilled, but something was missing.    One might jump to comparing this game to Game Dev Tycoon, however while the game is about making games and becoming a successful game developement or console developement company Mad Games Tycoon takes Game Dev Tycoon's preface to a whole new level in terms of gameplay and offers a much more refined experience in my oppinion.---- Game Dev Tycoon vs. Mad Games Tycoon    Game Dev Tycoon was a brilliant game back when it was released and to this day it provides a fun experience but Mad Games Tycoon gives MUCH more freedom to choose what you want to do with your company. Game Dev Tycoon forces you to follow one path. The only thing you can hope to do in Game Dev Tycoon is to make good games and produce consoles so you feel extremely limited whereas Mad Games Tycoon lets you make almost any type of gaming company that you want. You can be a developer, engineer, publisher, console maker, or my personal favorite: PUBLISHER'S ♥♥♥♥♥! Yup! You can be Bungie, Infinity Ward, Dice, and Treyarch in this game! Nothing like being Activ-Vision's or Electronic Artist's ♥♥♥♥♥ ammaright? Jokes aside, this game gives you many more options than Game Dev Tycoon for what kind of company you want to be. You can also customize your building and choose what kind of offices there would be and how big they would be and where they were. Bottom line, this game is SOOOOO much more customizable and less stream-lined than Game Dev Tycoon. Whether or not that is a good thing is up to you but I LOVE this game's customizability.---- Pros    - Balanced and Rewarding Gameplay    - Not Terrible Graphics    - Runs Well and Doesn't Crash (as far as I have played)    - It's Just Dern Fun---- Cons    - Game Gets Boring at the End    - Graphics Not Amazing, But for a Theme    - Doesn't Really Seem to End, Just Goes On---- Last Thoughts    Mad Games Tycoon is a pretty darn good game but it is not life changing. It's a lot like Game Dev Tycoon with a heck of a lot more to do and a lot more freedom. If steam had a /10 rating system I would rate it at 7.8/10 -Too Many Rooms

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								I wish listed this game, and decided to give it a try when it went on sale via Steam.My expectations were fairly low given that Game Dev Tycoon is already out there, and the fact that this is in early access.  That said, I was pleasantly surprised to learn that I had severely underestimated this game.  From a strategic standpoint, as well as various gameplay options, it provides a deeper experience than Game Dev Tycoon (not to continually compare the two, but I'm having a difficult time avoiding that). The added element of designing how to utilize your blank work spaces was a welcome wrinkle, as compared to other games of this type.  I've purchased and played Game Dev Tycoon, GamersGoMakers, as well as Game Dev Story on mobile.  To me, on balance, Game Dev Tycoon was the best of these games.  Once this version is complete, I believe this will be the go-to "game making" game for me.If you're a fan of Game Dev Tycoon, this is a must-buy.  Especially if you can get it when it's on sale..  Just make sure you can set aside a few hours first.10/24/16 Edit:There have been significant additions, updates, and various items cleaned up since my initial review.  The developers have been making those improvements steadily, and have been communicative about issues that have arised.  The price of the game has doubled since I initially purchased, but I would say that I would gladly purchase it at the $14.99 US price poitn that it's currently at, given how much enterainment it's provided.  Original recommendation stands, if you liked Game Dev Story, this is a must purchase.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								|Disclaimer: Game goes on sale regularly, so don't pay full price, if you want to buy it.|This game is developing slowly, but steadily into the right direction. It's already completely enjoyable to play and feels feature complete for the price tag.There are a couple of games similar to Game Dev Tycoon out there and this one has become my favourite, because it just keeps throwing features, genres, technologies and stuff at you all the time, basically incorporates the entire Game Developing and Console Developing features from GameDevTycoon while improving on it.If you have played Gamers Go Makers or GameCorp DX you will realize that the genre actually offers a lot of possibilities in regards of adding rooms and facilities. Mad Games is the only game in the field that let's you create big teams doing different things in different rooms with a decent presentation.In addition you get stuff like MMOs with a Server Room, Sequels for great games and Add-Ons for the MMOs.The game development itself is pretty much the same in all games. You can use look-up-tables on the net to create the perfect game or stumble your way to perfection with your own table, or memory. With all the Genres and Topics in the game you will probably go crazy making your own table and definitely unable to remember everything that worked with all the sliders.Mad Games not only takes the "hint" feature that Game Dev Tycoon introduced with a patch, but it also lets you re-apply the same setup from a previous project. The advantage being, that you can develop an RPG, then a Sports Game and then another RPG, load the RPG settings and re-adjust from there on out, instead of being forced to manually switch everything back from Sports to RPG. And thanks to the "hints" that appear, the more you develop within a certain topic/genre mix, the more of those hints you will see and the better your team becomes.Is it the perfect game? Not by a long shot.It's way too easy too be a successfull developer and the result is that I have no idea how platforms and genre mixes work.Your workers don't age and their wages are quite low in comparison to what they start earning for you. This makes the game easier, but on the other hand you don't get the management horror of a Software Inc. , which is nice.Once you develope a great MMO game you are done. It's GG. You could say that this is realistic and you are probably right. Just look at the history of Blizzard. If you are going for money, go for subscribers. You can also release a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ sports game every year without learning anything in the process or improving the engine, so that's realistic, but also too simple.Overall the best reimagination of the original GameDevTycoon concept by Greenheartgames. I'm sure we are going to see another one of those in the future that will surpass Mad Games, but for now I'm declaring it the best game developing tycoon out there.I wish there were more games in that style. Especially if they could switch from Game making into a more detailed movie making simulation. A blend of the classic Molyneux' The Movies with the now 2nd Generation Indie Management games would be the best.For the presence, we have to stick with Mad Games Tycoon.

Making games as contracts never seems to be worth the trouble over regular contracts.

It's got nice visuals, and building your studio adds a lot more depth than just making game after game and upgrading like the others. There are a lot of management-type games coming out lately, I wrote this review with the hope that this one gets the attention it deserves. If you want a game dev sim, this is the one; for business sim fans, check it out too. it's worth a look for sure.

number of helpful: 14 of 19 people (74%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was hesitant at first to buy Mad Games Tycoon until it was 50% off, but after 10+ hours of the game, I am becoming increasingly happy with the game and the community are very nice people. You, the reader already knows that you are your own game development company, but more of a Sims effect is placed in the game, because you the owner are to create different rooms including development, research, etc. and place objects in there including desks, etc. The more starred things you purchase, the better employees you hire and the further efficient your staff and you are.Making the games is a fun process. It varies each game you produce, but it can get annoying considering it gives you hints as to whether which side you should make your game. For example, do you choose more of a focus on graphics over gameplay or vice versa, and after creating a game for that genre, it would give a suggestion to go to say, the graphics side of things. It can get very easy and with the limited amounts of genres and topics, it is easy to reproduce the same type of game with the same focus under a different name and get a high rating.The game however, is in early access still (I'd say mid Alpha as there aren't all features implemented yet) and for right now, the basics are there, they just have to be developed more. For example, I'd love to have more of a intertwine between the games you make and how that affects the NPC world, does it affect the sales of your competitors, or vice versa. The similarities are there with Game Dev Tycoon, but I think both are distinct. They follow the same basic guideline of making games, but both do so in a different way and I personally think Mad Games Tycoon is much more in-depth so far than Game Dev Tycoon, especially in the Alpha stage.The later part of the game (Past 2010) is not fully developed yet. The NPC companies work still the same, but I find an unbalanced effect happening. Playing in easy, by 2010, I have released about 10 games with three hitting first on the all-time charts, by 3x what the NPC game was. My three would final sell at 13+ million copies while the highest NPC one would be 4.5 million. Another example is, less features pop-up following 2010 and I have noticed by 2020, the game has stopped releasing consles, features to develop, but NPCs still release there games. To expand on this though, I'd think that everything hasn't been implemented purely because with all features so far in the game being researched, there is 41 or 42 features (and with the improvements in features like parallex scrolling compared to basic scrolling) the usable count in a AAA game (mind you, AAA games allow 50 features max) is about 33. Thats my own real flaws as it can become increasingly easy late game, but then again, I'm playing on easy and haven't really tested the higher difficulties as I had did a full playthrough of normal, but that was prior to a patch recently while buffed the difficulties of all levels.At the moment, I'd say buy the game. I have had two full run throughs in about 10 hours, with the game setting on easy and me fast forwarding everything. It isn't a full finished product yet and the updates are regular (actually the updates coming every week or week and a half and if a hotfix is needed, a hot fix comes about 2-3 days following), though in saying that it is solid enough to have run throughs without being bored. The use of NPCs which are a major hit, different variaties of producing the game including motion capture studio, etc. and the building effect make this game a solid outing thus far, more in-depth than GDT personally, and with a suggestion thread that the developer usually follows apart from his own wishlist (though the thread will stop recieving suggestions on April 30th), the game will improve along the way and become better.Currently, a rating is not needed but I recommend buying it at your own risk. For the average player that plays this, you can easily get 15 hours out of the game minimum, and I haven't done that yet because I had only bought it a week ago, though I have only had playthroughs mainly on easy, and will go to the next difficulty soon. If you are still hesitant following my review, if you do like these types of game, wait until it goes on sale because if it does on the summer sale, it will most likely be 50% off and will be $7.50, though sale or no sale, I think it is a must buy for the management fan.----Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviewsIf you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page. If you liked it, give it a rating.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												I'm a sucker for games like this, business management sims.  This is hands down the deepest of the bunch.  I have played Game Dev Tycoon, and while that game is fun, it's very simple.  Also, my biggest pet peeve with GDT was that, absent mods, the popularity of the systems was easy to anticipate.  The nintendo-like console would succeed, the dreamcast-like console would fail, the same topics and genres went well together.Mad Games Tycoon fixes this problem by giving you an option for randomizing the popularity different platforms and topic/genre combinations.  This means that every play through can be completely unique.  I love the engine optimization, and that you can sell your engine and actually make money off it.  I love the fact that I get to choose the layout of my office, hire as many people I want, the game is great.To give an example of depth, when you get big enough, you can start producing your own games.  This isn't as simple as choosing self-produce.  You have to have a production room and buy production machines to make the games.  Then you have to have a storage room to store the copies.  Then you have to choose how many copies of the game you are going to produce.  You don't want to produce too many, cause then you'll have huge stacks of the game sitting on shelves, but if you don't produce enough, you won't be able to meet demand and you'll be losing money.  You have to watch the sales of the game and watch the amount of copies of the game you have on hand, so if supply starts running low, you have to produce more. This is just one example of the complexity and depth of this game.  I love it.  It's my new addiction.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								To begin I would like to say that this game is in alpha so take everything with a grain of salt as it may change in the future. I like were they are going with this game. Game Dev Tycoon had small problems such as a limited staff to start off with. Also once you make one type of game you cannot make a game of the same type or it would bomb. I feel like that does not represent real life game development at all. Mad Games Tycoon changes that. It keeps the similar layout that Game Dev Tycoon had and allowed for you to do what you want as many times as you want. Like to make mid evil rpgs make as many as you want. With that being said there are some problems with the game(Its in alpha to be expected).First MMOs do not make since. You can make your game have a subscription fee yet not have but a small fraction of the game sells have the subscription. Also with the production costs and server costs they make very little to no money. Also right now it really doesn't have any type of penalty for making a game that makes no since such as some people have said in their reviews. You can make an music RPG/shooter and get game of the year. Of coarse stuff like this will more than likely implemented later down the road. Also if you get into the game some and hire a lot of people money will never be a problem. This is do to the fact that a game can get more than enough points to be game of the year if you have the staff, and make serious money from anything you develop.I will recommend the game if you have the money and don't care that it is in early development. If that is not the case pass until it releases in the coming months.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								There is no denying that this game has taken a huge amount of inspiration from Game Dev Tycoon. The game feels similar due to a similar layout, a lot of similar functions, and even the music is oddly reminiscent of Game Dev Tycoon. The thing this game does well though, is that it locates a lot of the flaws in Game Dev Tycoon and fixes them. This could easily have been called Game Dev Tycoon 2 and no one would have doubted it for a second. I personally love that this game lets you have more than one development team, more than one research team, etc. It increases the pace at which your company grows immensly and it gives you more to do while waiting for a game to finish developing. The production element is also quite interesting, as you can print your own games and determine price, rarity and more. You are also able to buy other gaming companies, and release their games as your own, where you take the majority of the profit. While it's a fun element at first, it can get quite demanding if you own a lot of companies, as they produce a lot of games! If you're like me, you'll even forget to release your own games and instead just rake in 100+ million every year releasing other companies games. Overall, the game runs extremely well for an early access game. It has a lot of cool features and expands brilliantly on top of an already terrific design by Game Dev Tycoon. It'll be interesting to see what other features they have lined up for the completed version, but so far I love this game!

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												A great tycoon game with a lot of content and more importantly, many ways to explore that content. It's definitely a "never the same game twice" kind of game, even when loading from a save file and playing from that point on - depending on speed and difficulty settings, combined with random events, I've had all kinds of experiences, from the company that skyrockets to become an empire in a handful of years, to a small company just barely managing to make ends meet after thirty years in the business due to some overly ambitious decisions.You can basically grow into whatever kind of company you want. Sure, you could make top of the line games that come in a box filled with extras like a t-shirt, and pamper them with updates and expansions to keep it selling for a long time. You could also just focus on cranking out a ton of solid but unremarkable games and ride sheer volume. You can nurture franchises, or even publish other companies games for them.You can even churn out buggy movie tie-ins for consoles if you so please - and can manage to make it profitable.What's more, there's plenty of starting options too - starting decade, an option to leapfrog to an office (rather than starting in your garage), randomization options, speed, difficulty - there's plenty to explore that will have an impact on your game.It's an excellent tycoon game and I'm glad to continue developing the Sexy Puzzle Moms series of puzzle games, aimed at adults with the theme of fashion and eroticism.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												I'm glad to have played this game, making dark RPG games titled No Pants Dragons, playful Shooters called On My Back, and outlandish Simulation games called Going Outside. This game is definitely at the forefront of Simulators for game making. Not that the "topic" is flooded at the moment, but I've played them all mostly.Mad Games Tycoon gives lots of options and locations for building your company, not just office or studio, but eventually a game making conglomerate. It's lots of fun getting there too, buying or making game engines to power your games, hiring and firing employees and making them do thankless menial work like customer support, it gives you a good sense of being a di- i mean boss. The games gets continuous updates since its release and continues to improve, and I hope it does because even though I've thouroughly enjoyed it it's falling a tad bit into a gameplay pitfall. It uses the same slider method of "making games" as other simulators. My problem with this is this is not a good method in my opinion, because it's easily solved by opening a guide and just notching as you see to get appropriate scores. Pretty much all aspects of getting a good score for a game can be solved by opening a guide. At that point all the fun goes out the window. Game making suddenly becomes less about making funny/cool games and more about copy-pasting a recipe for a profitable game. I know you're saying, "Oh, then don't look at a guide if you don't want to be EA!". Well, failing over, and over, and over, and over, and over again, to eventually get to the point where you're basically writing a guide that's already been written, is not fun either. At least not to me.Besides that aspect of Mad Games Tycoon, the fact that the bathrooms are the hardest rooms use space in efficiently, and the like it or hate it graphics they got going on, I sure can recommend it, because I had a blast playing it! If you loved Game Dev Tycoon, Game Dev Tycoon, and the like, you're prolly gonna love this! I'm sure they'll keep improving and I'm looking forward to seeing it in full!

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												I loved Game Dev Tycoon. If you're thinking about buying this game, there's a chance you do as well. But after having put some real time into Mad Games tycoon, I can say quite frankly that I'm probably never playing it again. It's not meant to be a diss toward them -- it's a great game, through and through -- but MGT is better in almost every sense of the phrase.MGT is a tycoon game wherein you build a game studio, release games (no, you don't actually make them/ can't play them), and eventually work your way up to producing consoles, MMOs, and more. If you've played GDT, MGT probably sounds pretty familiar. But in this game, you're actually doing floor layouts for your buildings. Your options when hiring workers are better. The gameplay feels smoother and more polished. You can self-produce your games and go into publishing the works of others. There's even an admittedly-dodgy stock market system where you can buy out your competition. All told, MGT is a lot like GDT... only there's more of everything, and everything feels better-refined.Well, almost everything.MGT does come up short in a few aspects, most notably with its failure to include a Steam-like distribution service that would cut out physical media production altogether. When was the last time you bought a game in a brick-and-mortar store, with a disc and everything? 2005? Yeah... this game needs to offer players the ability to publish on/ create a service similar to Steam. GDT has something sort of like this, so why doesn't MGT?Another problem, one that befalls most tycoon games in general, is an utter lack of creative throughput. When designing a game, you can basically that game a name, a broad genre, and a couple of basic topics... and that's it. Where are the sliders for making stories more intricate? Where's the mad-libs-style topic input where I'm defining protagonists, antogonists, and setting? Where do I design the game to feature open-world? Offering these sorts of customization options can make a game considerably more fun and addictive, even if your choices don't have real consequences. Rock God Tycoon lets you write music. The Movies allowed you to make films and watch your creations (why the crap isn't that game being remade?!?!). I want more options when making games, even if I can't play them!All told, Mad Games Tycoon is a very fun, addictive game. It has its drawbacks, but every game does. If you're into tycoon games, this is one I very strongly recommend picking up.
