content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has pretty much perfected its genre. It has a depth that no other game development sims have. The skill floor is just low enough to be able to jump in with just a little help from the tutorial, while the skill ceiling is unimaginably high. There are many ways to increase the efficiency of game production, from assigning staff to certain departments, making sure you're fitting the current trend, and even having a reasonable office layout. The different kind of company you can be also beats out any of the game's competition. You don't even have to rely solely on games. You can produce state-of-the-art engines and license them, you can be a games publisher, and you can even be a console producer and just make a first party game every once in a while.All in all, this game is thoroughly enjoyable and a definite must have for any fan of game dev sims. 9/10 in its current state.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great cheap game! The idea is to build a successful video game development empire. 1. The beginning is a little tough. Game development is expensive, and you rarely make a profit. I recommend concentrating resources on research and development of an engine in the beginning, at least then you can make some money off others. 2. The tutorial is rather brief, and just brushes the surface of things. Basically, how to build a room, hire staff, and develop a game. A lot of the finer aspects need to be figured out after, but it's not that difficult.3. The sounds I find slightly annoying, so I just mute it.4. If you plan for expansion you should do well. It's tricky to get that first profitable game, but once you do it seems like things start getting a little easier.Ultimately for $8 there is plenty of play here.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2016
												As a fan of sim & tycoon games, I'm very glad I supported this Early Access game.  It provides a great mix of simulating some small details as well as the big picture of the game development industry. It ranges from picking physical game package contents to buying out other game developers and publishing their games. I find that type of end-game stuff to be more satisfying than comparable games. They've also added specific development departments/studios like for testing (gameplay) and audio, which for a price help boost certain aspects of the games being developed.The game difficulties are true to their names, and I appreciate that genre-specific tips earned with dev time don't just give away precise levels for what it takes to make the best games. The trial-and-error nature exists, but the Game Reports help indicate when certain things like casual vs core gamer balance are just right, and trending topic & genre can help. Even if you get all the sliders right, its still really tough to get 100% on a game - As I've only done it once - On Easy.  More elaborate MMO and F2P mechanics have to be handled different than retail games.  The devs addressed all the bug reports I've provided during Early Access, and I like the choice community-fed ideas that have been put into the game.

I've spend my fair share of time playing Game Dev Tycoon, reached an endgame multiple times, and had fun almost every time, although as usually in tycoons grew tired and gave it up due to lack of challenges after 35 years of carrer as games tycoon, and limited possibilities to make games.Here, in Mad Games Tycoon i have way more of influencing every aspect of the game. number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								-Early Access Review-Well, where to begin with Mad Games Tycoon? Would I recommend it in its current state? Yes. Yes I would.I bought this game today, I played it non-stop and have now ran out of content after building my one man in his garage into an enormous empire with around $2270m. More content will be added in the future as a few rooms are locked and I assume more techonology advancements and the likes will be added, so fun fun!Pros:+Its addicting, seriously.+The customisation for the rooms is interesting.+Plenty of choice and competition.+There is already a fairly large amount of content, even for an EA.+The graphics are nice and fit in well with the theme.+The choices when making a game are pretty cool and varied.+The different stats on your workers allow for some tactical placement early game.+Updates appear to come quickly and in response to community demand, which is nice for an EA! (Cough, Starforge, Cough)Cons:-The music. God damn. I had to mute it after about 20 minutes as I felt an urge creeping upon me to douse my computer in petrol.-Placement of items is still a little so-so, I've bugged it a few times and had desks stuck in walls and objects placed over the tops of each other. (Just another minor issue with EA)-The MMORPG's subscribers drop off in drones randomly you are also unable to make expansions at the moment, if I'm wrong correct me. ( I just didn't see a way)-Once you have money, it is beyond easy regardless of difficulty.-Needs more level 3 publishers to allow for greater yeild on your prefered games. (Current set-up makes RPG's less than profitable)Interesting bits!* The random speech is quite fun actually, with strange little references to other games.* Some of the current bugs can be funny and are not particually game-breaking. (one of my workers was typing on a plant and cupboard)*The names - Seriously - They are great little knock offs. I love it!To sum up, even in its current state it is well worth the purchase and the time. The developers are community-centric and update often with bug fixes and content. There is much more to come so pay up, support the developers and reap those rewards!Current rating: 7/10 ~Liquifiction

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've never been a fan of early access. Also, I have never written a worthwhile review before. This game changed my mind on both of those. ***How I feel about Early Access and these developers***My problem with early access, I've seen to many games cost $20+ for a game that is anywhere from 10-40% complete, and that just doesn't seem fair to the consumer. I have also heard when games have been sold cheap for Early Access but then has to be repurchased upon realease. Both of these are reasons that kept me away from Early Access. This team of developers has changed my mind on this. Eggcode has made me happy to finally be a pleased supporter of an Early Access game. They release a sizeable update approximately every week. It shows that they care about their project even though they could take the money and run right now. Also, when I bought this it was clear and upfront that the game was considered 15% whole. This was a great change than what I've seen. With each update it shows that they are listening to the customers and are on top of things like the small details such as March 24th when to numbers would display switched with each other. This didn't need to get tackled so rapidly, but they chose to be on top of even the small details.***The Game***This may or may not be the most accurate depiction of the game based upon when you read it because updates are happening approximately weekly. The game had a good bell curve of difficulty. I felt like I was trying to climb and try every angle at the beginning with little success but enough to stay afloat. As you succeed at creating games or doing contract work you can afford to keep employees. They are not extremely dynamic yet, but after about 2 employees they start requiring items such as a couch for "sitting," vending machines, (humorously) toilets, arcade games, etc. These employees have monthly salaries which make you have to continue working. The employees cost more as they level up later in the game. You can train your avatar as well as your employees which lead to better games and faster contract work, but cost more as the get better. Your employees have multiple facets: making games, contract work to make some quick money, marketing to sell more games, customer service to keep your fan base happy, and research. The games seem to change with time. At the beginning you can make a game that sells "enough" to keep you going, but as the game progresses your one man or woman indie game team won't keep you alive. Later in the game it does take a team to make good games happen fast enough to sell on whatever the current market is. There is more to say about this game. I spent 20+ hours making 10+ billion dollars and called it quits at that point with a team of 25 fully trained game developers, 8 customer service pros, and 8 marketing pros. I look forward to "replaying" this game as the updates progress, and hopefully I can update this review as time progresses.?/10 the game isn't finished so this wouldn't be valid. It's an enjoyable game that goes at your pace. Late late game is a breeze, but other than that I have no complaints and this game is currently the best Game Tycoon game out there.Thanks Eggcode for changing my mind about Early Access Games!

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mad Games Tycoon is a lightweight management game focused on the games industry.Lightweight in the context that the player is not flooded with analysis sheets left and right or financial reports but instead cuts through to the point - center attention on management and keeping the corner of the eye on the company liquid balance. Effective and fun._____________________________________________[ early access review @ 20 August 2015 ]The topic chosen is quite appealing and I must comment on the alter-names and logos of all the companies I know by heart given I went through them all during my PC gamer life and those that really made history like Microprose, Ocean and Activision just to say a trio.The graphic department is competent. It does what it is intended - gives movement, colour and life to a "time sheet". There are some issues with colours but nothing that takes away value. My guess is some further work on it.The sounds are there. Mechanic types and directed mainly to the alerts and to signal the progression of the tasks being performed. Would enjoy some variation and explicity especially on the events like the games conventions and marketing campains.Mad Games Tycoon mechanics are good and open way to great diversity. We have all the technical departments in place, at least the major ones and the liberty to self manage a dynamic shift of responsabilities on the different offices is notable when compared to other tycoons where there are limits. For example I can build mini offices with all the necessary departments and develop several projects at the same time. Other tycoons fail at this. A plus on this mechanic.The Marketing and Customer department mechanics need more depth, after all they ARE one of the most important aspects of the gaming culture :) Also it would be top work if we get the reports for the campaigns.The Games Engines part is weak at best. While games can be buggy the engines are flawless. I bet this part will change for the best so we can develop a subsidiary dedicated to engines with their own issues, so better branching par with the Production mechanics are needed.In the optimization side, the game can demand a bit from the shared graphics laptops. With a dedicated graphics everything goes very smooth. This being said and from a propective buyer point of view one would expect a average specs laptop with an SSD to run it okay especially with all blows and whistles turned off. It is early access and this can change as well.To close it, this will be a entertaining game. Very fun at this stage already even with all the raw mechanics.If attention is given to the core rules of the game in the upcoming development cycle we might have a lot more to review.A great Indie project.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me start by saying I am a mad tycoon fan!(failed pun, right?)Not going to say the game is great, it isn't. But it will be. It's not another of the "had potential" games. This game HAS potential, and its developers know how to get there.Despite having some really bad grammar issues, which are being solved, there are frequent updates, and they're reasonably active around the forums, which is a big plus for any game, especially an Early Access game.I don't like mentioning other games during reviews, but you can't help but sort of compare it to the likes of Game Dev Tycoon, which is far simpler, and probably easier on the eyes, since Mad Games Tycoon has the ability to build rooms, furnish them and even decorate a bit (wish you could turn the fan movement off, though). Since you can build rooms, it's easy to imagine that you can build them to any size you want, while having a big variety of office sizes to choose from, as well as a big variety of rooms to build, from Development Rooms to Research, Marketing, Server Rooms, and even a couple more that are still not active.Not a fan of branding a tycoon game by its graphics, soundtrack or even story (since there's hardly any), since the gameplay is pretty much the important part of any tycoon game, and oh boy, does this one have it.I do recommend this game, not only for what it is right now, but for its actual potential, its active development team and its active community.

content:
Posted: January 2
 You must be Mad.... Over the last few years, there has been somewhat of a resurgance of the tycoon genre, and this is a further product of that. The 'game development tycoon' genre popularity started a while back with games such as Kairosoft's Gave Dev Story, and since then different studios and developers have improved and refined the formula. Out of all the various options out there, I feel like this game has the potential to stand out in the crowd. It allows the player much more freedom that we have come to expect from this style of game. You start off in your humble office and rather than the predictable start of just grinding out the games from the get go, there is a bit of extra work to do, and that is where this game plays its ace. The design element of this product is very good, you place down the walls, door and features of a room and then start to utilise the area to it's full potential. This game reminded me after a few minutes of the Bullfrog classic, Theme Hospital, and that is high praise. There is still a little 'polish' that could be done, mainly with some of the mechanics and the game interface, however, for an Early Access game, you'd be mad not to give it a go...

content:
Posted: January 22
The ideaWhat a brilliant concept to offer gamers a simulation of the gaming industry, making sure that every player has a positive emotional connection to the virtual goods he deals with - games are fun! I know this one is not the first to use the idea, but it is an advantage nevertheless in comparison with other simulations that take you into a cookshop or a truck cabin. At least for me, it worked very well. The gameVisuals and music do not show that this is an indie production at all - it is all well done, in the bright and cheerful spirit of Sims 3. You can even play dollhouse by choosing and positioning furniture until everything is perfect, but this is optional. Just like for many other things like repeated tasks, you can choose automation and grouping functions for that and avoid tedious micromanagement if you don't care for that. Like all tycoon games, this one gets repetitive anyway after a while because you just amass more and more money by doing similar things. However, this one is superior to others because of the historically accurate technological progress from 1980-2018 that gradually unlocks more and more features and increases complexity, until you can really feel the effort of years of development and cooperation of four or five different departments until a big AAA title can be released to the market - and receive its ratings.  My journeyGetting a perfect review, making a 100 % perfect game that gives my customers a good time, that was the lifetime dream I started with when I built my first little office next door to my garage. I studied new inventions, I struggled with my bank loans, I hired more and more staff (gamers and nerds like me whom I could very well have befriended in a real-life situation like that) - and together we grew bigger and more respected in the industry, until one day, I finally achieved my first 100 % score. It felt amazing! After that, game development lost a lot of its appeal, but I could choose a completely different path: I made money, as much as I could, by doing contract work for other companies and creating MMOs - my biggest title was online 20 years and earned me 12 billion dollars! And with those riches, I bought out all my competitors and made them produce games for my very own gaming console, making it market leader eventually - while I sat back, drank my coffee and watched the cash flow in.This was my journey in this game, and even though it lasted only 20 hours, I found this virtual life experience to be very memorable.VerdictThe game is still in development (updated regularly), and it still has some little flaws. But in the end, they did not bother me that much. I am very satisfied and give Mad Games Tycoon a 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mad Games Tycoon starts off just like GDS and GDT, you start off in a garage and it's a struggle to release a good first game, however once you have had your first good title, the game seems to get too easy, you just get better and very rarely fail, which is a shame as it would add to the realism if you made bad games as well as good ones.Mad Games Tycoon has all the features you love from GDS and GDT, but expands up on them, not only do you make games, you also build the studio and you can become an exclusively Production compay only company, which is a really good feature, you build a Production facility and a Store House and then you can make money from selling other companies games and with this you can fail if you don't pick the right game to publish.There is a feature that allows you to buy rights to Movies and Books and then produce a game from that book or movie, they have their popularity and also have their funny parodies of other Movies and Books, which some of them are quite funny and relevant to todays Books and Movies.The work spaces you get to buy and occupy are pretty big and fairly cheap as well, the only problem is when you get to the final Office, it becomes a little laggy, this is especially noticable in the Hire menu, but this is the only lag that I have spotted so far.The menus are easy to navigate and simple to use, though they do look like they have been pulled from a mobile game, the scrolling is a little slow though, but this is by no means an issue.After roughly 6 hours of playing I seem to have done everyhting in the game, it progresses a lot faster than GDT and GDS, which I hope is by design for future features.You can buy out your competitors which allow you to publish their games if you want or you can let them continue as they are, though they don't seem to make you money unless you publish for them.Pros:Easy to learnA lot to do while waitingA nice building mechanicCompetitors that actually have a presenceCons:Too easyThe progression is a little too fastGets a little laggy once you hit the last officeMenus feel like they are from a mobile gameOverall I find Mad Games Tycoon a very enjoyable game, I will be looking forward to what the devs have planned in the future.

content:
Posted: April 22, 2016
Early Access Review
								I love this game so much.  It is such a 'feel good' game, on top of being an amazingly balanced 'sim' game. I always find myself coming back to it and making new game companiesm, and playing it in so many different ways.  The dev keeps adding in new ways to keep the game fresh, and each time it makes it fun to start again and get rich...well, of course after tanking a few comapanies.  But seriously, it's so awesome that he listens to community feedback, so +1 there.For the most part it is a sim game where you build a game developing company.  Like all sim games, you must choose what to put your resources into, as well as hope for some good RNG on your side!  Half the time I play I make games like "The Second to Last Fantasy". or goofy pun names...and don't forget the go-to alliteration names.  The fans want a "Sports" game about "Robots" -  Robot Racketball!  They want a Puzzle game about Gangsters - Mafia Monopoly!  Of course every now and then you try to actually come up with real sounding names and making a serious company, which is a whole new way of playing.  This game is just so fullfilling, from the kid in my, all the way to the adult in me.  I always get real nostalgic when I play it.  I have played 100s of sim games in my life, they are by far one of my favorite genre of games, and I can easily say this game is in my top 5.  Definitely worth the buy.  Happy gaming all :)

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is fantastic! Even out the gate as an Early Access title, which I normally avoid, I was spurred to finally see what this game was about. I'm a pretty big fan of Game Dev Tycoon so I was interested to see what this game brought to the table.While it is a bit clunky at places, this game overall looks and feels like a finished and released title. This game pretty picks up where Game Dev Tycoon left off and goes so much deeper!Where in GDT you were forced into a pretty tight box and basically competing against yourself, here you have more freedom to do waht you want to grow your gaming empire. While it does have a learning curve, this game is fantastic.Pros:Features for days and weekly updatesMost UI sections are easy to useUpgradeable spaces for your businessCreate your console and produce your gamesTime sinkBeautiful atmospheric sounds and soundtrackCons:Staff interface is kind of clunkyLearning curve is steep to startMouse controls (for me) are very sensitiveTime sinkTraining works but seems inefective at timesSome minor spoilers below!Some things that do irk a bit more about this game are that there is no really easy way to manage the staff. You can mass fire people but there isn't a master list showing everyone's skills. You can look at one skill at a time but not all of them at once. It would be nice if the AI automated staffing wouldn't just arbitrarily place people in whatever room. I had a person with 80 office work end up in the research office.All in all even with small issues aside, a solid 9/10.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is shaping up to overtake Game Dev Tycoon. For an early access game, it is pretty much feature complete. It is much more in-depth, and has some great ideas that add to the game's realistic feel (like developing and selling engines to have a cut from the competitors profits). Unlike GDT, it includes some basic spatial management in the vein of Theme Hospital, meaning that you have to do some floor planning and deal with the furnishing issues. That isn't everyone's cup of tea, but I'm ok with this - if only you couldn't buy the best equipment available straight out from the beginning and had to unlock it instead. Production and marketing are supposed to be just as vital for your success as research and development. Speaking of which, Mad Games Tycoon is always telling what technology you are researching (rather than using the generic '3D graphics level 2') and even showing what the game you are developing is supposed to look like (not without some quirks - I have developed a FPS using the early 90s technologies, but the screenshot was more like Counter Strike).So far, all of the concepts implemented in Mad Games Tycoon look good, and the only issues are the game balance (for instance, once you have unlocked the engine development, you can switch to it and never bother with developing actual games to stay afloat), the interface that requires some easing into, and the updates that break your savegame compatibility. All of these issues are perfectly normal and excusable for an early access game. I'd like to add that during my 30-odd hours of gameplay I've not had a single crash, which is a no small feat for an EA game either.TL;DR:Pros:+More content and depth than the other games of that genre;+Frequent and meaningful updates;+Stability.Cons:-Balance issues;-Some major updates break the savegame compatibility;-User interface.Bottom line:Highly recommended for anyone who is into that genre/topic.

Early Access Review
								Like "Software Inc.", this game takes a lot of cues from "Game Dev Tycoon" in the sense that you'll be able to make games and sell them on the market, reasearch and unlock new features to add to your game engines, hire employees, and more.  Unlike "Game Dev Tycoon", you can build your own rooms (though not the building itself). Finding the right ticks on the sliders can be frustrating (setting focus on graphics, gameplay, etc.) and you'll often get bad scores until you get a feel of what each genre/topic calls for...though if you've played "Game Dev Tycoon", you'll be no stranger to this.  It's pretty stable and looks good, making it an easy recommend.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								       Excellent game! This game allows you to simulate what it's like to run a video game starting in 1980 all the way to present times and beyond. This game has a lot of depth, and is loads of fun. At times, it can seem frustrating: Just keep in mind that starting out isn't always easy. This game is a bit of a process of trial and error, until you find that perfect balance of space and resource management. There are currently 6 save game slots (Awesome! Wish there was more tho). As of right now in Alpha, they are often needing to wipe saved games to accomodate for the new features that they add and change. I thought I would be more upset with the save game wipes, but it actually wasn't bad- It wasn't until starting over that I realized all the things that I could improve upon from my previous game. This game is not hard to figure out, but has lots of depth and thus takes time to truly master. As a musician and aspiring game dev, I found this game to be enlightening in some ways. Obviously it is "big picture" stuff compared to the day to day work of a single game dev, but it is interesting to consider all of the moving parts. It is astounding to see how time, society, console popularity, choice of game engine, marketing techniques and various other aspects all affect success or failure of a game.                         Also, I wanted to avoid comparison, but I knew I couldn't. I own this and Game Dev Tycoon, both are excellent games. I feel that, at the moment, Mad Games Tycoon is a bit more complex and advanced. Both are truly awesome games in my opinion though.

Posted: September 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								Yes, yes...  all you're games are belong to me.If you've ever dreamed of building a super cool game company, and wanted to watch your dream grow and then suddenly be snuffed by a large bank to whom you owe millions of dollars, and who you can't possibly repay because you're game sales have no staying power, because for some reason, the public doesn't appreciate your killer new RTS about a super cool donkey civilization trying to save the world from the evil rabbit robots, well... you've come to the right place.It seems my goal is to create as large as company as possible, so I can layoff 30 or 40 employees instead of just 3 or 4 of my closest friends working out of my garage, when the walls finally cave in.  Build rooms, put people in them, make them create games, research techs through the years, train these people so they stay on the leading edge, develop new techs like quality assurance, graphics labs and sound studios.... and build and use them.  Get some marketing types and stick them in a room to sell your games, some phone workers to make you look professional, and eventually some big printers to mint your own games...  that's about the way it goes.As tycoon games go, it is actually very cool.  The only thing about it I don't like much, but is probably unavoidable, is that when you move your company to a new building you have to completely redesign the entire interior.... but no big deal.The developer is fast.  New content comes out all the time, and the updates and bug fixes are rapid fire as well.  There are a few bugs still, but nothing that really affects your game play.  Just annoying, little things.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
Game Dev Tycoon meets The Sims!Mad Games Tycoon does not only allow the player to create a Software Company, the player also needs to care for its employees’ needs in order to hire and motivate them to work (pay and perks). Do you want that RPG specialist who is also great at the graphics that your own engine supports? Then you will have to buy a certain “furniture” or an “arcade game” first before he or she even considers to accept your job offer! A Fantastic Idea!The game also runs really well for an Early Access application. I’ve not encountered a single bug, yet. Sure, there are some features that are not in game but that comes with the territory. The devs also really take into account its customers’ ideas into incorporating them into the game’s updates.However, one major flaw that I’ve come across thus far is that Save Games from prior game versions do not load properly whenever the game updates. The player loses hours of gameplay and progress that way. Nonetheless, it’s really not a consequence because starting over keeps the game fresh while offering new contents and its own challenges.A few things I have on my Wishlist are the following: Be able to quickly sort through applicants by certain genre or feature specialties when hiring new employees Be able to have an idea of projected sales from Marketing to help with self-production Random events in gaming industry that cause competition to fail and rise (i.e. random R&D breakthroughs that become players own license, market recessions, bankruptcy, or even new competitions such Indie Devs) More end game features such as Digital Download Services, Market Investments, Building our own consoles or platforms, to name a few 8 / 10 – Great Early Access game! Greatly recommended and worth checking out!

												I really like this game. It`s a great addition to the Tycoon family of games. It is a nice game visually. I like the evolution aspect. You start out small and grow your buisness into larger and larger facilities. The R&D aspect is very nicely done and easy to understand. Pros   + Good looking game       + Research is well done       + Lots of new buildings to grow into       + Lots of game topic       + I belive you getting value for the current price point ($16.99)Cons   - later in the game it can be handful managing a large staff       - game consoles do not reflect the proper percentage of the markrt share. I'm selling thousands                     of them and creating games for the console, But the market share shows less than 1%, but i'm         making large sums of cash.I also have seggestions to maybe help expand the game play. Make a legal department in the game. It would be interesting to have them deal with issues like, copy right infringement, piracy, colaboration with other rival companies to create games, consumers sueing your company for damage clames because of a game. There are many other scenarioes that could be created. This would reflect the real world issues faced by game developement companies.In closing this is a fun game with hours of interesting content. It is very similar to Game Dev and a great addition. I recommend this to anyone.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even in its current unfinished state, Mad Games Tycoon is a great game! Initially I thought it looked like a Zynga-esque rip-off of Games Dev Tycoon, but I took a gamble on it during a sale and to be honest I find MGT is the better game! There are very many similarities between MGT and GDT but Mad Games feels like the less mobile-version game of the two. It has a watered down, but still enjoyable, Sims-ish building/management component that GDT does not. But the best element about the game in my opinion is the actual game making itself. I found it infinitely more enjoyable and transparent than GDT, where the quality of your games feels like a crap shoot and you are not penalized so harshly for being imaginative and drifting from obvious genres. Instead of the Tech/Design ratio thing GDT has, MGT has a numerical graphics/sound/controls/technology pool which is influenced by the visible stats of your staff, making way easier to understand where you game succeeded/failed. Similarly, any feature extras like 'sprites', 'vibration controller support' etc contribute directly to the game in transparent ways that make sense, such as 'sprites' contributing to the graphics quality of the game, 'vibration' improving the controls, etc. Also, every update the dev releases (which is about 1 a month or less) has been excellent and not just bug bashes, and he seems very responsive to feature requests on the Steam forums. He has also been very cooperative about making the games files available for modding, allowing us to rename companies and products to their real-life counterparts.So if you like GDT, I recommend this! I find it like a less mobile, more in-depth and (most importantly) more transparent version of GDT, and even then it is still an early access with features being added to it!

Early Access Review
								So i have played quite a bit of Game Dev Tycoon and another lookalike of it (Cant remember the name of it though) but i must say that both are easily outclassed by this very enjoyable game. It takes most of the elements from Game Dev Tycoon and adds some new ones, the biggest new feature would probably be the Theme Hospital/Sims based building customization where you decide how large your various offices should be, which objects should be inside etc. The game is currently in Early Access though i'm not sure if its in a late Alpha state or in Beta. However the game functions fine though i'm getting a bit of a framedrop as i get into the later parts of the game. There are also some features which are currently locked because of the game being in Early Access. However aside from that the game performed really well which really surpassed my expectations because of it being in Early Access. The developer is currently updating around every week or close to that at least. The only real negative thing i can say apart from the framedrop is that each update makes you unable to load your old games but you can easily make a playthrough of it in that period so that's only really an issue if you want to play it a short amount of time each day. So yeah i would recommend buying this game if you were into Game Dev Tycoon or similar Game Developer simulators

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Yes, it obviously is very much based on that other game dev tycoon game. The title is a bit underwhelming, and I expected a pretty bad rip-off. At first, I thought I was right, as the starting situation, with your company in your basement and a car next door reminded me quite a bit of a certain other game. However, soon you realize that this game has more features. You can design your office, controlling the size of each room and what is being worked on in that room. You assign dev- or research projects to a room, and the more people work in it, and the more advanced they are, the faster the result is done. You can even start to produce the games yourself, which requires a manufacturing room with CD presses and a storage room (make sure you get both, they dont need employees in them, but before you have both, production won't start, and you wanna have the game available as soon as it was developed).Moving to a bigger space requires a bit more work... you sell old office stuff, move into the new space... and it's all empty. So you have to build those walls, decorate and furnish the rooms and assign your workers, which of course still get paid while you build, so it helps to go room by room so you can assign people quickly. In general, the game has more detail than that other game (Which I enjoyed a lot as well, btw!!), has more options and features which DO make sense, and seems to be shaping up quite nicely. My first play-session lasted for 3 hrs straight with no break, and I am looking forward to continuing. Not sure how much replay-value the game has once you have become the big and rich tycoon, but until then, its a very enjoyable and slightly addictive game.

Early Access Review
								For a Game in Alpha to be this good is astounding. The controls are a bit iffy and has a little learning curve but once you get the hang of that things get fun. Now you need to be prepared, this game is not at all like Game Dev Tycoon. Game Dev Tycoon focuses more on developing games to make money. Mad Games tycoon focuses on expanding and creating not just video games, but game engines as well as the layout and size of your building. There are a little things that can be frusterating when you make your first few games but once you get into the swing of things it's easy. In this respect the game is alot more immersive than GDT because you honestly never know what the finished product will be like. This game is great and even though there are a few buggy things (Which is to be expected when a game is in alpha) the dev team is working hard to fix it. 9/10 for the experience alone.

								While this is early access in my opinion it is a solid game as it stands with a decent amount of features and depth already, i like you can select which country to base your company in and choose what your character can specialise in. content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								A great simulation game.This early access game is already the most comprehensive, funny and polished game in this niche category (Videogames Development Business Simulations).And the fact that it's still in early access means that the Devs are still introducing a lot of new features and requests from the players.________________________________Pro:- Tremendously comprehensive list of features. You can do practically everything that comes to your mind, from developing your games or game engines, modifying, updating, selling or reselling them in budget editions or bundles, to making your own production factory,  hiring and training your employees, acquiring subsidiaries and make them do the main work while you sell services.- Projecting, expanding and decorating your headquarters is very funny, it remembers me of the old Hospital Tycoon.- Games reviews are really articulated and they point out the  strengths and weaknesses of your games.Cons:- Videogames Consoles market shares are a little unbalanced and too predictable at the moment, but they're working on this.- For a better immersion in that time, It lacks some form of media news/events not related to the videogames industry.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mad games TycoonA building simulation with a little bit of skill building sims. Like the game Theme Hospital but with computers instead and the ability to upgrade your working conditions such as garage or office building.You raise the stats of your people and produce a mass of games in hope of being the best and keeping your business afloat. Story along the lines of Game Dev Tycoon. All features of Game Dev Tycoon are in there including Making your own system, doing side work, and  creating mass games that blow peoples minds. Upgraded graphics and more open ended gameplay make this a pretty good game. I like that I have a choice in what my people are going to doand where. You can even pick employees with special skills and traits that you want. I personally enjoy giving my employees what they need and even messing with them when they do bad by taking away things like the bathroom. I love the new explination system as it gives you more in depth information on things and offers beginners a better understanding of what you are doing. I can't really say much about how to get a perfect game but there are online  tutorials and such out there that you can look up. You can  make the game easy or hard and cater to your desires of running a business bankrupt or making it a success. I miss some of the cutesy graphics but I guess that the new ones are just as good. I got frustrated at the move object function until I learned how to turn it off as I kept selecting items I did not want and in a time sensitive game it is not good for you to waste any precious seconds when in threat of bankruptcy. Also, when you delete a room you get nothing for it. So if you spent 200000 on it and remove itbecause it was too small, you lose 200,000. There is no way to enlarge or shrink a room.  So, in my opinion it is just as good as their previous game but polished a bit for those seeking better emersion and more stuff. I find myself stuck on it for hours when I play it and oftenlose track of time as I micro manage my little simmies into an early grave.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Alright update 14.06.2016, the game has been updated pretty regularly and there have been SO MANY things added and I've restarted this game SO MANY times. I don't think I'll ever get bored of restarting the game. I've not yet finished it on the hardest difficulty, but it seems fair if you have played on normal or hard before and have been successful. Now, I HAVE TO give this game a thumbs up and a recommendation and a good score and whatever else it wants. I'm tempted to just buy a few more copies and share them with my friends just because the developer is that much awesome. -------------------------------------------------------------------------All my initial problems are fixed. The game also now has enough content to warrant a buy. I say, go ahead, get it. I also want to add that whenever I suggest something, it gets enough attention so that it is either fixed or implemented as a feature or option. The developer(s) of this game is amazing and the community is also working. I couldn't be happier with my purchase.Go to the bottom for TL;DR version.This game has a lot of Theme Hospital inspirations. Like how your staff needs radiators to be productive or how certain staff members can only be hired when you have certain items. The game's atmosphere is nice on its own and it has a lot of topics and genres and features for your development journey.Now, let's talk about the downsides of this early access. First of all, there isn't much of a tutorial on how things work, the only tutorial you're given is at the start and it's pretty simplistic. After that you have to unlock certain stuff by doing other stuff. Researching a feature to be able to make your own engine for example. However, the buildings that you unlock have no tooltips whatsoever and you can only go for a trial and error approach. They do have tooltip boxes though so they're sure to be explained later on in an update. There are also some minor grammatical errors or typos but nothing too bothersome.Now, if you have bought the game and you're just starting out, don't invest in the last 3 skills. They are only ever useful for research, marketing and support. Get skills other than music, sound and graphics since those are the first few employees available to you and you can just get one if you need.TL;DR version: This game is like Theme Hospital meets Game Dev Tycoon. It is in Early Access but it doesn't have any bugs that I can see. Only issues are, late game lag (can be solved by lowering graphics etc.) and npcs getting stuck (can be noticed easily) and some minor typos. The game deserves its current price tag. As an Early Access game it gets a 9 out of 10.-----------------------------------------------------------Warning, this review is out of date. The problems mentioned here may or may not be present in the current version.Edit: Performance issues with having too many employees seems to be fixed or at least alleviated. Teleporting employees now only teleport to the door if they can't find a path to their desk or where they want to go, which is a good thing. Late game seems like a bother because of the training room and how employees get so little experience from actually designing games.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Early Access ReviewUpdate 27/01/2016 - Original Review below this update. This game has been continually updated since my original review and there are some changes I would like to share (there are many more but these are some of the main ones I find)- Lots of bug fixes- Added missing rooms such as Motion Capture & Recording- More info around Staff- Can now develope and sell your own consoles meaning even more ways to make $$$Still some things to sort out- End game is still a bit too easy as making successful games is still a bit formulatic but has improved since original review. Updated ConclusionA fun game that has gotten better and better.  If you like tycoon games this is one I would recommend and is a load of fun even though it is still EA it is feature rich and stable. Original EA ReviewQuite a fun game, in similar vein to Games Tycoon but more expansive.  Essentially you start as a games developer in your garage and work your way up to mega corp.  You need to hire staff, match their skills to the various assignments and train them up. You can build a large variety of rooms and need to decorate them to improve productivity (must like theme hospital).  Getting larger offices means you can build larger rooms and dedicated more staff to the room etc. Also you need not focus only on game dev, you can also go the publishing route, publishing other developers games which is neat.  One thing I also like is once you have released a game and if you have publishing facilities you can re-release them later at a discount and also make bundles, thus increasing your profits for that game in the long run.  Still a few issues to sort out, a few bugs and also to address (which I believe has been) the fact once you reach mid-point the game gets easier and getting good score games is a bit too easy (again this is being fixed).  Overall a highly addictive game thus far. I will update this review when the game is released but right now it is in a very good state for Early Access.

Posted: April 12, 2016
												I gotta say, having played most(?) of the Video Game Industry Tycoon games, this one is my favourite.+ It allow customisation of your office with a wide amount of objects to place down.+ The Dev team have been on this game for a year and in that year added features that are to me pretty big and wanted as it gives out more options to choose in your adveture to our current year.  e.g Languages, Buying other companies, Game updates, Icons(you can add your own), Servers for MMO Games, a Mad  Games Convention(E3), Game Size, Rooms to make an aspect of your game better, Platforms, Buildings, Consoles  Development and a literally tons of Hot Fixes which makes the performence, the UI and general gameplay much faster,  easier and fairer.I would add more but I don't know what else to add as I put most of it in the second Pro.It runs well on my AMD A4 6210, 5 GB Ram, AMD Radeon R3 Graphics Card Laptop.So far i think the dev gives out an average of 3-5 updates/hotfixes a month.It does get annoying that occasionally when the game updates, you can't load in old saves due to a new features or a change but I don't really care.And that was my first somewhat long review.I definitely would recommend this to any tycoon lovers.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												Mad Games Tycoon suffers from a major lack of feedback.  Unfortunately in the beginning there isn't much of an indication of what you're doing wrong.  Worst yet, when your game does somehow succeed, there's no real indication of why it did well either. Let's start off with what this game did right.The progression of building your business is really there.  For example: Upon your third year you can make a marketing department or when you have enough fans you'll need Customer support to continue to make them happy.  Once you have enough money you can expand to a larger building site and create break rooms and larger toilet facilities for your staff. Developing your own game engine.  This really helps out on the profits.  This also gives you a good feeling of what technology is out there and what other engines you are competing against. Researching is extremely important.  It isn't just about developing games and engines, it is also about researching what topics and genre's and components are out there as well.  If you don't keep your research up, you will certainly fail!Different staff are available at all times.  There are even such "legendary" workers that you can hire such as Sid Maier (misspelled on purpose)Now for the reasons for not recommending this game:There really isn't much feedback at all to why your game did well or badly.  I've made so many consecutive worst game of the year's that I simply feel extremely frustrated rather than having fun.   You would think that the higher the numbers the better right?? Nope.  What about the stars next to the numbers??  Nope.  I still don't understand why one game fails and another succeeds!!The game does an extremely poor job of explaining all of the features once you do become a bit more successful.  I suppose it's a bit self explanatory, but if you're not ready to trial and error you'll never know it was there.I will state here that it's not like I didn't try to understand this game, I tried looking up what other people has done.  I've asked my buddy who purchased this game during beta.  Yes, once in a while I hit a beauty and I do well but most everything I've tried blows up in my face. I've even tried to avoid creating games until the trends lineup and then trying with the proper engine and legendary workers.. and my game STILL falls flat on it's face.... AND I DON'T KNOW WHY!!!!


YouTube™ Video: Mad Games Tycoon - Gameplay Review 

			Views: 52		

			Developed by Eggcode Progression of the business simulation is nicely handled. However the overall lack of feedback on projects entirely ruins the game as you do not know why your games do bad or...		

Mad Games Tycoon? More like driving you mad while making games tycoon.

								I just want to get this out of the way: I know it's an Early Access game, so some of my issues I have with the game will hopefully be fixed. Needs VAST improvement (GODZILLA ISSUE!)Overall, think about getting the game, but unless you're patient enough to hope for updates in the future, you may feel a slight buyer's remorse.  I know I did until I sat back and looked at the big picture.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												Let's talk about the few glaring flaws first:- Borderline atrocious UI. It's ugly and it's not super intuitive. This game is not a "looker".- The game does a poor job of explaining its mechanics.- Poor grammar at times.If you can get past those cons, I think you'll find the most complex "game development" game released yet. Mad Games Tycoon offered me more control & flexibility over how my studio was run than I expected.+ Building out your studio room by room (may be a con for some, but I enjoyed it)+ Developing your own engine & having the option to license it to other developers+ Having the option to release games through publishers or publish your own games+ Being able to publish games from other studios+ MMO's and special "add-on's" for MMO's (you even have to have a server room)+ Special facilities for graphics, audio and quality control departments+ Full control on what is focused on during development via slidersI could go on. I found the game surprisingly deep and I'm having a lot of fun. I recommend this to anyone that has enjoyed other similiar titles.

Early Access Review
								Definetly more complicated than Game Dev Tycoon, I had a harder time getting into it. The "game report" feature isn't implemented yet and the start of the game can be very hard (at least no rent to pay). It's not quite clear why a game gets bad ratings. I had good combinations with good production value and no bugs and the game still gets slammed with a 40%. Still fun, especially with the complexity of different rooms and finding out how they work. MMOs are much better implemented than in Game Dev Tycoon and you can as well print your own games in-house and ship them. But you can not make your own hardware. In 9 hours I moved through 3 different offices and ended up with an MMO and a RTS that I would actively update and advertise, ended up with 8,3 billion before I decided to end it. Definetly a recommendation for everybody who likes these kind of sims. I'm looking forward to future updates of this game, hopefully containing the still missing rooms.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Note: This is a long review so if you plan on reading read to the endSo this is a game I had picked up recently due to the interest I had had in it a while back. Playing games like this I find pretty enjoyable and  have done my fair share of Game Dev Tycoon, seeing this I immediately jumped to the conclusion that this was a rip off of that very game. And boy was I wrongSo not only is this a game that takes the functions of Game Dev Tycoon and other Game Dev Sims it improves on it greatly allowing you to go into a deeper creation of your games, although not too far away from where it's aging older brother set the benchmark. By this I mean the ability to impliment copy protection for your games allow it to be released in other languages because it isn't all about the english speaking world and above all else it expands on what Game Dev does with it's combinations.What does this mean? Well this is quite simple where Game Dev had the massive list of topics with the  5 root genres with the 6th researchable one of casual games coming into effect early on along with Multi-genre and MMO being unlocked later into the game, Mad Games Tycoon  goes balls to the wall with the progression of time since Game Dev's release these roots have branched off  to a collection of 16 genres for you to combine with one another to experiment and create the best games, and as time goes on maybe this will increase even more.The Key element of this gameplay however is the other side to it, Game Dev is you sitting at your desk making money by making good games and then having you move into a bigger space and hire more people to sit at deska and help you make money, that may be putting it bluntly and to be fair there is other stuff to do like research and so on but stripped to it's core that is game dev. Mad Games Tycoon however decides to borrow elements from the late Maxis'  collosal franchise of the sims where you have to care for these people in more depth, you give people the multitude of rooms to work in along with a bathroom and break room as well as tending to their needs so their will to work for you is great this hopefully allowing you to get more done in your games and tilt the tide to get that higher rating and more money.There is however one issue with this game that I have and that could partially be blamed on me as well. Mad Games Tycoon at the moment of me writing this review has no tutorial mode and if it does I can't find it, It does have an easy mode option which starts you off in an office space however but that really doesn't do much when it comes to learning the mechanics and the key gameplay elements. it took me a while to find out how to even build a room to work in let alone make a game and even then the sliders are easy to work around, but i wasn't too sure on how it would work. With words either side of the bar  I was unsure if moving it closer to one way meant it was a higher priority or that it meant it was a lower one because of the way Game Dev worked with the bigger bar meaning more time, and i'm honestly still not sure to this day.Don't let this bring you down as eventually when you learn how the game works you can easily get into the game even with the difficulty. all of these games are the same fundementally with the rinse and repeat and if you don't succeed try again aproach with the idea that someday you will hit it big and from then it is smooth sailing.Overall then this is a strong game even in it's early access state and is in strong standing within the Game Dev Games, although this review constantly made comparison to Game Dev  it does not mean I think of it as a worse game, I would honeslty say I believe that Mad Games Tycoon in it's current form is on par even without the tutorial and I really hope to see this game through to a full release where then it could take it's place on the throne of where Game Dev Tycoon currently resides

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
Mad Games Tycoon is a management simulation where you get to create and manage your own game development studio.Mad Games Tycoon is very in-depth when it comes to developing your own company. You can specifically place each room inside of your studio such as a development studio, quality assurance, marketing etc. You can also decorate and place objects inside your studio to satisfy your employees needs and wants, hire employees and a great many other things!The aspects of the game that i thoroughly enjoyed are:-Customisation options-Plenty of offices varying in size-Detail-Difficulty settings for every player, hardcore or casual-Loads of settings in the options menu allowing you to turn off or on specific things in the game-Fun and addictive gameplay-Controls are simple and easy to use-Regular updatesCreating your own consoleBuying out other game studiosAspects of the game I didn't particularly enjoy are:-Hype for a game is capped at a max of 100 instead of being dynamic (nitpicking)I really couldn't think of anything else i didn't like about the game.Obviously as it is in Early Access (soon leaving Early Access) some features that I'd like in the game are not there such as: creating DLC for your games or creating early access games and perhaps even player mod support for the game etc. But those are my personal opinions, still a fantastic game and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes management simulation games.I'd give it an 8/10, a very good game with little to complain about.

content:
Posted: March 10
												Very good game. Some tips. Play legendary. Build one room for each function. Keep expanding rooms as needed. Alway do production contracts with the machines. Hire people who are fast and good. For game design have one of every feature. Game gener should be second to features. Hire as many people as you want they make money not cos money. I have built a console in 20 years on legandary no problem. Always research Consoles as you go. Try to focus on 6-7 game types not all of them. In the begining hire as many people as are available. Don't try to ne a hero and figure out the slider settings. just write them down and use them, you need to move on to different games so just try to move fast. always move to a bigger building when you can. Keep departments close that you access regularly. Close to developement. Price sales at 19 and forget it. always have a fan club going to get fans. Always have as three games ready in June for the booths. Fans are a priority. I absolutly love the game. You may want to listen to something elese while playing as the music is repetive at best. There is no voice actiing. I have probably played more hours of pc games then most people on earth. If I say it's good it is.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												There are too many flaws to count in this game: the graphics are terrible, the sound is bad, the ui is very very buggy. The person/mascot/paperclip person is creepy with his pervy smile and tight black v-neck t-shirt. It's impossible to read the notifications so you have to live without them. A lot of important information is hidden deep within the menus for you to discover too late in the game. And yet, I found myself binge playing it and enjoying myself immensly.I bought this game on sale after reading a lot of its reviews. So far I made it from a single person studio in 1980 to a AAA giant in 2016 (with one failed and three super successful MMO titles that grossed hundreds of millions), but I hear you can play this well into the future. As a gamer in real life, the choices I make as a developer in the game echo reality: should I release the 6th installment of my uber successful series, where profit is certain but creativity is nonexistent, should I maybe probe the market with a cheaper title that explores a radical new genre/combination, or do I dare invest all of my effort into making a brand new concept for an MMO, knowing there are dozens of millions of development and production dollars at stake? There's a lot more of this type of openness - you can decide to be an SDK focused busienss and sell engines to other companies. You can venture into console development and production. You can develop titles for other publishers, you can publish other developers games, you can create annoying candy crush clones with a F2P model. The game's biggest strength is how it puts you in this historically accurate simulation of gaming history and lets you be part of it in whatever way you choose.Since the game offers no real guidance about how to succeed, I was left with my background of playing a lot of video games since the late 80s. So far they seem to have served me well in picking genre and topic combinations, making target age group and game balance decisions (when you make a game you need to set a series of sliders to balance things like graphics vs gameplay, functions vs atmosphere and so on). I did not read anything about how to play, because I didn't want to ruin the experience, and this led to me learning some game mechanics (like the effects of reputation and the fine balancing act of pricing and packaging) fairly late in the game, so I am curious how I would fare in a second run. I'm also curious to try to play in hard mode - would it be arbitrarily punishing or a well thought difficulty curve?UPDATE: On my second run I became a multimilionaire by 1986 and by 1990 retired from the business because it's really hard to manage such a big company. I bought out most of the other development companies and made them make games exclusively for my consoles.I sincerely recommend getting this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
Early Access Review
								I just can't stop coming back to Mad Games Tycoon. Every couple of months I find myself spending a week as flat out as I can on it. It is addictive and satisfying - exactly what a tycoon game should be!The synopsis of the game is such. You are a small scale aspiring game developer working out of your garage. You need to make it big in the gaming industry and you do so by researching technological advances in both hardware and software. You employ the people who you believe will make you the best games and then you plan the game to be developed according to the current trends.The devs have clearly struck a real good balance in so many aspects if you ask me. For example; sometimes you may think that you are onto a whopper of a game... only.... it flops - generally for understandable reasons. That is when time starts ticking and bad decision making would almost certainly spell  B.A.N.K.R.U.P.T.C.Y.  However, delving into some serious debt with the bank is an option. I mean what is the difference between going bankrupt with a debt of $200k or going bankrupt with a debt of $1.5m? (The answer is nothing - except of course for the differing amount but that is irrelevant as it has no impact upon you). What I am coming to is that the extra borrowed cash used to make a good game has been enough to bring the company back into the black and I have gone on to build a massively successful gaming company thereafter. What is my underlying message?  THE GAME IS FUN AND REWARDING!! Devs don't read the next statement.  I have gotten my money's worth many times over already IMO and yet the game is still in Early Access!!  Well worth the money for a really cool tycoon game. Can't wait for the next. 10/10 for Replayability7/10 for User Interface 10/10 for Developer Continuous Dedication

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's still a lot of work to do, but this concept has got a lot of potential to become a knock-out fun time consumerer. It already is in a sort of way, but it's still a short-term addiction.The interface is a shameless copy of Theme Hospital. Let's just be honest about that. But why not use something that has proven to be solid instead of reinventing the wheel? There's something very appealing in being in charge of a gaming company. You start from your garage, being small time and struggling to keep the annual figures in green colors. You have to work a way through developing games, hiring staff, expanding your business and getting fans.The strength of these 'tycoon' games, is that they don't demand much graphical attention. What does demand attention, is detail. I want to have to make important decisions: do I take out a loan? Do I invest funds to reignite a game? Do I have to cut the budget by firing staff? Some elements of a typical Tycoon game already show, like deciding to take part in a yearly game convention and expanding your fanbase or the endlessly staring at figures and gauges towards planning your next move.If you're a fan of tycoon- or simgames by any stretch of the imagination, you'll like this game. There's a satisfying depth in developing your own games and there are a lot of possibilities to do so. I can only recommend to the creator to add more depth. As much as possible. I mentioned Theme Hospital. Remember how you were able to turn up the heating at a certain expense? More heating means the people will feel better, but it presses on your budget. I want to be thinking about these managerial decisions. If that can be provided, this game can become a long-term addiction.Some advices for enhancing the game: add a toggle gridline, show the measurements of rooms when designing them, add the option to redesign a room without having to delete it, being able to take out a loan, easy dispatch of staff (not having to pick them up one by one), more gamespeeds (the first speed still feels a bit too fast, especially later on in the game).Keep up the good work!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
Status;"IN PROGRESS"First off... its not Game Dev Tycoon, not comparable. Played both now for hours.This game is faster paced, more in depth, and has so many more attributes to follow as if you were running your own game development studio or corporation.Get this game if you like Tycoon games, we guarentee you will enjoy this!Not easy, but very easy to learn.Replayability is great.Polished, you get to create your space for each department.Many publishers to choose from.Many genre's and market choices.Good graphics and no lag what so ever.No crashes yetThe content just keeps coming. Amazing run and devotion!Tips; (Dont bend over in a public restroom! No... seriously... don't... )Spend slow, build slow, get some cheap games out first to get your revenue going.(Its fun to grow slow and watch it come out huge! Really huge!)Dont hire anyone but your dev team to start, and make a bathroom, otherwise it can get messy! Be sure to include a water fountain, plant, fire extingusher, and top desks in every room.Buy it, you wont regret it if you played Game Dev Tycoon and enjoyed that, this game surpasses all it had and has so much more.Guarentee you will really like the work done and the hours of play! THIS GAME IS ONE OF THE BEST in the Tycoon Genre.This is a solid buy as they come but the devs wont respond to email, so good thing there is no ground breaking problems as of yet.  They make a lot of posts and updates but don't really listen or interact with the community, which is sad with a homerun like this. Your only good as your fan base guys. Keep up the good work tho!!Discalimer; The Review Crew's evaluations are based on paying close attention to forum response and activity, system demand, fun of the game genre, position of originality in respective genre, growth of the project in its current state at time of review, graphics as a whole for end user, presentation of the game and display, replayability, patch/tweak progress, beginner friendliness & gameplay direcction, content & depth, attention to detail on small things(polish), lag and multiplayer application if applicable, badge card availability, with a minimum 8 hours of gameplay and interaction with customer base after release. We are not affliliated with any specific brand or entity or on any payroll. All views are based on positive only feedback as we are in no position to criticise anyones craft, just current states of development and progress at the time of our participation. If we offend anyone with our content, it was not us! Our review was hacked!

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game reminds me of the games in my childhood. If you'd like to play games so called 'tycoon', this game is good for you. This game follows the common track of tycoon games. Money, hiring, facilities, development... so it's easy to get used to this game. Yeah, unfortunately, this feature is its weakness, too. Of course, this is early access and I know I have to endure some uncomfortable ones... but where is a tutorial? Although this is quite simple and easy to play, just a short tutorial is needed in every game. I didn't know how to set up my office so I thought it was a kind of bugs.  Moreover, the more employees you hire, the slower this is. Now I'm in the biggest office with about 40 employees but its speed is too slow for me to play this anymore. I recommend it but only for tycoon lovers and ones who are sick of complicated games. If you are not... well whatever.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								What I enjoy about this game is that its Game Dev Tycoon but bigger. Although lacking for late game content (New systems and features kind of stop arriving around 2008) Its still alot of content, and with frequent updates and this game still being in early access means that there is still a great game with huge potential. Comparing when i first got this game a few months ago and playing it now i have seen the game grow with the adding of gameplay features like new rooms and random events to adding things like achievements. My one big complaint about this game is the lack of a custom logo option (having to pick from a closed set of logos rather than getting to create my own.) Personally i would enjoy being able either to pic from a selection of shapes and colours or even being able to upload my own logo form my computer into the game would really inhance immersion, but all in all this is stil a great gameId recommend this game to anyone who has enjoyed Game Dev Tycoon or any tycoon game really, as it provides a fun game and challanging businees simulation.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								I had loads of fun with this game. It really does improve on everything on existing "Gave Development" games. The biggest downside however is near the end, and not a lack of end-game either. What I've noticed is that once you start making bank, you've made it to the bigger buildings, and then you move into production and self publishing. I had every room in the game in my building, and it was the most micro-managing I have had to do since StarCraft 2. For me, it lost a lot of it's character and enjoyment as soon as I hit this roadblock. Developing games quickly becomes just a side project alongside the many many other side projects you have, and it becomes very reptitive. All said and done, it's still a great game and it will keep you entertained for hours, and this is still alpha! There are loads of things I'm sure that will be added on, improved, and possibly flat-out removed.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Mad Games Tycoon - The First Impressions ReviewThe Cons- Currently there is no real way to gauge production, for example, your company just made a game called "Bob and the Destroyers" the game gets an average 75 to 80 rating. There is no system that lets you know how many copies you should produce. This leads to a guessing game on the overall rating, hype, and fanbase of your company to create an estimate. If Pre orders became a thing in game like maybe in 2007 or so then it would make being a publisher easier.- Currently there is no real way to assign your subsidary to create a sequel to a game, I find that most of my game sequels are 4 - 5 years apart, however sometimes my dev studios are busy trying to make a new IP and I forget about a previous one that was fairly decent in success, this leads to a ten year gap sometimes between some games. If you could assign a subsidary to create a sequel, and control the engine used as well as the platforms, this would make it easier to keep your greatest of Sagas or trilogies going while being able to focus on new projects and games, of course the level of studio quality will influence the games overall rating, so chooing wisely would be in your best intrest.NeutralYou cannot create subsidaries, conventions, or create handheld consoles.Okay this is more of me nitpicking small details, but this is something that would really be cool or interesting to do.Scenario: Your company is growing and you decide you want to make a subsidary becuase you plan to publish your own titles, creating a subsidary would be a big investment like buying them out is. You start out and have 5 options, for 3 million you can make a one star subsidary, 5m gets two star, 7m gets 3 star, 10m gets four star, and 15m will make a 5 star subsidary, the inital investment is steep, from here subsidaries could be given more directions, for example you could create a deadline for the AI controlled subsidary to come out with Two new games every year or so. This could affect not only the goodwill of the company (value) but also affect the rating of the games it creates.On game conventions, making one called AGX (Arcade Gaming Expo) which is a play on the Penny Arcade Expo or PAX that is cheaper to participate in but also yeilds less attendance and hype would be great for smaller companies, or the ability to create your own and make proceeds from the companies who attend the event, of course this would also be another investment.Right now we have the ability to create home consoles, but if this could be expanded to handheld that would be a cool feature alongside having both the Home and Mobile markets split into two seperate identies would mean your company could have their home console and mobile console on the market at one time. Positive Influences+ You can virtually create any kind of company you want to. If you wanted to you could creat a game development studio that is independent and has no set publisher and develop for PC only or you could create over time a game dev and publishing company that publishes and makes 100% of the profit, or you could go as far to challenging Katari or Mintendu by becoming a Hardware manufacturer owning subsidaries and publishing console exlusive titles making your market share rise. You could even only do contract work and make minimal money to operate but keep yourself small. The choice is yours.+ The gameplay is addicting and challenging at higher difficulties, in essence you create your own problems and have to make the correct choices to manage your companies funds and gain foothold in the market.Overall I give "Mad Games Tycoon" an 8/10 for my First Impressions Review. This title has a ton of potential to wipe the floor with other Game Dev Simulators, also I would rather state this game is more of a Game Industry Simulation.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												i don't usually bother with reviews so don't bite my head off for this. the game is pretty well made for an early access and considering how far along it has come already, my only hope is that by the time it releases, it becomes a true masterpiece. the achievements alone are hard enough for you to actually need to play for about 20-30h and the replayability factor is big enough. unlike gamedev tycoon, the game still has room to improve so that's a pro. can't really think of a con unless you hate this type of game (in which case, there's no point in you reading this).EDIT:been playing this one for a while now so I'd like to think I'm somewhat wise now. yea, the graphics are ancient, the game feels repetitive (once you're at your 25th or so run), the game looks like it was modeled after the hobbits themselves ("you can learn all there is to know about them in 2 weeks yet after a life time, they can still surprise you") but there's something that just keeps begining you back. i don't know what it is, still trying to figure that part out. don't expect great graphics, expect a level of complexity on par with the C&C franchise (pre RA3) that makes your head spin.if you're expecting pros and cons, read other comments. if you're expecting the "wisdom" of an old RTS player, here it is: in the past 10 or so years, this is just about the best strategy you'll find out there (and yes, I do mean strategy game), unless you feel like picking up a game made before 2006 (and trying to make it work). and i hope that the devs either let the community mod it or keep those content updates coming (or both).
