Early Access Review
								It's extrememly addicting.I made an engine for free that takes 50% of profits from devs.I made games such as "0/10 Crappy Shouvelware", "I'm broke lol" and "aopisdjfaopeifj"I forgot to publish other people's games 90% of the time after signing multiple contracts.I found the worst employee, who happened to be named Dean, nicknamed him "THE DEAN MACHINE" and forced the staff to worship him as he proceeded to do nothing for at least half of the playtime experience.I installed 20 heaters next to the publishing machines in one room so the employees would stop complaining. They did.I devoted an entire room to nothing but cabinets becuase the employees wanted them.I noticed that the employees had an inseperable connection to cabinets.They wouldn't stop wanting more cabinets. I had an unholy ammount of cabinets but it wasn't enough.So I took all the cabinets and put them in my office and became the god of cabinets.I ended up with 600 million dollars and 1 million loyal fans, getting GOTY every year and Dev of the year ever year.This game is hands down 10/10 no questions asked. It doesn't even feel like an early acess game it has so much to offer.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just thought I'd quit playing the game real quick to put up a review. I'm really impressed. Especially since this game is in alpha. It already feels complete. And honestly, this is probably the deepest game dev sim I've played. There are good ones out there (Game Dev Tycoon, Game Dev Story) but this one reaches almost every aspect of game development. Or it close, at least. Props to the devs for making this game. $15 well spent.Edit:This game gets very hard after you have around 20 million dollars. Lots of micro-management. Would like for that to be slightly better.Edit 2:Did not realize you could have more than one desk per room. Wow I'm dumb...Anyways, that takes off the mass amount of micro-management. This game is truly great. 10/10Edit 3:Yea...went back to fix typos. Just one quick thing: The amount of updates parallels to that of Unturned (Another great game). They constantly update the game, adding new stuff (and bug fixes). It gotten immensely improved in the past 2 months. I'm probably getting redundant by this point, so here's the end of the review.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								I had loads of fun with this game. It really does improve on everything on existing "Gave Development" games. The biggest downside however is near the end, and not a lack of end-game either. What I've noticed is that once you start making bank, you've made it to the bigger buildings, and then you move into production and self publishing. I had every room in the game in my building, and it was the most micro-managing I have had to do since StarCraft 2. For me, it lost a lot of it's character and enjoyment as soon as I hit this roadblock. Developing games quickly becomes just a side project alongside the many many other side projects you have, and it becomes very reptitive. All said and done, it's still a great game and it will keep you entertained for hours, and this is still alpha! There are loads of things I'm sure that will be added on, improved, and possibly flat-out removed.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let's write a quick review:At this stage I would give 8/10 in this game.Pros:- Nice graphics and sounds. Nothing big, but fits well into the game.- I do not feel the pressure to release a game. I can spend time on enhancements.- There are just enough areas the game covers, from game engine development to production.- Quite good interface. It's easy to reach anything.Cons:- It is a bit annoying that after I finished a game, my development team cannot do anything if I select 'release later'. My team should improve the game, develop bug fixes, add new features, etc...- The music team cannot finish their work if I choose 'release the game' even if I set a long, lets say '24 weeks later' option. The whole game release process should be revised.- The review should come after I finished everything, even improvements! Now it happens immediately after I selected 'release game'.- I am not sure, but it seems that even if I started repaying my bank loan, when I have enough money to repay the whole amount, the original amount will be taken from my account.Improvements:- There are tons of topics to research. With a 4-member-team I can easily reach a point when I do not really have anything to do just reasearching new topics. A small checkbox with title "Continue topic reasearch when finished" would come handy, so I do not need to go through the research topic procedure in every 3 seconds.- There are areas that need some additional help information. Bank loans (about the amounts that need to be payed), production (how much production capabilities per week I have), buying properties (how big each offices are) and similar things.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								First, I want to mention that I NEVER recommend Early Access games unless the current product is entertaining, and well worth the price you pay. That is the case with this game.I've played Game Dev Tycoon, and Game Dev Story (not 100% sure that's the name...I'm talking about the Kairosoft game), so I know this niche genre pretty well.It will take a second to adjust to the way things are done in this game. The complexity I've always felt was missing from games like this is here in abundance. You need to manage how your resources are used to develope each game, and hire/fire employees...standard stuff. However, this game requires you to use the space you have to the absolute fullest. You need to section off areas of your garage/office into designated areas reserved for developement, quality control, research, marketing, bathroom, employee lounge, and much more! The game unlocks things as you play, so it attempts not to overwhelm you. I have to admit, even though I love these kind of games (and am pretty good at them) on my first playthrough I did find myself getting a little overwhelmed. I kept finding myself feeling like I was playing catch-up to the ever increasing demands of the game, and not in a good way.EDIT: On my second attempt, things went MUCH better. I can honestly say that this game is the best Tycoon game I've ever played. I pretty much just lost an entire day in this game, and enjoyed every hour of it. It can be kind of complicated, but it's definitely learnable through some trial and error. If there are bugs, I haven't seen them. There's an element of Sims at play here, as it can be fun setting up your offices, decorating them, and all that. There is a lot to this game, but it's simple once you spend some time trying it out. Expect to fail at your first attempt, but just view it as a learning experience.Long story short, this is the best game developer tycoon game ever made. Game developer story and game dev tycoon can't hold a candle to this game. Worth every penny. The best part is that it's still in Early Access, which (if the current state of the game is anything to go by) means it will get even better than it is right now.My rating- 9/10A small message to the devs, if they should happen to read this, please get rid of that obnoxious phone ringing. One more thing...when employees are working, i think you should go with either the progress bars, OR the little icons popping up above their heads. Not both. The only issue I have with this game is that there's a lot of clutter all over the screen, and it sometimes blocks out things that the player needs to be able to read. One last thing, I think the demands of the employees should be reduced, frequency-wise. It feels like it's happening a little too often that my employees start working at half speed, all because I don't have enough cabinents (or something similar). It's kind of strange how hiring employees is restricted by what pieces of furniture and stuff you have. If I have a luxury sink in my bathroom, why would an employee demand I have the cheap one before I can hire him/her? If you have a better version of an appliance/furniture/etc. it should count towards employees that demand a lesser version.EDIT #2: This game is receiving updates from the devs, FYI. They are consistently adding features, here and there, that expand the game in meaningful ways.

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
Early Access Review
Status;"IN PROGRESS"First off... its not Game Dev Tycoon, not comparable. Played both now for hours.This game is faster paced, more in depth, and has so many more attributes to follow as if you were running your own game development studio or corporation.Get this game if you like Tycoon games, we guarentee you will enjoy this!Not easy, but very easy to learn.Replayability is great.Polished, you get to create your space for each department.Many publishers to choose from.Many genre's and market choices.Good graphics and no lag what so ever.No crashes yetThe content just keeps coming. Amazing run and devotion!Tips; (Dont bend over in a public restroom! No... seriously... don't... )Spend slow, build slow, get some cheap games out first to get your revenue going.(Its fun to grow slow and watch it come out huge! Really huge!)Dont hire anyone but your dev team to start, and make a bathroom, otherwise it can get messy! Be sure to include a water fountain, plant, fire extingusher, and top desks in every room.Buy it, you wont regret it if you played Game Dev Tycoon and enjoyed that, this game surpasses all it had and has so much more.Guarentee you will really like the work done and the hours of play! THIS GAME IS ONE OF THE BEST in the Tycoon Genre.This is a solid buy as they come but the devs wont respond to email, so good thing there is no ground breaking problems as of yet.  They make a lot of posts and updates but don't really listen or interact with the community, which is sad with a homerun like this. Your only good as your fan base guys. Keep up the good work tho!!Discalimer; The Review Crew's evaluations are based on paying close attention to forum response and activity, system demand, fun of the game genre, position of originality in respective genre, growth of the project in its current state at time of review, graphics as a whole for end user, presentation of the game and display, replayability, patch/tweak progress, beginner friendliness & gameplay direcction, content & depth, attention to detail on small things(polish), lag and multiplayer application if applicable, badge card availability, with a minimum 8 hours of gameplay and interaction with customer base after release. We are not affliliated with any specific brand or entity or on any payroll. All views are based on positive only feedback as we are in no position to criticise anyones craft, just current states of development and progress at the time of our participation. If we offend anyone with our content, it was not us! Our review was hacked!

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's a lot of "game design" type games on the market. This one has potential, but in its current state you come to a standstill after about 5 hours of gameplay.PROS:- Interactive choices, you can build your own rooms and add furniture. Style is reminiscent of Theme Hospital.- Ability to add decor is nice. Some employees may require for you to have a specific piece of furniture or decoration before they'll work for you.- Large variety of topics and genres to build games off of.- Ability to train staff is nice.Edit 05/29/15:- Recently added feature allows players to release game updates for their games.- Recently added "Quality Assurance" room allows players to bug test their game prior to release.- This game is updated frequently enough that I keep coming back to it, giving it lots of replay value.CONS:- Needs a bigger variety of staff to hire from. After a while the only ones I could hire were the ones I fired for having low stats. Edit 05/21/15: This was fixed in latest patch.- Game starts to get really slow and laggy at the biggest office upgrade. Maybe I just have too many staff, I dunno, but it got really sluggish after a while. Edit 05/29/15: I don't know if this was actually patched, but in my most recent game I noticed this is no longer an issue while playing the biggest office. (Nothing on my end changed, so I assume this was a result of a patch.)- Lots of features not implemented, which brings the game to a standstill in its current form.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great game, its a lot like Game Dev Tycoon but with the ability to build your own office and a few interesting options, such as creating and selling game engines and buying licenses for movies and the like to make games for.The first 10 years are really fun and challenging, but at this point the end game is quite broken.Once you can afford R&D you can easily stay ahead of the game engine curve, so every game you make gets a 90+ rating and earns mega bucks. Then you can spend that money on a production facility and cut out the publishers, which is super low risk and earns way to much money. Finally, half your building is devoted to servers for your MMO subscribers, and you are earning millions more in passive income than you know what to do with.

								Before I start this game is amazing, these comments will only to be to ask for improvements upon the game. The first thing is the space. Fourth its to easy to make amazing games especially early on, make it where the characters actally suck at everything, so we may groom them for what we want them to do. The next one, fifth, The game doesn't give you enough information making it hard to figure out your building layout, or just whats going on. Sixth keep up the good work the game is really turning into something promising, love it. Oh and can you please implement all these ideas however you like and then remove and add if necessary. Love the game. :-)

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have never written a review before in my life, for literally any product. I don't fill out online surveys. I don't respond well to people calling me and asking if I have time to answer some questions. I NEVER GIVE FEEDBACK. Yet, here I am, writting this review. That should say something about how passionately I feel about this game. This is exactly what I have been searching for. I love it. I cannot stop playing it. It's absorbing my life and ruining my sleep schedule. If you like logistics you'll love this game.It's still early access, but it's already a great game. I don't know if developers read these reviews, but I have only a few complaints. 1. When your company gets large and people are wandering around it becomes impossible to find people and move them to a different room.2. I feel the game is paced too fast. I think that one game year goes by in 20 minutes? I haven't really timed it out, but it is too quick. I think that they should slow down how long you get to spend in one year, or at least add the ability to adjust the game pace (making faster makes the game more challenging).Those are my two biggest complaints. And they're not even complaints. I don't know how much longer they plan to keep it in early access, but this is a well put together game right now. I can think of a lot of features it would be cool to have (for example the ability to release early access games, the ability to develop mobile app games), but I can't think of anything this games needs to complete it.If you like the builder/management sim type games, you will love this game.You will be obsessed.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								Mad Games Tycoon - The First Impressions ReviewThe Cons- Currently there is no real way to gauge production, for example, your company just made a game called "Bob and the Destroyers" the game gets an average 75 to 80 rating. There is no system that lets you know how many copies you should produce. This leads to a guessing game on the overall rating, hype, and fanbase of your company to create an estimate. If Pre orders became a thing in game like maybe in 2007 or so then it would make being a publisher easier.- Currently there is no real way to assign your subsidary to create a sequel to a game, I find that most of my game sequels are 4 - 5 years apart, however sometimes my dev studios are busy trying to make a new IP and I forget about a previous one that was fairly decent in success, this leads to a ten year gap sometimes between some games. If you could assign a subsidary to create a sequel, and control the engine used as well as the platforms, this would make it easier to keep your greatest of Sagas or trilogies going while being able to focus on new projects and games, of course the level of studio quality will influence the games overall rating, so chooing wisely would be in your best intrest.NeutralYou cannot create subsidaries, conventions, or create handheld consoles.Okay this is more of me nitpicking small details, but this is something that would really be cool or interesting to do.Scenario: Your company is growing and you decide you want to make a subsidary becuase you plan to publish your own titles, creating a subsidary would be a big investment like buying them out is. You start out and have 5 options, for 3 million you can make a one star subsidary, 5m gets two star, 7m gets 3 star, 10m gets four star, and 15m will make a 5 star subsidary, the inital investment is steep, from here subsidaries could be given more directions, for example you could create a deadline for the AI controlled subsidary to come out with Two new games every year or so. This could affect not only the goodwill of the company (value) but also affect the rating of the games it creates.On game conventions, making one called AGX (Arcade Gaming Expo) which is a play on the Penny Arcade Expo or PAX that is cheaper to participate in but also yeilds less attendance and hype would be great for smaller companies, or the ability to create your own and make proceeds from the companies who attend the event, of course this would also be another investment.Right now we have the ability to create home consoles, but if this could be expanded to handheld that would be a cool feature alongside having both the Home and Mobile markets split into two seperate identies would mean your company could have their home console and mobile console on the market at one time. Positive Influences+ You can virtually create any kind of company you want to. If you wanted to you could creat a game development studio that is independent and has no set publisher and develop for PC only or you could create over time a game dev and publishing company that publishes and makes 100% of the profit, or you could go as far to challenging Katari or Mintendu by becoming a Hardware manufacturer owning subsidaries and publishing console exlusive titles making your market share rise. You could even only do contract work and make minimal money to operate but keep yourself small. The choice is yours.+ The gameplay is addicting and challenging at higher difficulties, in essence you create your own problems and have to make the correct choices to manage your companies funds and gain foothold in the market.Overall I give "Mad Games Tycoon" an 8/10 for my First Impressions Review. This title has a ton of potential to wipe the floor with other Game Dev Simulators, also I would rather state this game is more of a Game Industry Simulation.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								The year was 1980. Reed, the sole proprietor of Angry Panda Studios began his journey. Over then next twenty years APS would be the laughing stock of the gaming community. Always being the underdog drove Reed. He stayed afloat for another decade when he decided to hire another person. It was this ragtag team that formed what would be referred to as "The Big One." With both employees focused on producing a game of epic proportions history would be changed forever. The release of their game generated nearly 500 million dollars in revenue for the company, thus expansion began. APS became a titan in the gaming world almost over night with over 30 employees on staff 24/7. Reed decided it was time to unveil the real reason he started APS in 1980, to take over the gaming industry. With all staff members devoted to one project they created a monster, a hellish beast. Critically acclaimed and winning game of the year this game pulled in over 10 billion dollars in revenue and stayed on the market for 20 years. With such a large income Reed purchased all competitors and forced them to close, making Angry Panda Studios the studio of the year, every year.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you’ve played previously games like Game Dev Tycoon or GamersGoMakers then you already know what to expect.  If you haven’t, then this puts you as a game developer, starting out in the early 1980’s.  You begin small, producing small, simple games, from small, simple premises with appropriately early gaming technology.  As time goes on (assuming you don’t go bankrupt) you have the opportunity to expand, by hiring more people, researching new technology and moving into bigger premises.Visually, Mad Games Tycoon is better looking than those other games.  Another area where this differs from the aforementioned games is that with Mad Games Tycoon, you have to manually create each room and place the appropriate furniture in it.  Over time, your staff will complain about wanting things, like plants or heating, which you’ll have to place in the room, so you’ll need to make sure you create a room big enough.  Not too big, though, because in the early stages, you only have limited space for your rooms.Eventually, you’ll have the opportunity to produce and distribute your own games instead of going through a publisher, as well as creating MMO’s hosted on your own servers.This game is still in early access, and while it should be obvious what that means, it’s apparently not obvious to some.  Early access means the game is still in active development.  So, new features will be added and existing ones may be altered or even removed.  You might even find your save games get ruined sometimes, forcing you to start again.  The game is NOT a finished product, which is why it’s in early access.  You’ll almost certainly run into bugs from time to time, and features that aren’t available or aren’t working as intended.  The most important thing to know about early access games is this: are the developers actively working on it?  The answer for Mad Games Tycoon is definitely ‘yes’.  Updates are regularly being released, which are usually both fix bugs as well as adding new features.  This is important, because I’ve seen early access games where the updates concentrate on one but not the other, causing the game to suffer as a result.The game is still very much playable in its current state, but it’s by no means finished, and nor is it perfect as yet.  It would be really good, for example, to have better feedback as to why your game was terrible, or indeed why it was so good.  It’s not necessarily easy to work out exactly why your previous game did as well, or as badly, as it did.  Hopefully that aspect of the game will get worked on in time to come.  I know too many early access games have died or taken forever to do anything, but I’ve seen nothing so far to suggest that this game will be the same; on the contrary, I’m confident that we will indeed see a finished product in time, and a damn good one.  But please keep in mind, if you buy a game in early access then you’re paying money for something which may or may not actually get finished, or finished in the way you were expecting.  It’s always going to be a gamble, but in this instance, it’s one I was happy to make.

								I Bought this game after I realised I needed something to play that is calmer than Capitalism 2 but satiate my need for management, making money and build a company - hence Tycoon games gendre. So i jumped on to Steam Sidenote:(what a great platform for investigation it is - Good job Valve). and typed Tycoon in search bar. Prison Architect being another great game in this gendre. Then I proceeded to search via User Reviews and then MGT had Very Positive rating. Then upon investigating what games users played and then the best one - 10 reviews mentioned how many times and regularly the studio updates!! A KEY COMPONENT of Alpha games, combined with 1382 reviews and positive studio reports I dived in and purchased. That was 3 days and 67 hours ago. :P I really enjoy this game and it's just excellent (of course i have suggestions and improvements however when a game start sthis well in Aplha the Omega is the limit :D.) And since my purchase on Tuesday 24th May 2016 i have enjoyed 2 updates already. GREAT JOB @ Eggcode :D and even bought the game for a friend @Vader and got another to buy once they saw me playing. And thank you to fellow Steam users and for taking time to write Reviews.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								TLDR AT THE BOTTOMFirst off I want to say that I think this is what Game Dev Tycoon should have been (mostly), and that it is THE best game tycoon to date. Pros: Nice aesthetics for a tycoon game, no lens flares and motion blur to be seen hereWhile it is simplified, it is a realistic simulation of the game industry as a whole.Wide variety of developers and publishersAt the moment , the price point feels very appropriate (£10.99)You can import your own logos, in the game files, look for a folder with lots of PNG files, and then download your own PNG files (not sure if other formats work) Cons: At the moment, there is no modding community, I am not sure if it is that there is no mod support at all or if the community is not big enough, but as someone who loves to mess around with game files, this is very disappointing to me.At the moment, the end game is very lacking  and it is way too easy at the end. In my main save, it is 2006, I am sitting at about 2.5 billion dollars, 1.2 million fans and all of my games have been 90% or better for about 18 years, and this is at the hardest difficulty. The game is really unoptomized at the moment, my computer can run simcity on high settings at 1080p at 60fps but it cant run this at "fast" settings at 1336x768 and stay at 60, which really killed my experience.In conclusion I think that this is the best game studio simulator at the moment, but it does still need some work on expanding the content.TL:DR Buy it, its pretty good.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you are a fan of tycoon games, this is a must!Pros: - Console development- Great development team who updates the game regularly- Good sense of replayability - Ability to branch out into many different aspects of the video game industry- The many rooms such as marketing, customer support, quality assurance, research, motion capturing, + more, immerces you into feeling like you're running an actual games company- It is more friendly and easy to beautify your company- the game is easy to pick up and well worth the money - You can find yourself playing way more than intended- You can train employees in the skills that matter to their job- You can make MMOs and addons- You can patch your game after release as well as develop updatesIt's safe to say there are many positives, it is well worth a purchase and the development team deserve a thumbs up, there are many more aspects of the game I have not listed. It seems that the little features that you notice go a long way. Final review: The game is worth the money, and cannot be compared to game dev tycoon as Mad Games Tycoon is something unique in itself that allows you to branch into many different aspects of the gaming industry. Conclusion - WORTH BUYING

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm on my first playthrough of this game and I love it!It probably helps if you're a game nerd and a lover of tycoon games, like me.You start of in your (parents?) garage and work your way up from there.The controls are very easy. And there are lots of thing to develop.You can take contracts and produce games for others, but also release games and consoles yourself.Hire the best staff and train them to become your masterminds. Make sure the right person is in the right place.I find this game very satisfying and I have a hard time closing down my laptop and going to bed haha.Pros:*Easy to learn the basics.*Many different games to develop.*Lots of hardware and software to research.*Easy to get "caught up" and play for to long.Cons:*With a huge company it tends to get a bit messy on the screen.*Quite hard to master the development strategies for high selling games.*Some graphic glitches where staff teleport through walls, but no big deals.*Easy to get "caught up" and play for to long.Overall:I give this game a score of 7.67 / 10 for being very fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fun, but only for a very short time...It's 2015. Every game I release that does not sell 100 Mio. Copies in the first year is considered a failure. But that's still ok, since my studio hasn't released a game with a rating less than 90% since the early 80's. Unfortunately, I can't releaser any more games, even in the biggest office and though I demolished almost all other rooms, I can't build any more servers for my subscription sheeple. And since I closed down all the other studios early on, there hasn't been a game of the year in...years, really. So I guess, I'd be a little more fun if there was something to discover after 2001, a way to improve something instead of just repeating what you just did, like dismissing a marketing campaign every 5 seconds. But you get to develop something like 75 games before you figure out the perfect settings, and for that time, it was great fun.The bad: * the default speed is way to fast, and space does not pause the game (hint: '1'does, though)* assigning people to rooms is hell* re-assigning people to rooms after some training comes down to 'who are you and where did you work before'* no work queueing. (actually, that is not true. Almost no work queueing)* after a while, it get's repetetive as .... * appearently, the world of video games has not made any advancements after 2001.Still, you get almost 30 (simulated :) years, in which teh game is great fun.Last's about a weekend.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like Game Dev Tycoon, you will probably like this more. It isn't the same as GDT, there's a lot more management. You build your rooms add desks, hire staff etc. You can buy or make your own game engines, with the option to sell the engine and get a percentage of the AI developers games. There is more control over the games you create - you can buy licenses to increase the appeal of the game.Currently the game is Early Access, and will probably stay that way for a long time although the devs do dish out updates often. With that MGT has a lot of problems:- looks like English isn't the devs native language, you can understand the messages just about though- massive amount of annoying messages that pop up, whenever your staff complete any project or training, any new research available, when a console is going to be released, has been released is going to be taken off the market, when it has been taken off the market, when your games get taken off the market, when your engines sell, each time your game stops until you click ok (and project/training messages require 2 ok's) - research technology isn't consistent, particularly early on. By the time you finished your research and created an engine for it at the beginning it is already obsolete, but after year ~2000 there's hardly anything new that comes out. -theres currently no point in doing AAA games as there is only 20 different end game technologies available. -they recently added new consoles and stuff, which doesn't do anything for you other than more annoying messages.-Easy and normal have no challenge to them whatsoever, and there's no end game score like in GDT. If you haven't made 200 mil by 2005 you probably wanna check your pulse. Legendary mode is rediculous, although I've only had 1 good go at it. You can make games without engines and sell them for a profit so long as your staff are fully trained, you can do contracts and make engines to sell for like 5% profit at the beginning, but everything else fails. After my best go i made a few mil, made the best engine, fully trained my staff and made a AA game with everything in it and it failed and I went bankrupt. In Easy it's the opposite, no matter what you do you will still make a profit.-when you get a larger building and fill it with stuff the game's performance drops through the floor. To summarise, this game is worth it if you are into sim/tycoon games. The devs do update the game often, but in it's current state only die hard tycoon game fans will clock anywhere near as many hours as i have put into this game.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
Early Access Review
 I want to say one thing before you read this. This is still in Early Access, they are still making the game. Don't forget to post bugs and stuff you see. Now that that has been said, continue reading.I highly recommend this game. Not only is it a better version (and more updated) of Game Dev Tycoon, but it adds the element of how it is like to acutally create the game. This game does have some downsides, but other than that it is a really good game. I think this game will bring alot of people into the game making community! Now, I have personally tried using the unity engine, and I know Basic C#, and I could create nothing like this. I also have about like 79 games in my library, so this should make an impact. If you want to see this, hover over it! First off, this game is amazing. Not only will you spend the time to get started, you have $500,000 dollars into the hole while playing. I have gone into the negitives a couple times, but I have always gotten out. This game should really have a modding community, or at least mod support, because this could be imporved by adding things by mods.There are a couple downsides to this game as well though. If you want realism might wanna play Game Dev Tycoon. If you want fun, might wanna play this game. I say that because the ecomony is not the best. I will usually get about 500,000$ on a really sh*tty game. A second thing is that, sometimes when I launch the game, it will crash when it is done loading the "Egg" screen. I don't know if this is just me but I have to relaunch the game to get it to work. After I re-launch it seems to work fine though, so yes, this game is amazing. Another thing I really hope they work out is the "No Deleting Saves" thing. I feel every Game Dev game is missing a delete save. What are the odds ;)?Other than the couple of bugs, I highly reccommmend this game, because I have played it for hours now, and already almost reached a day. This is going to be an amazing game when it comes out of Early Access, and I wonder what the price will be when it does. Thank you for making this game, and thank you for making everything about it.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've booted this game up once only so far, and have 13 hours in game. That should tell you quite a lot.This game is quite similar to Game Dev Tycoon except has a whole lot more. The rooms are customisable and your staff will require different furniture and working conditions to keep them happy. It has quite a steep learning curve at first and I failed miserably with my first 3 games. As the game progresses and as you hire more staff, you'll need to be ontop of several different tasks at once, all with time limits. Games that have been released will need advertising and game updates to keep them in the market. If you publish your own games you'll need to keep an eye on how many are being made, if you have enough stock etc. The game will pull you in, and has a lot of replayability. Finally making a smash hit game was hard to do but felt so damn good.Definately worth the money.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've booted this game up once only so far, and have 13 hours in game. That should tell you quite a lot.This game is quite similar to Game Dev Tycoon except has a whole lot more. The rooms are customisable and your staff will require different furniture and working conditions to keep them happy. It has quite a steep learning curve at first and I failed miserably with my first 3 games. As the game progresses and as you hire more staff, you'll need to be ontop of several different tasks at once, all with time limits. Games that have been released will need advertising and game updates to keep them in the market. If you publish your own games you'll need to keep an eye on how many are being made, if you have enough stock etc. The game will pull you in, and has a lot of replayability. Finally making a smash hit game was hard to do but felt so damn good.Definately worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								As an aspiring game designer I find this game to be an inspiration. What better type of game to make than one about making games? Besides, I find this very type of game interesting as it allows me to simulate my dreams. This game is very much for the players as well, as any ideas or suggestions are considered by the development team. Although simple I feel as though it is the perfect game to begin your—Eggcode’s—development experience with. Mad Games Tycoon starts you off in a garage in the 1980s where you must claw your way up through the game industry by starting your own company and making history. Creating revolutionary games is all the fun with this game. Being able to create a legacy for others to be inspired by as well as making the games which changed the industry in your own way are the reasons this game is so addictive. The game is quite easy as well, making all of the complex tasks very easy for beginners; of course there are exceptions further along in the game whereby the expansion of your company requires more elements to be available. The ability to unlock more aspects of the game in a more controlled manner by forcing players to earn money and play for lengths of time before they can move onto more complex tasks creates a buffer for new players to understand the mechanics of the game industry better. I did find however that when I began first creating my games they would usually go bust and I would have to rework contracts to regain money, I now realise that this game utilises the term you need to spend money to make money, and it works.Their depiction of the tools available is quite well done in fact, it excites me. Being able to change and modify so many details such as the toilets for example captures the side of me that loves management games. The ability to develop patches, updates, language packs, sequels, as well as undertaking contracts tugs on my perfectionist personality when it comes to games, so making sure they’re ‘up-to-date’ creates the atmosphere of me almost being there. The endless immensity of content in this game leaves me wanting more, and the actual experience far outweighs the realistic visual quality some of today’s games may offer, especially for such a low price. This game honestly propels my excitement for my own career through the roof. Being able to tell stories and make so many people happy in such an interactive way is thrilling. Mad Games Tycoon gives me encouragement to create games which can redefine gaming; a big dream yes, but at least I’m aiming somewhere. This experience provides me with insight into what can be done with a little work: being able to create worlds, or go back to different times, it’s all merely based on imagination and creativity and this game shows me that Eggcode has created a very tantalising experience—one that shows they create promising hope of future games as alluring as this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								So, I'll be honest, after the great game that was "Game Dev Tycoon" (GDT) scratching an itch to be a game developer that I didn't know I had, I ended up talking and making mods with an associate of mine, and eventually ended up looking for games that came close to what we wanted to turn GDT into. The only thing that was 1) available, and 2) came anywhere close was a title called "Mad Games Tycoon" by Eggcode.But it's not a title that appeals to just one type of simulation gamer, but multiple types. It aims not only at those aiming for perfection, but aiming for an experience that isn't easy.True, you could take notes on things between games on where different sliders for game customization should be for different genres but to me that seems to lessen the experience a bit. This is a game where you start out in the early days of video game development. The first systems are a Personal Computer (PC) and an early Atari-type system. And it goes from there, with new consoles being released, competitors making their games and engines, liscensing your engines, and the reviewers being as critical as they ever were!It comes in four difficulty levels and options to randomize the console popularities, and so many little intricacies that you can use to affect your scores on different titles that you can never be quite certain how things will turn out.Oh, did I mention it's still early access? Yeah, it is. This game isn't even officially "launched" yet, and it's my benchmark for any title that wants to be a business simulator--yes, not just a game development simulation, but business simulators in general.If you've not picked up Mad Games Tycoon, you should. Surely you can spare $15 for this gem of an early access title.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								This is a more realistic take on game development simulation than what was seen in Game Dev Story or Game Dev Tycoon. I played the hell out of both games, but both games lack the amount of depth Mad Games Tycoon brings to the table. It combines the core aspects of Game Dev Story/Tycoon and adds in the ability to manage different divisions of your studio. It also adds the ability to publish games, market them, sell game engines, and a lot more. It takes sometime to grasp everything, but if you stick with it you become addicted. Mad Games Tycoon can use a couple more points in the visuals department, particularly with its UI. The graphics are actually pretty good. The main menu is fugly though and the game menus are a little cluttered and not totally polished. It's early access though and this is just nitpicking. I'm just glad this game exists; it’s totally what I was looking for. If you liked Game Dev Story/Tycoon and would like something more in depth then try out Mad Games Tycoon.

								It's a somewhat hesitant yes. I certainly had great fun with the game for a few hours, but I wont be coming back to it.I mean for long stretches the games was fun, but in the end when I got MMO's it went downhill. MMO's are simply too overpowered. My world of warcraft-ripoff made well over 800 million for me and all I had to do was open more develoing rooms so I could develop several consecutive MMO:s and develop expansions for them and the money just kept rolling in. Across all my active MMO:s I had well over 15 million subscribers so it kind of feels like I cant really lose at this game now.But up until that point it was a fun, albeit somewhat unpolished, game. Maybe I'll revisit in a year or so when maybe things have changed.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								I'm having a lot of fun with this game. This game adds more depth than previously released games about running a game development company. In addition to developing games, performing research, and developing game engines, you also can (optionally) produce the games for retail sale yourself. Releasing good games will help increase the market share of any device they're released on, including your own console if you create one. If you have production facilities, you will also be able to publish games made by other game companies. Probably the biggest difference in this game is that you create your own floorplan by drawing rooms and placing furniture in them. Creating an efficien layout is very important. This is the only game development game I've seen that has this.- If you've played Game Dev Tycoon and enjoyed it, then you should enjoy this game.- Vastly superior to Game Dev Story (mobile game).- Haven't compared it with Game Tycoon Studio (mobile game) yet.

								MAD GAMES TYCOONSo... where to begin, where to begin?I LOVE ITPERIOD.I. LOVE. IT.So take any tycoon game, take your favorite tycoon game, base it off of game development.Now take this tycoon game and let it make love with The Sims.You now have Mad Games Tycoon.You start in a garage, just you and try to make your way in the video game world.Hire employees, tell them what department to work in, tell them what project to work on.Make video games, produce video games, do contract work, make your own game console.Get rich as **** and buy yourself a new building to migrate to.Rinse and repeat til you have the biggest office ever!Oh did I mention that you build the office and it's components like you would design a Sims house?Because you do.10/10 Love this game.Oh and it is being updated I think monthly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								One of the best management simulations on steam right now IMO. If you've ever played Game Dev Tycoon but wanted more depth, you can stop reading and buy this. If you haven't, Mad Games Tycoon is a management simulation about starting a game development studio. You decide what genre(s), topic(s), target audience, game engine etc etc, the game is going to have/use. You oversee the development deciding whether to go more heavily into one catergory (like gameplay) over another. But you don't have to actually make games, I mean at the start yeah but not after you get established. You can make an awesome engine and sell it and make a good bit off of it. Or you can just publish games and try to turn a profit. Many different avenues can be taken to make a fortune.Pros:- Deep gameplay, with many options- Graphics are pleasing. Not amazing, but they work and add to the charm- I like the music.- Addictive- Adjustable pace.- A few different starting points (1980, 1990, 2000, 2010 IIRC. Only looked at it once)- You can set trends and be a hipster- You need to attend to people's needs. No being a slave driver.- With the sheer amount of topics (something like 300 i think), you can get some hilarious games made that'll sell well. Imagine that's a big plus for streamers/Youtuber people.Cons(minor):- The UI can be frustrating/clunky. (have to click like 3-4 Xs to leave a build menu)- The amount of sounds from completing research/parts of games etc can become constant in a big office. (thank big gunz upstairs for volume control)- Have to rebuild the entire office after each move. Understandable from a realism perspective, just sometimes can be an annoyance if you don't want to do that for 50+ people.- Have to be smart. If you have a dumb-dumb moment and move into a bigger building just because you have the cash to buy it, well read the point above again. You'll have to take out a loan, possibly at 200% the normal interest rate. In other words, a small tooltip there would be handy.- No way of grouping people into "teams" that i've seen. After a move, or a big class session, it's a pain to sift through your people to find the ones you had developing, researching, doing the graphics etc. Would be amazing if that little nuisance was plucked in the butt.- Addictive.- Nothing to really indicate when a new console is coming/when it's going to be taken off the market. No/not much historical news either. I'm in '94 right now, and haven't seen one yet.Overall, the game is very good as it is. The cons are just minor frustrations that will probably be dealt with before full release (or it's my own ignorance/dumb-dumb moments that made the cons). This is defintely worthy of a pick up if you're into management style games. If you're looking to start playing management games, this ain't a bad place to start. I'd give it a solid  8/10

Early Access Review
								I like this a lot better than Game Dev Tycoon, the only other game of the same subgenre I've played.  My reasons for that are that there is more to do / care about, more ways you can influence your game releases, much, much more with company management, it's still under development (and thus getting more content than it has already), and has more overall depth.Fun to play while you're doing other things, but I'll admit I end up being too focused on the game to function elsewhere.  Well done, devs; you've already made a decent game, but I'm looking forward to the next patch!

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Played it 12 hours straight on day one.. A few minor translation errors and there are some areas of the game that are not intuitive, but become clear when they come along later in gameplay. For example there is no point in holding the publishing of a game early on, if you do not yet have departments for graphics, music and QA etc. It is not immediately clear on how repackaging and bundling old games works. The purpose of the desk in the Home Office is also not explained, it is not actually used but applies a modifier based on the quality of the desk used. Those things being said, it is a rather enjoyable game I'd say even in it's current 'early access' state.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
Early Access Review
								Become the elite game designer you knew your were destined to be. Flog your name as the ultimate game brand and rake in the millions.This is a real gamer's game that puts you at the helm of a fledgling game company at the beginning of the industry and let's you try to do better than the big names (with a little help from mods). It's a fun experience that gets a lot of things right ...but - so far the simulation levels behind the game systems are quite shallow, and being shallow are quite exploitable and break the mood a little. If you are willing to self impose a few ground rules then these can be overlooked and ignored for the most part. And this being an EA title we can hope that the devs will flesh out some concepts and polish up the edges.My prediction is Mad Games Tycoon 2 will be a classic, this game is worth supporting to get us there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is awesome! I haven't been addicted to a game like this in a while. I played GameDev Tycoon when it came out and loved that one as well. Always hoped for a sequel to it. Well, Mad Games Tycoon is the sequel I've been waiting for! Tons of topics to use with lots of genres that you can mix, match, and blend together. The scoring of games seems to take more into account than just how much higher your score was from the last game you developed. As such I've been able to make some smaller B+ and A games that my company can release while I develop the next big AA and AAA games. The smaller games still sell well enough to keep the cashflow coming in. With several different buildings available for purchase and lots of objects to fill them with, it's easy to customize the layout to your liking. The bigger buildings give you more than enough room to make a massive gaming empire.So far I personally haven't run into any bugs. However, I would like to see more miscellaneous objects with higher ratings to decorate the office with. Also, the option to have multiple doors on a room would make designing the layout of the floor easier. Some more tooltip popups on some of the other menus would also be helpful. A brief explaination of buying and selling shares of other companies would be nice as well. Other than those things there isn't anything else I can think of at the moment that could be improved. All-in-all, this is definitely one of the more complete and polished early access games I have played. One of the better purchases I've made. The devs seem to be pretty active as well. I would totally recommend giving this game a look if you're into tycoon type games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016



YouTube™ Video: MAKING GAMES LIKE MAD! | Mad Games Tycoon #1 

			Views: 146		

			I'm really enjoying everything Mad Games Tycoon has to offer! Part 2 ►https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cyt8orDue-Y Get Mad Games Tycoon on Steam!		

What makes Mad Games Tycoon better than other game dev tycoons?In the little bit that I've played of Mad Games Tycoon, I am already really enjoying it!  It has everything that other game dev tycoons offer and even more than that.First of all, CUSTOMIZATION.  Mad Games Tycoon gives you customization opportunities out the wazoo.  It really opens up the door for extremely close and personal gameplay, so that no two players' games look the same.  Where other games have offered its players the ability to name each game, what kind of game it is, who you hire, etc., Mad Games Tycoon goes much deeper than that.  In MGT, I am given the privilege of customizing my headquarters just the way I want it, down to the foliage scattered around in my offices and even vending machines in my staff room. Customization options when making games are also pretty hefty as I am able to customize every game down to even choosing a publisher. The customization options in MGT really make me feel like I'm playing MY game and not a game that everyone else is playing.Second, REWARDS.  MGT so far has proved to be an extremely rewarding experience.  As I progress further into the game, new opportunities unlock for me (and I don't just mean new consoles and/or game genres).  The more I do in the game, the more I'm rewarded with things like new office spaces, new items, and new publishing opportunities.  The reward system of MGT takes place on a greater scale than any other game dev tycoon I've played.Lastly, THERE'S ALWAYS SOMETHING TO DO. A problem I've run into with other game dev tycoons is running out of things to do once I start development on a new game.  I would always end up hitting the fast forward button to finish the game as quick as I could.  But in MGT, there's always something to do whether it's customizing your offices, hiring new people, buying licenses or whatever you want really.  The only downside of this is that as far as I can tell, when you're doing most other things while the game is being developed, I'm pretty sure that development pauses.  But I could be wrong.So far, what I've played of MGT has proved to be an immensely satisfying experience.  I wasn't sure about it at first, but the game proved me wrong.  I would suggest Mad Games Tycoon to anyone interested in this genre of game.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game starts you off in the early days of computer gaming as a developer. Mad Games Tycoon takes a more realistic approach than some others in the genre as you hire far more employees, can upgrade to huge buildings and have far more options for your gaming empire. Here you can produce your own consoles, publish your own (and others) games, acquire other developers and eventually make massively multiplayer games that require a server room. Along the way you need to research features, console parts and an almost endless assortment of other things to keep on the cutting edge of gaming.The heart of the game is making games. This entails making game engines, which you can sell, choosing genres and sub-genres, optimizing settings for that genre, choosing a desired audience from kids to senior citizens and eventually having graphics, sounds and animation departments added features. Oh and you'll need a group of playtesters to stamp out bugs.At points it can all feel a bit overwhelming, but it is a vast amount of managerial fun if you like management times games and can handle some micro-management along the way. The game has constantly improved along the way as the developer is responsive to the community and updates frequently.I've played a significant number of games that are similiar and most are fairly good, but so far MGT is my favorite and it seems like everytime I figure I've played enough for a good long time, out comes an update with a new feature that I want to try. This is the good side of the sometimes problematic Ealry Access format and I commend the developer.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								Finally a game that doesnt try to make a total copy of "Game Dev Story" (yes im looking at you Game Dev Tycoon).MGT is a really fun approach to game dev simulation games, You start on a small garage and can only build a couple different rooms, but after a while you will be managing a big office with +100 employees. You have to plan a lot of stuff into making each of your games. Early on, you will only have a small development room, with a few people that do most of the work, but as you grow, you will start getting new rooms for each specific part of development (music, graphics, gameplay, QA) working together to make the best game possible. After you grow enough, you can even start to produce the games, instead of relying on other companies to publish it for you (and you start getting publishing deals for smaller companies too).It's still on Early Access, and it's getting weekly updates for most part. It still suffers a bit on the performance side, when you start growing up and using the bigger offices, you will get huge slowdowns, it gets a bit better each patch, but it's still far from good.Pros:- Engaging gameplay (Time flies while you try to make the best game possible, or organize your newly purchased office).- Difficult early game (You're not a God sent developer, even more so in harder difficulties, this can be very frustrating or really interesting).- As of the latest patch to date, you can build your own hardware, it's still in early stages and needs some work, but its fun to dig into the hardware market and try to make your platform the nº1 in the market.- Building is not super indepth, which imo is fine, it works really well for what the game tries to accomplish.Cons:- Late game is far too easy, around year 2020, new stuff stops coming out, and by that time you start having enough money to completely monopolize the market, even in the highest difficulty.- Changing to a new Office can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥when you have hundreds of employees and you have to manually assign each one to their position all over again.- HUD could use some work.- There are too many menus (e.g. To buy a chair you need to: Open the build Menu > Select the Misc sub Menu > Select the Chair you want), and while you're browsing the menus, the game completely stops, and slightly breaks the flow of the gameplay.- The Market needs a huge revamp, a finite amount of buyers, and logic consumers (I've had a game, exclusive to my own hardware, and that game sold twice as much as the console ever did in it's life time).Overall I'd say this game is a safe purchase if you're a fan of the genre :)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								So, this is a weird one. Mad Games Tycoon is pretty much exactly what you'd expect. It's miles beyond something like Game Dev Tycoon. It's always updated. They update it constantly.But here's the problem: It's incredibly addicitive for the first 8-10 hours or so. I went to bed at 4:30am two nights in a row. Then you realize you've done everything there is to do and the game gets boring. I completely lose interest and usually stop playing after around 10-12 hours. I go awya for 6-7 months, come back and there's enough new features that I reapeat the process again.The problem with MGT is that it's going to have zero replayability after the constant updates stop, and they eventually will. You play it once, do everything you can in 8 hours, then never touch the game again. Keep in mind, I _love_ management simulations. I have hundreds of hours in Football Manager, for instance. But there's just not so much to do in this one. As I said, once the updates stop, there's no chance you'll want to replay it after you go through it once. Keep that in mind before you buy it.I do give it a conditional Yes, though, as it does have that initial 8 hours of crippling addiction.

The game has constantly improved along the way as the developer is responsive to the community and updates frequently.I've played a significant number of games that are similiar and most are fairly good, but so far MGT is my favorite and it seems like everytime I figure I've played enough for a good long time, out comes an update with a new feature that I want to try. This is the good side of the sometimes problematic Ealry Access format and I commend the developer.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you love game development and if you love Theme Hospital then you will love this one. Given this is early access and room for heaps of improvement is brutally obvious, the game is shaping up to a solid management simulation in the likes of Bullfrog creations. It even sprinkles some humor over the game to keep things interesting. There is depth in gameplay which is missing from Game Dev Tycoon (another good game in its own right). You need proper planning and the game, in its current state, is unforgiving. You cannot resize rooms! Choices like "should I place that expensive one star plant or the cheap one star plant?" become important as you grow a bond with your virtual employees. Sometimes you feel like rewarding them by throwing in an extra fan. The game follows accurate history of game development and I felt nostalgic when I could easily relate to 16-bit graphics being a selling point. I highly recommend you try it out and experience it for yourself but keep in mind : EARLY ACCESS

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
Early Access Review
								Mad Games Tycoon is different from games like Game Dev Tycoon. It has a more realistic approach like that your employees have to use the bathroom and if they find the room/building cold then they work slower. Although I find working 24/365 unrealistic as I don't think anyone is that passionate about games where they would work without at least taking a vacation in 30 years. Mad Games Tycoon has more ways of making money for example  you can make money off of engines by setting a certain % of profit sharing if people buy your engine and use it for their games. You can also make money from subscriptions from MMO although that needs some balancing.The game is still in early access and so far I am happy with the way things are although there are some bugs and things that need balancing.Would recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								After a massive timesink into this game I feel that Mad Games Tycoon makes for a signifigant updated version to Game Dev Tycoon. The consept of the two games are similar, but everything else within the game is much more complex in both tasks and mechanics. You are required to put in a lot of consistant imput, spend a lot of time thinking about growth, and for the perfectionist there is a lot of ways to micromanage, but the game is not built to require it either for the casual gamer making for a great balance.While there are flaws such as how the charachers will get themselves hung up on some objects, I hardly consider such minutia an issue due to the fact that this is an early access game (as of writing this review). For those who loved Game Dev Tycoon, this is a must buy. Just remember when you start the game, there is a sudden learning curve (due to the fact that the early access lacks a detailed tutorial at the time of this review). So for the first time player, treat the first 2-3 starts as a dry run to learn the mechanics, the objects, the rooms, etc. For early access buyers, bear with the learning curve because once you pass the turn its a massive and enjoyable timesink.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is the best of the game simulation titles that I have played and while comparable to Game Dev Tycoon it is more akin to Game Dev Story on Android devices. It has more variety, it allows you to build rooms yourself, it has a wider range of training parameters, and the story is considerably longer than other tycoon games. At six hours I just encountered the release of the PS2 where in other games we'd be finished the list of events. That said the game can be much better. English is clearly not the first language of Eggcode (See event message for game release "3th World War 2") and there needs to be quite a few corrections. Secondly the animation and graphics of the people / employees is terrible. People barely look like people and females are only distinguishable by their names. The game allows you to succeed largely as a producer of engines if you don't have luck making games but I feel this could be expanded and improved to allow for engine marketing and support. Maybe even the design of periphreals to sell with the engine or game. Another issue is that the event messages are strictly limited to other game releases and profit reports. Eggcode should be looking at adding things like conventions, pirating issues, fan requests, and direct interaction with the publishers. The game tracks publisher relationship but that doesn't seem to extend in functionality any further than how likely they are to produce a marketing campaign for your game.

												I'm not sure what initially drew me to this game. I've enjoyed most game development titles but always thought that there could be more. I watched good ol' Sips play a bit but I don't think he grasped the difference between Mad Games Tycoon and other titles. What struck me was the depth available in gameplay. Sure there are some things that could be done better (upgrading location for instance should keep layout of current office; ability to simply "move" rooms with contents; multiple automated offices?, things like that), but the core of the game is very good. I would recommend it, especially seeing how I got stuck in for 4 hours right away, and keep coming back. I've got a few more hours to put in before I've hit everything I think I could hit, but I think I could replay this some more with various settings like events turned on, raising the difficulty, and so on.

content:
Posted: March 14
												Backed it up when it was in early access. It was constantly changing, so I waited about a year for it to be complete. It paid off.	At first, the tutorial is kinda lame, the interface is simplistic, and some of the animations don't match the style, or they are just downright hilarious. But, after about an hour, I was completely invested in that game, and I played for about 7 hours straight, right before midnight. If you like tycoons, sims, or just wanna sit back and relax, the game is a good pickup.my only gripes with this game is that when you move from building to building to save more space, the rooms don't save, so you need to rebuild everytime you move (and you'll be moving a lot, pal.). You should group up your employees before you move, or else you'll have to carefully reorganize everything back into their original positions.\I would give this game a 9/10.I also haven't encountered any bugs yet, so if I do, I'll be sure to update this.

content:

Early Access Review
								I don't typically review a lot of games; others usually say all that needs to be said.I'm making an exception here.I saw this game and debated it, since I enjoyed 'Game Dev Tycoon' enough. One of the best purchases I've made in a long time. I don't see any cons yet, which for an Early Access game (Which I usually avoid,) is outstanding in itself. It takes a little time to completely figure out how it functions, but that's because it's FAR more complex (In a great way,) then Game Dev Tycoon.The amount and levels of control you have is great, highly useful.I build games... and did horrible at the start. Stopped, Focused on game engines instead... did well. Went back to making more games, doing better but not great. Funding came more by the money made by my game engines. After money... made money producing games, too. Still didn't make many games.Years down the road... I'm now a economic powerhouse who has the best console, best RPG games (Which is my main focus,) and best production house in the world. 11/10 would build a company from scratch again and become another powerhouse.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								Very Stable game, especially for an early access game. I'm a big fan of simulators and most of them are crap. This one is different and the Dev's have obviously made a commitment to quality versus just trying to turn a quick buck. What is lacking is an end game at this point, or true competition with other Studios in the game. Further, when you add production lines and start self producing games, it becomes a bit difficult to manage without larger buildings, or a more automated process. The Dev's at this point could release the game as a full complete addition, and it would rival many of the sim games on Steam. But they promise more, and the sky is the limit as far as how far they take this game.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I failed 5 times until finally a game reach 20% passIt's either I suck at this game, or this game shows us the cruelty of videogames industryAfter a few more times retrying, finally gotten the basic of this gameThis game really really need tutorials, at least the basic oneBut still, for an early access game, it's great, and I'm pleasantly surprised with how complete the game is in this stageUpdate: After another dozen of hour spent after a few monsth of update, I think maybe this game has finally reached the point of "Worth buying if you're a fan of tycoon game"There's still no tutorialThere's still no way to know how to improve the sequel (well, there are, but it's vague)There's still no way to keep a fan's request for a spesific game (you just gotta remember it)Is it great?No, but good enough to keep you entertainedIs it deep and complex?Maybe? I don't see much complexity thoughIs it better than GDT or GGM ?Dunno, haven't played eitherIs it complete?There's still a feature here and there unreleased yet, so no. But the base game is complete enough to be called "Complete"Is it fun?Hell yes it is, though it gets boring later in the game, where you have lots of employees, and waiting for a new game to be finished. It is VERY sleep inducingThe graphic? The music? Nothing great about the aspectThe only thing I really, really hate about this game is there are no way to drag a lot of people in the same time. So you gotta drag people ONE BY ONE, this is very irritating, especially when you have 100 employees or so.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I chose this game based on the many reviews that said it was the "Best Management Game Evah". It's not. After 15 hours I've barely made ANY progress in this game, even following the guides and tips online. You hire a dude, make a room, make a game (which consists of picking a genre and then adjusting sliders). In one game I did somewhat okay, unlocked this room where I can analyze games so I can re-create their success. Got the best-seller, recreated it perfectly, got a horrible review, went bankrupt. Things that work in one game don't work in the other as far as creating games, so you're constantly trying to find what's good to make, constantly taking money from the bank, feels like you're never truly in control. Quite annoying. I hated this game.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												12+ hours so far, and I'm still not done playing it. 3 save files, and I'm learning more every day.I know I should make some long, drawn out reason WHY you should buy this game, or consider buying the game... You know, a legitimate review. But I won't.So quickly. For early access, this game has tons of features, and it seems to be actively worked on. If you're a fan of games like Software INC, this game is for you. While it doesn't allow for actual custom buildings like software INC, it does offer a LOT of depth, and has a decent amount of graphs, and information to offer you enough feedback so when you're doing something wrong you generally know what it is.The tutorial is lacking, severely. This game benefits from struggling, to completely failing the first time around just to get you familiar with the mechanics which are poorly explained. However, executed fairly well. The tutorial is by far the most lacking part of the game.Anyways, for $14.99, the amount of depth and the active development is enough to justify at LEAST hitting your wishlist for further consideration at a later time. Would definitely recommend, evenif this is a poorly written review. I apologize if thats the case.Still awesome! [edit 11/28/16]

content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								So this game has been updated quite a bit over the past year and I thought I'd update my review. This game is in one word awesome.  If you enjoyed Game Dev Tycoon you'll have a lot of fun, (dare I say even more fun?)  playing this game as you rise to the title of a true tycoon. Crush your enemies, see them driven before you, and hear the lamentations of their women! Buy out your competition then shut them down for good, or let them make games for your profit! Build a console that breaks the mold and take control of the hardware industry! Create the perfect game, with dozens of genres and even more topics to pick from you're sure to find a winner.  Customize your studio from the ground up: choose the logo, company name, and build your own offices!

Early Access Review
								Had an odd moment playing this game. Was pricing a game engine, trying to decide how to get the most profit, when I realized this isn't how I want companies to act. I had more than enough money, MMO subscriptions alone would carry the company, I'd have to _work_ to make an unprofitable game. Yet, I was considering taking a 50% share with millions upfront....Ended up releasing every engine type for free. Hope the non-existent people of the non-existent world get a richer gaming life because I got a memory worth keeping. Sometimes enough is enough.

number of helpful: 13 of 26 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game is shallow, poorly balanced and the UI is rudimentary and obtrusive. The concept is nice but the implementation sucks.Too little variety in all areas except game concepts. No help or explanations inside the game. A lot of ridiculous assumptions like too many types of game consoles (more than the number of games), plenty of game consoles with 0 games but 5% market share (what's the point of such a device), all employees at one level having the same salary which remains constant, people choosing a job based solely on the office furniture, people being able to work in any department (but furniture being tied to the type of room), people's skill set is extremely simplistic (game design, programming, graphics, sound, office skills - which one is useful for someone in marketing or hardware design ?). Game info is spread too thinly over a lot of hard to find places which consist of dialog boxes chains instead of having a more sensible solution. There is no progress indication for projects that aren't games (research projects, console development, marketing campaigns) not even a list of current projects. Now you manage that! After a certain point this game gets too annoying

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
Early Access Review
								After playing Game Dev Tycoon years ago, I always desired a successor that had more depth and options in how you can progress in the game. This game is everything I asked for, with the replayability being helped by the constant updates to the game. My one gripe with the game is that once you have the formula for success in your games, not making a profitable game, nevermind failing, is a non issue. This issue seems to have already started to be addressed with the addition of negative trends, so I have full faith that the game will be balanced further as it is developed. This game is worth every penny it is sold for.UPDATE (6/17/16): The developers have updated the game constantly (three in the past 10 days by the looks of it) and the balance in difficulty has definitely started to be addessed. With the consistent updating of the game. The additions the developers have made have also given this game a lot of replayability (as can be seen by my curent playtime) so I recommend it now even more.
