content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
Early Access Review
								Take Game Dev Tycoon and Rollercoaster Tycoon, now put them together. You take the idea of developing games from Game Dev Tycoon, and you take the strategic building elements from Rollercoaster Tycoon.I really liked Game Dev Tycoon, but it was lacking something. For instance, you cannot design your building in Game Dev Tycoon. The strategy was there, but there just wasn't enoughMad Games Tycoon fixes this. The game is deep, and it can take awhile to learn how to play the best. This game is well worth it at full price, and if you find it on sale, grab it right away! This one is great!8.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								I know this game is early-access but it does not free a game from judgment.This game is a step up from the game Mad Games Tycoon, though sadly it does not contain the ability to create your own console/computer.  But still, I did not and will not judge a game by it lokking or just is a copy of another game, it is content and the way that content is distributed throughout the game by it's engine.  The blend, in my view, is perfect.  However the following are the major flaws I have found to be quite irritating; you must be carefull when selecting options for what you want to be accomplished in a certain room, by opening that menu it pauses the game, but, it does not prevent you from picking up an object/staff member.  Then there is the lag generated by the moving boxes on the pressing machines, tha particle effects of a pressing machine, and from the progress/money icons generated from the staff/machines from progress/up-keep cost, respectivelly.  Next, the way pop-ups are handled in the way that the releases of consoles and the generation of money from a competitor.  I know that you can turn these off, but I belive that they could have added in, say, a ticker bar at the bottom that would not cause the game to pause during me looking up achievements or hurrying to a room to order a contract to be completed in order to avoid bankrupsty.  Finally, the way that games are created are based off of an irratating back/next button desicion screens, I sometimes miscount the number of features, or realise that the game I wanted was either to be market release only or MMO.  It would kinder that they replace the button system with a tab system.  But with the enjoyment/satisfaction I feel I would have to say 8.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you like the whole tycoon style of gaming, this isn't one to be overlooked!Basic outline of the game:The game has you start in your garage, you work for free (because you're that kind of guy!) and you possibly hire a few guys to help you out.  You research new graphical and sound techniques to keep up with the trends and work your way up in to a gaming powerhouse with your own motion capture studios and graphical studios, even being your own production company!The similarities between this and other games of this genre such as Game Dev Tycoon and Game Dev Story are many, the mechanics are the same, the goals are the same and you research the same sort of technology, genres etc.  The difference comes in that it feels a bit more in depth, it isn't just 3 sliders to determine what goes in to the game, there are a few more sliders, but the same sort of thing! Of course it does look a bit prettier as well, less like a Windows 8 store game and more like a real game, so it has eye candy going in its favour too.Being early access it still has room for improvement and I'm sure it will come. Is it worth £10.99? At the moment, probably not, I don't feel it has enough "pull" to keep me going for a long time, but £5.99 sure, I couild see that being a reasonable price in the current position (at time of review).As this is steam, I should probably give it a rough score with a funny magazine style quote.7/10 - Would fail to finish MMO expansion in time again.

However the following are the major flaws I have found to be quite irritating; you must be carefull when selecting options for what you want to be accomplished in a certain room, by opening that menu it pauses the game, but, it does not prevent you from picking up an object/staff member.  Then there is the lag generated by the moving boxes on the pressing machines, tha particle effects of a pressing machine, and from the progress/money icons generated from the staff/machines from progress/up-keep cost, respectivelly.  Next, the way pop-ups are handled in the way that the releases of consoles and the generation of money from a competitor.  I know that you can turn these off, but I belive that they could have added in, say, a ticker bar at the bottom that would not cause the game to pause during me looking up achievements or hurrying to a room to order a contract to be completed in order to avoid bankrupsty.  Finally, the way that games are created are based off of an irratating back/next button desicion screens, I sometimes miscount the number of features, or realise that the game I wanted was either to be market release only or MMO.  It would kinder that they replace the button system with a tab system.  But with the enjoyment/satisfaction I feel I would have to say 8.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you like the whole tycoon style of gaming, this isn't one to be overlooked!Basic outline of the game:The game has you start in your garage, you work for free (because you're that kind of guy!) and you possibly hire a few guys to help you out.  You research new graphical and sound techniques to keep up with the trends and work your way up in to a gaming powerhouse with your own motion capture studios and graphical studios, even being your own production company!The similarities between this and other games of this genre such as Game Dev Tycoon and Game Dev Story are many, the mechanics are the same, the goals are the same and you research the same sort of technology, genres etc.  The difference comes in that it feels a bit more in depth, it isn't just 3 sliders to determine what goes in to the game, there are a few more sliders, but the same sort of thing! Of course it does look a bit prettier as well, less like a Windows 8 store game and more like a real game, so it has eye candy going in its favour too.Being early access it still has room for improvement and I'm sure it will come. Is it worth £10.99? At the moment, probably not, I don't feel it has enough "pull" to keep me going for a long time, but £5.99 sure, I couild see that being a reasonable price in the current position (at time of review).As this is steam, I should probably give it a rough score with a funny magazine style quote.7/10 - Would fail to finish MMO expansion in time again.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm a firm believer in that when it comes to Early Access, a review has to be about where the game is going, not where it's at.Because it's early access, it's STILL in development.But this is one of those games that I can review both sides of itWhere is it going:This game is showing the potential to be an insanely great Tycoon game, with massive amounts of depth, intended more for a seasoned Tycoon player.And if the developers listen to their community, it'll be a truly community shaped Tycoon game, with massive amounts of depth and features that the gamers want. (which is really what Early Access is all about, unfortunately, not every developer gets this)Where it's at:The game is rather stable, my computer can play it without crashing, or encountering many bugs at all (my computer is a 2013 high ender, it's due for an upgrade, but it's still really powerful) this is rare for a game so early in Alpha.The game already has some really great things to play with, the core mechanics seem to all be present to my knowledge.Where the game stands now, you can purchase it and have a lot of fun with it.The game however has one downside that I personally hope gets addressed, progress on games, research, engines, general progression even progression relating to skills, is really slow, and this means that after finishing a game, you don't really get any real benefit from it in the skill department, your developers do get better at certain genres though, which is a separate system from the skill system.And to add to that, you are often put in the situation of "I have nothing to do and I'm bored, because I'm just watching things happen" while you wait for a game to complete or an engine to be fully coded, or research to be completed, etc.and there needs to be things implemented so you the player have something to do while you wait (maybe a mini game, or just general things to do, click this, this happens kinda thing, for example watering plants, collecting mail, something to keep you occupied) The visuals are good enough, but I personally believe they should upgrade the graphics if the developers get the chance, and aren't bogged down with everything else. I'd also like to be able to zoom in further.Where is it going scoreboard:Has the potential to be:Visuals 8/10Gameplay: 10/10Depth and scope: 10/10replayability: 9/10Where it's currently at scoreboard:Visuals 6.5/10Gameplay 7.5/10 - (affected mostly by what I discussed above about there being nothing to do during certain parts)Depth and Scope: 8.5/10replayability: 8/10Overall (currently): 8/10Verdict:Do you like tycoon games? do you like money? do you like video games and challenges and management?!Then why are you not supporting this?!If you like all of those things, buy this game, support the developers, play the game now and have a good time!

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
Early Access Review
True story:- Founded a company called Electronic Farts- Became ridiculously rich- Acquired all of the promising developers- Used all the manpower to create shallow successors to what once were great games on a yearly basis- Ruled the market- Got even richer- Gave♥♥♥♥♥♥about my fans10/10 best real life simulator everActual ReviewThe game is great, it's much more in-depth than other game tycoon games. Mad Games Tycoon actually feels and plays like a true business simulation. You can do so much stuff which you can't do in all the other games, so this one should be a no-brainer if you are looking for a more complex game. You can do so much more than just develop games. My first games all got bad ratings, so I decided to screw game development for now and became specialized in game engine development. You can sell the engines you develop to other studios and you also get a cut of their profit for games based on your engines. Don't like this approach? Go into production, produce games for other developers or take it one step further and become a publisher.It's true that there is quite a bit of micromanagement involved, but it's not a problem. At least you got things to do in this game. Besides, that's the way things work - as a boss you got to tell your people what to do - you delegate (unless you have some sort of middle management that does it for you, which you simply do not have in this game). That is exactly what you do in this game too. Edit: After 45 hrs. I just found out that you can queue orders for most of your departments. Graphics, audio and gameplay improvements (6 in each department) can all be selected at once and will then be completed automatically. This greatly reduces the micro management criticized by most of the negative reviews.The developer is great, he is very active in the forums and not only listens to suggestions from the community, but actually implements them. The game itself already feels very complete, this is not one of those barely playable early alpha titles. The only downside I noticed is that the performance suffers a bit as your studio grows. Not a game breaking issue though, so definitely recommended. Well worth the full price.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's been a while since I wanted to try a good Game development simulator. After reading the reviews and watching let's plays of Game Dev tycoon and Game Dev Story, I came to the conclusion that they both were lacking of deep gameplay and customization mechanics. On the contrary it seemed to be one of the strenght of Mad Games Tycoon which is exactly what convinced me to give it a try....and I do not regret it so far:  this game is already very good even on EA. There are flaws and annoying issues of course but also great gameplay mechanics and very good ideas in this game. Pro's:-Dozens of game genres (Rpg, RTS, FPS, TPS, Sim, MMO, Arcade, Sport, Fantasy, Strategy....) which can be mixed together with a subgenre AND one of the hundred of themes (SuperHeroes, WW2, Pirates, Mafia, Space, Wizards, Planes, Tanks...). This system allows you to make very unique and customized games following (or not) the public current expectations.-Office configuration: You create the rooms where your developpers will work, allowing more space and more workforce to key sectors (Research, Development, Support, Server Rooms, Marketing...) This system reminds very much of Theme Hospital and Prison Architect. -Characters levelling: Your developpers gain experience in different skills when making games or following courses on specific aspects. You can train a "Sound and music effect" expert team working specifically on music-based game for example, the possibilities are huge.-Ability to create your own game engines: Another gameplay approach is the engine development. Bad at game development? You can create games dedicated engines (customizable with a lot of functionnalities) and sell them to the competitors that will send you royalties when they make games with your engines. This alternate gameplay is one of the examples of the game's depth.Con's:-The current major issue to me is balance: For my first game in normal difficulty, without knowing anything of the gameplay mechanics, I ended up with 360M$ in about 20 years, leader on the market, releasing only major hits (90%+, 3 MMO's and 50 games overall) with my own high end game engines, with nothing to fear from the competitors (top 20 games were mines).-Lack of interaction between us and the competitors: we don't know much about them (stats, strength and weaknesses, no possibility to hire their developpers or see ours being recruted by them). I'd like to see major game companies leading the market with AAA titles like in real life, and struggling to get market shares on their lands. Currently this is simply not the case.-Not enough building and rooms objects ATM, and more than half of them are useless (why buying cheap desks when you can have the best for almost nothing). -Not enough control on the work force and the budget in general (you can't adjust the wages, no taxes, no charges...) I understand this would make the game a little more complicated but that's what economic simulations are for IMO.-Other balance issues: Marketing is basically useless (the publishers do a great job at it and releasing the games on your own (game possibility) is not financially very interesting (you earn millions even without it). Fan mechanics is not developped at all (what do they want? ATM they are only a Score System, sort of...). Some game consoles or computers are not interesting, their market share is too low (why not make unique specificities for them to give them more attractivness: A company focused on casual gaming and movment recognition could target the wii or kinect for example and become one of the leader for these consoles or on this game trend. Or aim at a niche market on another one which would be the best at one type of game.... just toughts. -Graphics and Music are poor at the moment, but that's not a major concern for me. -No tutorial (I put it here because I saw a lot of negatives comments about that, but that will change for sure).Overall this is a very good game but it seriously lacks balance at the moment. If the devs manage to balance all this and keep adding features to it, it will be one of the best economic simulator on the market.6/10 for the current state of the game, but It has the potential to reach 8/10 easily.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												I really hate to do this, but I'm changing my positive review of this game to a negative one.I first reviewed this game about a year before it left Early Access, and at the time the game was fun. But since then the game's mechanics have changed, to the point where every game I create usually loses money, or at best breaks even. Seriously, I make more money doing contract work and licensing engines than I do making games.The main problem here is that there are very few in-game cues to indicate to the player the correct settings for creating a successful game, and even these are vague. Add the fact that even if you use the perfect settings, your game might still fail depending on other variables such as the skills of your employees.For example, in my last (and probably final) game, after creating ten failed games in a row, I checked out one of the community guides to find the perfect settings for  an RPG (leaving any game to check out a guide or wiki, just to progress normally in the game, is something that no player should ever have to do). Looking forward to a quick influx of cash to save my company from bankruptcy, I was dismayed to find that my game received a review score of 42% (only marginally better than before) and ended up losing over $50k.Was it because of the skills of my employees? Was the failure of the game caused by something else? I have no way of knowing, and no way of finding out.I'm sure that there are people who have the mechanics of this game all figured out, and I'm sure that many of them are willing to pass along their knowledge in guides and in the forums. But to me, not being able to figure these things out by myself (within the game) simply is not fun. And if I'm having these kinds of problems, with a couple years' worth of experience with the game, I can only imagine how frustrating it would be to a brand-new player.This major, game-breaking problem (to me), is not likely to ever be fixed, as the game is finished and the dev has moved on.TIP: If you do decide to buy this game, and if you happen to be a Game Dev Tycoon player, don't expect your knowledge of that game to have any bearing whatsoever on this one. The mechanics of these two games are completely different.

content:

Early Access Review
								A fun game developing game in which you are not just making video games but are actually runing a full fledged game development studio.In that effect it's gameplay is more of the mix beetween games like hospital or rolecoaster tycoon and recent Game Development tycoon and Gamer's go.Micromanagment might seem a bit putting off in the begining but it will soon be barely noticable.You are also no longer weighted down by being able to develop only one game at the time. You can have multiple teams working on different projects.Aside from Micromanaging and some complaigns in regards to balancing and graphics looking like Sims, I have realy had not seen anyone bring up any other issues. And depending on how you feel about them, you might not even have problems with this things.Game is far enough in the Beta that it's playable without any major problems thought some might still occur based on how unlucky you might get. But dev's seem to be nice and are genually trying to fix what they can.Would I advise this game anyone looking for Game designer tycoon? Obviously yes, but do be prepared to be a bit more involved with your studio this time around.

Early Access Review
								Although I put a not recommended vote, "Mad Games Tycoon" is NOT a bad game.I wish there was a neutral judgement, because as it is, the game would deserve it.Unfortunately there are still too many issues, in this early game access, to vouch for this game.There are issues with UI :  interfaces that should be together are separated, especially when self-publishing games.Game creation, is, in fact, way too easy : making a "Henry Patter" licensed game as a Post-apocalyptic city builder? no problem!Craming 10 employees in 30 square meters garage ? no problem.Pros : the game is stable and doesn't lag at any stage.Sometime, less is more in game design. Game Dev Tycoon and Game Dev Story both do it better, yet.I will nonetheless continue to watch this game, and change my vote once I feel it has improved enough.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played Game Dev Tycoon before and found it very satisfying to play. I hoped that MGT would be even better, however it turned out quite ... bad. It's just a bad experience.The theme / genre combinations just don't matter as much as they do in GDT - and as they should. Too little of the review score depends on them. It appears that much more of the outcome (review score) is related to the stars you get from going for the same themes/genres/platforms and your workers' experience. It might seem logical but comparing to GDT ir ends up unpredictable, sometimes counter-intuitive and in the end unsatisfying. You might think you have all the aspects of the game set correctly, just to find out that you made a trash-game in the end.This way in the beginning - when you have no cash, no workers, and no experience - the game is really difficult and on High or Extreme difficulty - unbeatable. Later, after 15-20 years, when you have all that you want, it's just too easy - you produce succesful games no matter what.There is much more - many functions that seem to not have been thought through long enough but were added to the game anyway. Still it gave me some fun and I'll probably be back to it. But with all its flaws, to me it's just not good game even though it is very convincing otherwise.

number of helpful: 4 of 15 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Copies its gameplay substantially from other "game development sim" games. Lacks a lot of "why can't I just do that options", e.g. you can delay a release but while it's delayed developers can't work on known bugs - you can only develop a patch to fix the bugs after you ship the game off to the publisher. Also, how the heck can I publish a patch so cheaply in 1980?? This is just one example - the interactions are not very carefully thought out.Edit: Some commenters have pointed out that known bugs can be fixed in the QA room. But that's not what QA does - QA discovers bugs, it doesn't fix them, nor is there any reason it should be impossible to fix bugs on an unreleased game without a dedicated QA staff. I consider it a vindication, not a refutation, of the above point about things not being thought out.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								Well, I really wish I could select something in between thumbs up and thumbs down here. I love management / business sim games and this one has some really good innovations. The developers did a good job trying to display all aspects of the gaming industry into this game, from the simple stand-alone game productions up to MMOs which you can host on your own servers.What breaks the game, is the balancing. The game is way too easy and is getting repetitive quite soon, despite all the different rooms and options. After you have survived the initial period you need to research the first available techs by doint contract work and developing crappy engines which you sell ridiculously overprized without a problem, you are done. Every following game will be a hit with 90% + ratings. It's hard to impossible to go broke then and the remaining 80% of game time is just doing the same over and over again. + a must for business sim fans + nice innovations and ideas in the game+ good presentation for a business sim- way too easy- gets boring quickly3/10

content:

Early Access Review
								This is an early access game, but the issues listed below should have been taken care of pre-early-access-release.- Tool tips are missing in a majority of places,- English is quite obviously NOT the primary language of the developers,- Staff needs are not apparent until they become an issue,- Creating a game is not intuitive (beyond the most very basic game).These items need to be tweaked:- Staff pathing is horrific,- Not being able to hire a staffer until he gets a pop machine?  Dumb.,- Room sizes are a bit out of proportion (bathrooms must be built quite a bit bigger than a single stall would require),- Understanding WHAT all the sliders are, and why, when developing games is a head-scratcher,- When an item is locked for some reason it would be nice to know what you need to do to unlock it (more tool tips...)The game isn't totally broken, and I'm hoping in a few months it's actually more playable.  My bet is that the reviews listed in Steam are mostly the developers faking the game's reviews so people buy it.  Shame on them.

number of helpful: 5 of 19 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Like most people looking to buy this game, I came in hoping for a version of Game Dev Tycoon with an expanded feature set. While that is true, this game is severely lacks polish. There seems to be little rhyme or reason as to why games succeed or do not. Though I did not play for long, a basic explanation of the mechanics would go a long way to increasing my enjoyment. When the core gameplay loop is resource management but the only source of information is trial & error, you have a problem.This game also sorely lacks professional localization. Sometimes translation errors are funny, but when your command of english is so bad that your tutorial only half-communicates the message it's time to bring in a native speaker of the language. The entire time I was playing I kept thinking, "Just let me go through all this text and fix it, my god."I know that this is a small project, but one tweet from the dev for crowd sourced english corrections would solve the problem.Lastly, the sound effects in this game seem to be intentionally annoying. There are numerous threads on the internet complaining about this. Sound assets do not cost much, and there are even free sound effect packages out there that would be much more pleasing.I did want to love this game, the way I love Game Dev Tycoon. Unfortunately, the developer seems to lack the experience or resources to grind away at the very, very rough edges. I have refunded this game.

Early Access Review
								im being "hard" on the game by giving it a negative review because i like this game and want it to succeed.i wont say this game is a bad one. in fact i'll say the opposite i love this game and enjoy playing it for an hour every other day. it is a good game. it is also hard to play but not unfair, i stongly recomend getting a side office built just to complete the side projects you get periodically. these will keep you afloat in the early game and add a good boost to your income.buuuut i will say it is not done yet and with each update has gotten better then before. i can see this game going far.currently the game focuses around building games around a game engine that you can make or buy and packing the right features together as you work your way up to become an evil corporation and knock EA out of it's throne chop its head off and drink wine with its skull. then you will make the same rehashed game every year making some serious profit from each release until you become unbeatable! oh and at some point you produce your own games... that's cool too i guess.you can also decorate your office and custmize it the way you want and hire your own staff. though i can say i wish the various rooms interacted a bit more then they do currently.also i wish the game had better models over all as that would make the game look a bit more intresting to look at.another thing that would be nice would be when you click and drag someone elsewhere they would kick and struggle as though you litterally picked them up. really not important but i think it would add some humor to the game.if the game reviews were a bit better or if you had more control over what the game becomes would be cool too. such as writing the plot or creating your own custom features that make you stand out from the AI.so i give this game a rating of 7 out of 11 an average game but not easily forgetable. buy it when it is on sale for now, but keep it on your wish list for the future. the devs deserve the money.

In some way it adds some more expanse to the game, with the ability to make multiple games, but managements quickly becomes unruly, especially when working with the graphics studio, sound studio, and etc. If you develop your own engine, then your game will often be interupted by other studios releasing crap. number of helpful: 3 of 16 people (19%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								This may be early access material, but it feels like very early access. More troubling is the fact that the developer suffers from a complete lack of focus on so many areas of the game (as others have mentioned).Here's an example:I get that toilets is a part of every day life, but when your little worker ants go potty as the game speeds forward at a pace where weeks are seconds, I see no reason why I should be treated to the view said ants taking a 15 second potty break, and then don't even wash their hands. That's right. After 15 weeks spent on a potty break (don't ask me what they ate), don't even wash their hands. Filthy animals!I'm not saying I want the developer to add a new animation just to show me that my employees are wasting another couple of weeks washing their hands, I'm saying we're getting distracted by this whole potty nonsense to begin with! Just like the developer! There's no reason to even show such behavior at all, unless we're moving at a real time pace, in which case, those filty animals better wash up! A simple complaint notification about there not being a proper bathroom with a toilet and sink would be more than enough.In Game Dev Tycoon, the employees need vacations now and again. That's fine. Perfect, in fact... because this isn't a real time kinda game. Focus on the big stuff, and not the potty. Please.Another example of the developer wasting time:There's no need for 3D models just to make a thumbnail representation of each individual worker ant. The 3D models currently in use are so badly made, I can't even tell race or gender most the time. I was playing the game, and it suddenly struck me that I only looked at the stats when hiring people. Go figure! My brain told me to hire the most skilled worker ants over the rest. I forgot all about being "politically correct" and trying to "diversify" my staff, so I decided - because I'm a perfectionist (and an idiot) - that I would make an effort to make sure my staff was in fact diverse.That's where I ran into said problem, not being able to tell the one from the other. But it doesn't really matter. This isn't real life and I don't live in a country that's run amok with politically correctness. It's not even a feature in the game. I'm honstly just wasting your time with this rant, just like the developer is wasting their time making 3D models that suck, instead of making simple 2D graphics and focus their efforts on what this game is really about! Managing a game company! You'd think a game company would grasp this inescapable revelation.The "tutorial guy" that pops up and tells you what to do talks too much, and doesn't really help that much. I was better off just clicking around and figuring things out on my own. There's no mention of how big a room should be in comparison to other rooms, or how many desks you would need to get a balanced workload.In the smaller buildings, you'll want to maximize on what little space there is, but you can't create wall to wall rooms in certain scenarios because you're only allowed to have one door! That means you have to waste space on hallways, which really feel like undeveloped, empty space.The gamebreaking fault with this game:I spend hours and hours in my very first garage, slowly figuring out what was important and what wasn't. I ended up with a simple one desk office, a one desk research pit of despair, a bathroom which I'm having some kind of problem with (apparently), and I think that was about it. From these humble beginnings went from struggling to survive, to making millions of dollars! Then I bought a gigantic office space, spent half the day drawing up rooms and adding props. A few hours later I had 1500 Mill $ in the bank, a thriving MMO and the ability to produce and store millions of copies of my own games. That is to say: I was done. No new consoles coming out anymore. Nothing more to aspire to. Game Over!It's like the game doesn't have proper stages for advancement. At one point, my worker ants were making a AA game. I clearly didn't have the staff for it, because it took about 20 years to finish, and every year I'd show up with a booth at the convention just to pick up more fans along the way. The fans stayed true and loyal for 20 years as I was promising to deliver. That aspect is something Game Dev Tycoon did really well. If you didn't publish within a certain timeframe after marketing your game, you'd lose fans so fast it looked like a snowball rolling downhill, heading straight for your office.If I had to do it all again, I'm pretty sure I could reach the same level of success in half a day, and that's not a game worth money to me. There's not much replayability here. I know, because I don't want to go through this circus again. Besides, games like this are only really fun before you graduate to the big leagues, at which point it becomes a managing nightmare. This is why in real life we delegate! I don't want to have to tell that guy to do these same six things with every game I make! He should learn to do this automatically, because that's what I'd tell him to do if this was real life! I'm the boss! I don't wanna deal with all the little things. I have minions for that! I just wanna make the big decisions! There's management, and then there's micro-management.When all is said and done, this game goes a smidge deeper than Game Dev Tycoon, but there are simply too many faults, missing pieces and lack of focus for me to think that Mad Games Tycoon will ever match the geniusly simplistic, polished marvel that is Game Dev Tycoon. Scrap this one. Start over. As for my recommendation: Don't buy! I want my money back, and this tragic game off my games list.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've only played this game around an hour but that's long enough I reckon to give me the feeling that I don't care for it overly much. I'm not saying it's bad, but I couldn't get straight into it like I did Game Dev Tycoon, which I think is better. There's just something about it - it seems to be missing something, soul, atmosphere, appropriate sound effects and game feedback. I don't feel immersed and I don't care about my character. Everything happens so damn fast, too.There are other issues, like lack of a tutorial or help, so you have to figure it out for yourself. Personally I also find many of the sound effects annoying (and the music) so I turn them down (many sound like something out of the early 90s). I don't much care for the UI either - too much clicking and mousing around for buttons. Another thing that annoys me is that my character is always followed/surrounded by icons and other info graphics, especially when he is at the desk working. It seems cluttered and looks ugly.On the plus side, the graphics are otherwise generally nice and the devs seems to have put quite a lot of thought into the game dev world elements (but it doesn't work as well as Game Dev Tycoon). And to their credit the devs seem to be very active in developing and updating the game.But I just can't get excited about it, it leaves me cold, and somewhat irritated. If they halved the price, I might say it was worth a buy, but at present, I regret my purchase decision.

number of helpful: 0 of 12 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								30 hours in, early access review.Thumbs down because it's in Early Access, it needs a lot of balancing, and some of the current implementation seems baked in that I don't like. However...The game gives good process, in a Civilization-like manner. You have a couple desks, you release a game, make money, buy more desks, add more rooms, sell more copies, buy a bigger place etc etc etc. This part is very addictive since there really is a ton of stuff (9 different desks, 20-some different rooms, 100+ game subjects etc) to build and set up. However...Balance: Easy is a walk in the park, while Normal suddenly becomes practically impossible to make money, unless you just concentrate on making game engines and doing contract work. I can't imagine this being what the develoers had in mind. You can release a game that gets good reviews, and release a game with the same staff and setup 6 months later and get Worst Game Of The Year award.Design decisions: You start in a garage with not much space, but enough for a small dev space, research center, toilet, and perhaps a marketing office. All this needs to be outfitted a la The Sims. Desks over there, plants over here, lighting, heating, ceiling fans, first aid kid, and on and on. Quite fun in fact. But then you make enough money to move to a bigger place. The game sells all your stuff and plops you down in an empty room where you have to do the whole thing over again. This is less fun. And there are TWELVE different building sizes, and each time you have to put the rooms, desks, plants, lights... This appears baked into the design. It would be so much better to add onto existing space, so you could have fun designing the more exotic rooms you didn't have access to before, because you didn't have the space.There are other balance issues, like getting access to console research when you barely have enough money to buy toilet paper, the bank's suicidal-like willingness to continue to loan you ever increasing amounts of money, despite never having made a successful game (Normal difficulty), but this is EA, so we'll see.Steam forums are dead, but perhaps discussion of this game takes place on another forum.Which raises the question: How do you make a 'deep' game with this subject matter? As a gamer, you have foreknowledge of the history of games. Adventure games were really big for a while, but now they're not. The Dreamcast flopped. The PS is gonna be big. If you know all that, the game should be easy. If you don't know that (or set the game to random trends) then the winning and losing will appear arbitrary.I'll be back for 1.0.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have one comprehensive criticism with this game. I don't think this will change, at all, although it's just in pre-alpha. And, that is, that they have this pop-up boxes PLUS they animate the entire screen once the pop up boxes are clicked off.Why is this a problem? It is an epilepsy hazzard. Even though, I don't think I have it, I am very sensitive to screens flashing all over the place.For instance, WoW had an animation whereupon if you were in a vehicle and you were taking damage, they made a red vignette flash around the screen. When I contacted Blizzard about it, they had already provided to completely remove it.I understand that the pop-ups are there to create interest in the game, but literally, they could provide a side icon that is permanent, that could light up when whatever state is ready, lights it up.I notice that if something small is on the screen, permanently there, and if it simply lights up, it doesn't cause so much eye stress.Secondly, losing control of the game is terribly annoying to me. And, this is the 2nd complaint about these pop-ups.Let's think about this for a second. If I am the executive director of a company, no one is going to send me a pop-up to tell me they are done with their poster marketing campaign. In fact, I find it highly juvenile that you don't have a queue of tasks for all departments.Also, you have no feedback, nor projections of what tasks are hoped to accomplish by their monetary expenditure.You've flushed out the other Game Tycoon games, but have left out the key components of why the successsful tycoons were so successful, feedback.You can't have a game with the detail of self production and self publication and leave out any feedback of what you're going to get from spending any money or contracts, or campaigns.

number of helpful: 0 of 14 people (0%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								I can't really recommend a game that's unplayable. How is it unplayable? Well, the game's purpose is the simulate a game development studio. The main mechanic of the game is the allotment of resources to the different aspects of a game. Should you focus more on game depth or beginner friendliness? What percentage of the budget should you devote to graphics vs. sound? etc. Apparently, the game favors particular combinations of the sliders which represent these values. Thus, to create a successful game, you need to randomly guess what would make a game of that genre and of that topic successful. Good luck with that, as after an hour of trial and error I have yet to come up with anything. There isn't even a good wiki or forum to reference (although I am a big believer that a game should never require you to utilize outside resources in order for you to play it). I honestly don't know how there are any positive reviews, as I don't know how anyone could figure out how to do well in this game. Of course, I could be completely wrong about all of this, as there is no tutorial yet. So for all I know, I may have completely misinterpreted everything. I might try this game again after I watch some Let's Plays and they release a tutorial.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												I do not legitimately review games on steam very oftenI also do not try to say that another game was trying desperately and failing to be another game, I'm not that black and white about games.But boy, I only had 30 minutes with this game and requested a refund asap because gOD THIS GAME!Since I'm a lazy frick tho, I'm gonna just post the notes I wrote down while playing and then expand on themlets begin*I expected a GDT wannabe*Read good reviewsI saw this game and the first thing I thought was "why would I buy this if I already have Game Dev Tycoon" BUT saw so many people say "but it's better than GDT tho" and said "aww what the heck" and wanted to try it out*I'm not impressed yet*THIS GAME LOOKS UGLY!*AAAAAAAAAAAAOkay, listen here, I'm not that dweeb that judges a game by how it looks, I could name so many games I like that don't look that good. However, the freaking MAIN MENU just looked SO gross. Not only that but I looked through the logos for a company and found issue with this too.You see, the custom logos are full of parody companies, which are chuckle worthy, but if you want a custom name it generally wouldn't match up with the logo. Now, some people could ignore this, it's small I understand, but for someone like me that would...NOT want a mismatched name and logo (I'm weird okay?) I have to go with the generic logos. Which would be fine (again I know my issue can be considered a personal problem) but the generic logos look...dumb, like they put so little effort into them because they were just SO PROUD of they're funny parody logos (The EA parody logo isn't even a parody...it's just a blunt EA).On top of all this, when I finally pick a logo and a name, it shows me the portrait of our player characterit literally looks like some garbage I'd see in a low budget game from the early 2000s......or a no budget game indie game with 0 effort or soul behind itI just got annoyed looking at everything.*Starts new game*The graphics look even grosser when you start playingRefer back to what I said about how the game looks like low/no budget garbage and double itI hate it.Now before someone brings it up, I wanna go back to Game Dev Tycoon, the game I can't help but say this game is trying to beI like Game Dev Tycoon's graphics because it has a style, it's cartoony and even tho it's not amazing, it works for what it is. Mad Game Tycoon's graphics look like a game with an identity crisisand a brain tumor...*This perspective bugs meIdk how to explain this, I genuinely don't, but the camera angle just...pisses me off to look at, feel free to ignore this point if you want to, but mixed with the ugly visuals the camera just makes me angry.*I'm so boredThis kinda speaks for itself*Try to make first game*Um*Did I mess it up?*I had to restart the game cuz it glitchedThis is when the game 100% lost me, the game was teaching me how to play, I placed down desks in my office and the game told me to start development on a game. I grabbed my guy, dragged him over to the leftand...he got stuck, I don't exactly know what happened but he just kinda got stuck. I didn't know what to do so I just started clicking things, I clicked the desks and they...disappeared, like entirely, they were removed for no reason and guess what?My guy was still frozen.So I basically had to restart the entire game because the gamestoppedworking.Like...was this just me? I wasn't trying at all to break it and it just...broke.*Try to make game again*Religion!?*Idk if the tutorial stopped becuz my game glitched but I have no idea what the heck any of this meansI was going through the menus and stuff and I saw what it was trying to do, it was the same concept of GDT's game development menu, with just a little more added in. Thing is, I didn't get to figure out what half of it meant, because the game broke and when I restarted the tutorial just didn't turn oneven tho I did not disable the tutorial before starting up the second game.A lot of the options on the second page were just labeled "My Games:", didn't know what they meant, never found out cuz I stopped caring before I found out, whatever.*I um...started development but...nothings happening*My guy's just walking around*OH! OK! I HAD TO DRAG MY EMPLOYEE TO HIS DESK!Nothing conveyed this to me...Nothing...Unless the tutorial said to do this but...FRICK man I wouldn't have been able to know...*H O W  I S  TH I S   BE  T  T E R  T  H A N   G A ME   D E V   T Y  C OOON!?*GDT worked becuz it was simple and straight to the pointThis game, from what I saw (including the reviews too), obviously wanted to have a hand over Game Dev Tycoon by adding more stuff, but I think this actually huurrrrttt the game more. Going back to my previous problem, I genuinely think the idea of having to drag the employee to the desk to make him to work, while not being a big problem, is just an inconvenience that I don't see the point in. Game Dev Tycoon was straight to the point with every thing, it was simple and because of that I didn't have to think as much about all the little things, which made it FUN TO PLAY! Now I'm not gonna say that adding more ruined it, it's just how it was done, I didn't care for any of what they tried to addit was just all...meh.*I'm still boredSee I had this idea for a big point I had against the game to put here, but I actually forgot it once I got to this part of my notes.So...oh well!*Everything moves so slow*Idk why the sales thingy is moving so slow and nothing is being conveyed to me, I can't even see the ratings*Everything keeps moving and releasing before I even have time to reactWhen I released my game, I saw the sales thing pop up, but um...it just kinda moved really slowly...it didn't even give me the number rating for my game, one of the things that made Game Dev Tycoon fun to me. On top of this it kept saying consoles and games were being released before I even had the chance to figure out what was going onmix this with the other frustrations I had with this game and all I was left wonder was...*What is this game and why did I waste 14 bucks on this?This is the last time I trust steam reviews, even if they are considered "Most helpful", it tries so hard to be Game Dev Tycoon but is too busy with it's♥♥♥♥♥♥in a blender to actually be worth the money. Want my advice? Stay with Game Dev Tycoon and save your money for something more worth it.

number of helpful: 9 of 38 people (24%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8
												I had high hopes for this game, but ended up getting really dissapointed.To make a good game you need to know what topics work well with the gentre and what age rating it should have. Then you need to know PRECISELY how much points you should put on two different kinds of sliders, because if you are too far away from the amounts the devs intended you to put for that specific kind of game, the reviewers are going to♥♥♥♥♥♥all over it. And the worst part  is that you can't really find out what went wrong, the game just tells you what direction you should go on one kind of sliders and THAT'S IT. It's just like "yeah you should go to the right side with this one" but you don't know if you need to go ALL THE WAY to the right or just a little bit.The good thing about Game Dev Tycoon is that you could learn how to make a good game just by playing and analysing your games to find out how to make a game that sells well.But there when you start you are expected to figure out the perfect way to make a game all by yourself. but before you actually do that you will go bankrupt!Seriously, the only real way to play this game is by having a guide that tells you what you need to do to make a good game because the game doesn't give you any hint about it and straight up mocks you if you mess up!It tried to be a more "serious" tycoon game than Game Dev Tycoon, but it was nothing but frustration for me.Wish I could just get a refund, but I wasted too much time trying to figure out what I'm doing wrong.To quote one of the reviews in this game:"Stay away."

Watch it from afar to see if the developers are able to piece the game together. If they do, then this will be a game worth talking about.

content:
Posted: March 14
												To start off, I enjoy this quite a bit.  It's surprising how easily you can get sucked in. That said, there is one problem. The tutorial/help dialog is so small you can't really read it. Also, to switch to Full Screen you have to enable this in the options menu then restart the game. Unfortunately when you shut down the game all options return to the default setting, including resetting it back to windowed mode. The stratagy elements though are where it shines in my opinion. Do you focus on making and improving game engines which you license out, or purchese the right to use game engines from other companies? Do you specialize in making games, or focus on hardware. Do you create your own properties, or hire your studio out to make games for others? Do you keep your staff small, or expand to create multiple games/consoles at once?These decisions can make an impact. And I enjoy figuring out the best way to advance.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have seen alot of games in my life, from Rollercoaster Tycoon to Call of Duty and Fifa to The Sims. I can enjoy all sorts of games, so i am open for new things, and this one got me hooked for now xD so why not give my opinion on what seems to be a promesing game.Brings back memories, when i start playing and find myself still playing 4-5 hrs later.For me its the best 15€ i spend this year (i know, 2015 just started, but worth mentioning imo) and to be honest, i didnt expected that! It looked like an ok game to me, but its way better then i imagined.If you like tycoon games, are willing to put some hours into the game to get to learn it, and are a game-fan just like me, i would not hesitate and spend those 15€ on this game.Remember its early acces, it needs more fine-tuning, but no game-breaking problems encountered yet! (Seen ohter Early-Acces games doing much MUCH worse!)Developer is active on Steam forum, listening to their customers, something i can only praise!Game gets regular updates, adding content, so they are working on it! (i was very pleased to see an even larger company building after a certain update this week, no such thing as to much space :)All those who complaign its the same as game dev tycoon: 1) du-uh, they are both game dev tycoon games, and from what i hear (dont have game dev) there are plenty of differences....2)The more choices we have, the better! Healty competition is good for us, cusomers :)I really recommend this game to every game-fan!Thanks Eggcode for making this game, and keep up the good work and im sure this will become (already is) a game that will steal alot of free time hours!+Gameplay I like the Sims Style - build and decorate - ur company (More objects are always welcome)+Graphics are not SUPER but deff ok+Start small - Grow big+Deff worth its money-Sounds are getting enoying very quickly :/-Some important things should be added later (maybe u guys are already working on this)*A pause / speed up button. (while still being able to give commands PLZ :) )*Being able to adjust room sizes by dragging the walls? its a pain to have to sell the whole room and everything in it (and loosing alot of money in the process) because it should be 1 square larger to fit in what u want to fit in*Pauze development / research / ....*Simple tutorial!Learhing curves can be steep at the beginning! so why not start a tutorial in the smallest garage building, where u show ppl how to get set up right?...*More in-depth info on all sorts of stuff*More ways to spend ur money mid-late game*Why can other developers build their consoles, and not us? *More content, more objects, more more more xD

content:
Posted: September 24, 2016
												The developers continue to improve this fun business simulation of the electronic gaming industry by adding new gameplay features, enhancing graphics, and polishing the business model. Of course, these are all things you can do, too, after you release your own game in the game! You can play as a developer who focuses on creating games and then signing contracts with publishers to sell your games. Once you’ve saved or borrowed enough money, you can play as a publisher who manufactures and distributes games from other companies. You could also go the route of investing in technology to develop and market your own living room consoles and handheld systems, too. Or you can play as a character who does all of the above, keeping your company small or delving into the big corporate world of electronic gaming.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I've played this for a couple of hours now, and it's already grabbed me by the goolies. It looks like it's had a tremendous amount of thought gone into getting the gameplay right, and making interesting options for people to tinker with. I like the fact you can become a publisher as well as just a development company, should you want to. Just one example of adding variety to an already solid game experience.I suspect Early Access had a lot to do with getting the game so good at release, so hats off to the developers for doing it right and clearly listening to their paying customers. Definite thumbs up on this game, as it's clearly the best among all the other games of a similar theme. I hope the devs do very well with this game to reward them for their efforts. I don't feel the game is over-priced at all, as the effort involved in making it is clearly obvious.Well done.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2016
												Of all the games in my library that I keep coming back to, Mad Games Tycoon is one of the most enjoyable to replay. These sessions don't last too long but a game like MGT is best served, IMO, in a 5 hour stint on a lazy weekend, greatly enjoying the gameplay, reaching a level of completion that releases the desired amount of dopamine and then not touched for a few months so you forget the mechanics and have a pile of updates to come back to.With the constant updates, coming back to the game is just as enjoyable as the first time around. One build had an absolutely unplayable and quite frankly dangerous for my PC god tier memory leak, but that was fixed in a timely manner.If you're actively reading reviews for this game, chances are you'll enjoy it. I have absolutely gotten my money's worth out of it and it's likely you will as well.Mad Game Tycoon delivers the experience I paid for.

												This is a awesome game!  Great immersion as a game dev.   It reminds me of my childhood growing up with all the console systems. content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I've played this for a couple of hours now, and it's already grabbed me by the goolies. It looks like it's had a tremendous amount of thought gone into getting the gameplay right, and making interesting options for people to tinker with. I like the fact you can become a publisher as well as just a development company, should you want to. Just one example of adding variety to an already solid game experience.I suspect Early Access had a lot to do with getting the game so good at release, so hats off to the developers for doing it right and clearly listening to their paying customers. Definite thumbs up on this game, as it's clearly the best among all the other games of a similar theme. I hope the devs do very well with this game to reward them for their efforts. I don't feel the game is over-priced at all, as the effort involved in making it is clearly obvious.Well done.

												This one is truly awesome.Every gamer should play this at least once.It can give you the insight of how the gaming industry works.Updating, making sequels, choosing what genre to specialize in, estimating how many products I should make, determining which part to sacrifice while developing every genre, etc.After this, every time I get news about newly publised games, I can understand unseen decision makings done by the gamemakers during development.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2
												This game is very  similar to Game Dev Tycoon, but SO MUCH better! Game dev tycoon tries to follow the real trends of the industry from the 80s till present and the game then ends. Mad games tycoon keeps on going. There is a lot more option and ways to make great games and mint money. I have played this for hours and hours... having said that... the game is abit rought around the edges, the UI and menus is not polisted or intuitive, it feels more like a game made in the 1990s like Transport Tycoon. the staaf sorting system and how to deploy people leaves a lot to be desired. But I wholly recommend this game, it is a lot of fun to make a MMO game, then make addons and then make it Free to Play and see the moolah roll in!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24
												I had so many hopes for this games but no matters how many hours and effort I put into liking this game, I still cannot: it's boring and frustrating. The boring part comes from all the calculations you have to do to get the sliders balanced right and that are supposed to add realism to the game reminds me of a math class at school. The frustration part comes all from the reviews of the games you produce: no matter which topics/audience/genre you choose, or how you set the sliders or the percentage, the reviews tell you always the same (which is: graphics are the best, sound is ok, gameplay and controls are below average).. there is no clue about what went wrong and after so many hours thrown away on this game I'm starting thinking that: 1) either the game is broken 2) or there is no mechanics involved at all, it randomly choose a review to display. The only way I found this game enjoyable is not producing any game at all and focusing on contracts, that's the only thing that seems to work.. unluckly, there aren't contracts enough to keep a large staff so you're stuck with a small bunch of employers for the rest of the game, which is not that bad at start but after a while it becomes boring..A quick advice? Don't buy this game, it's not worth it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
												Early access done right and great game, if you like management games then this is for you, of all the "game tycoon" games this is the most complete and one of the best in the genre.The only thing this game misses? The possibility to create a platform like steam to sell digital games.For the rest you have pretty much everything: you can create your console, your mmo, your f2p, you can publish games for others if you don't want to develop anymore, you can buy other companies, print your own physical copies and decide what to put in the box, make bundles, the list can keep going for a long while but one thing is sure: it's one of the most complete business management games EVER made.Don't mistake this game for a bland pc version of game dev story, it's not quite complex as Capitalism but it's much more closer to it than it is to game dev story.

Posted: December 31, 2016
												I really like this a lot! Game Dev Tycoon was what got me into playing games like these, but this game on the other hand makes GDT look shallow (not that it was bad for Ireally enjoy GDT). There's a whole lot you do in this game, from producing copies of games, to improving various aspects of games such as music, graphics, and game design. It's a more complex kind of tycoon game that gives you a lot to do so if you enjoy some complexity, this is the game you should play!

												Another game that I can't recommend even through I played allot of it. But if I was not into development it would be boring and since I am it is kinda boring. You never design anything, you just have to do the perfect even I just like to do some werid stuff which is fun. And also sometimes it doesn't make sense.Sometimes you seem to get good scores and sometimes bad, and once you got under 40% you get the worst game of the year award, like there are no games of like 20% score. I mean for higher dificulty I see it but for easy? I mean you loose more fans than you would gain for any other award. I mean the award thing is just a gameplay device since noone really cares about awards. Are there even real game awards who knows? I would even just put an Oscar into the trash can because it means nothing, totaly worthlose piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥Also I put in that the platform popularity should be random and it was like ever. Also how can PCs from the beginning on play AAA titles and why are there so many players on this platforms? If you think about it for a main part of the 80s it was only business people and school. So you don't get as many player as like with the Atari or NES. If you make popular games for console it doesn't change a thing of the popularity. Also if you get enoug money to make a console and selfproduce games than you make way to much money.But yeah this game is just boring. Game Dev Tycoon was boring and this is boring and the Game Tycoon of android was kinda fun. Because it was silly and you could play it on the go. It was a good idea for those concepts and from what I can tell the game never really changed so get the android game it is not wasting your time.
